TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sandy Macdonald (from 286 citizens) and Senator West (from 373 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Public Service: Higher Duties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned federal Public Servants respectfully submit that:

The introduction of a Public Service Act regulation removing appeals against higher duties of 12 months or less has the potential to undermine the principle of selection on merit and the principle of an apolitical public service and lead to staffing decisions based on patronage and favouritism.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Disallow the Public Service Act regulation removing the aforesaid appeal right.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the serious problem of illegal drug use in Australia, and the pressure applied by the drug traffickers upon young people to buy the drugs.
Your Petitioners call upon the Senate to:
urgently address the drug problem by way of educating our young people of the serious side and long term effects of taking drugs.
introduce tougher laws for those who are drug traffickers.

DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC SERVICE: ACCOMMODATION IN CIVIC, ACT

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reid) proposed:
That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)there is presently before the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works an inquiry into the proposal for the construction of the national headquarters for the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories at Barton, Australian Capital Territory,
(ii)the proposal for construction of the building in the Barton area is designed to transfer public servants from Civic to Barton,
(iii)for some years now a policy refusing permission for additional public servants to be located in Civic has existed, and
(iv)the policy of removing public servants and not removing the restriction locating public servants in Civic will add further to the run-down of Civic; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to halt the Public Works Committee inquiry at least until the ban on locating public servants in Civic has been lifted and consideration has been given to the needs of the various town centres for employment prospects.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This motion relates to the Public Works Committee's consideration of the proposed headquarters for the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. The Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), who is obviously handling this matter, is concerned about this issue for a number of reasons. On behalf of the government and the minister, let me say that we believe the motion should be rejected but, given the time considerations in the Senate, we will not be frustrating the inevitable evolution of how this will be handled by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: We cannot agree with the motion. We agree with Senator Reid's concerns about the broader planning issues for Canberra. However, we believe that her concern about a ban on public servants moving to Civic to replace those who moved to Barton is misplaced. We think the Public Works Committee is a process designed to elicit full public debate. The committee has already commenced its consideration of projects. It has allocated at least a full day this week to consider community and business concerns. We believe that the broader planning issues, including the town centre needs, are being considered by the committee.

As I said, time has been allocated this week to discuss those issues. Those issues are important. People should have the right to put them before the PWC this week. We also believe that future adverse impacts can be avoided. We do not believe that further moves from Civic are likely, providing competitive offers are made to tenants. Property rentals are now moving to more realistic levels, apparently as a result of prospective vacancies created by the proposed moves to Barton. The government will set up constructive mechanisms to have a better informed market. This will lead to better results in reintroducing regulation and compulsion.

It is our view that the alleged planning impact on Barton and Civic is incorrect. The actual impact is manageable. For instance, the number of staff involved in moving these projects from Civic to Barton is 1,450, not the 3,000 quoted. The projects have already met all the required planning guidelines. We are talking about two or more years to adjust. We are also concerned that these projects will have a positive impact on the ACT construction industry, something which Senator Reid should take into account. These projects will create some 500 jobs in the construction industry and we believe that potential workers should not be frustrated in obtaining those jobs.

Decisions are needed quickly by the interested tenants. It is quite obvious that deferring consideration by the PWC will simply encourage proposed tenants to move to other developments that bypass the Public Works Committee process. As we know, the PWC process attaches to proposals put forward by government and built by government. It does not attach to private sector developers. At the end of the day, if we use this sort of approach to frustrate the planning, building and locational needs of government departments, the direct result will be that people and departments will look outside the public sector for the provision of space.

The Commonwealth is undertaking development in the new town centres. For instance, DSS will be setting up a regional office in Tuggeranong. I do not want to go on at length on this but those points needed to be placed on the record. We believe this type of action only frustrates potential employees. It does not lead to good property management by government. At the same time, we recognise that there are planning needs to be taken into account. Those needs are being taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) referred in his closing remarks to property management. What I am concerned about is planning in the Australian Capital Territory, in particular the national capital, and the way it will appear to others. He also raised the question of construction jobs. I recognise that construction is an important part of the local economy, but you don't go on building and building anywhere just for the sake of jobs, because they only last for a few months in any event. Construction for its own sake does not and should not come ahead of planning.

PARA.TAB: What we are faced with in the Australian Capital Territory is an embargo, effectively, although some might try to say that is not the case, of public servants being allowed to move into Civic. We all know why that came about in the 1980s. I will not take the time of the Senate now to go through a couple of reports that dealt with it, but that is the fact. Times have changed quite dramatically since then and what we are seeing is public servants being withdrawn from Civic—in relation to the present proposal the number of public servants is somewhere between 1,400 and 1,500—at a time when there is already office space vacant in Civic. I have already mentioned that we are faced with a situation of not being able to move other public servants into that area. So we are creating a wasteland in Civic. Anything more detrimental to the overall appearance of the national capital you can hardly imagine.

What I am asking for is a halt on this until such time as proper planning consideration has been given to the future of Civic and to the other town centres. I do not believe you can look at one bit in isolation from the whole. At present there are no Commonwealth departments in Gungahlin. I do not know whether there ever will be, but at least it needs to be considered. We already have the impact on Woden of having taken departments out of there and placed them in Tuggeranong and there is space available in Woden. Now there is this massive increase in building in Barton. I believe the infrastructure of that area has not been adequately considered. There are submissions to the Public Works Committee from large organisations in the area which raised the impact on the area of this massive increase in construction.

There is no evidence that parking has been adequately considered. The ACT government planning committee has looked at it. There is another motion, which I shall be seeking to move as formal in a few moments, which deals with what that committee found. Perhaps I will refer to that now to save taking a great deal of time later in the morning.

The reference in motion No. 1892 is to the fact that the territory committee found that nowhere in the documentation is there any evidence Canberra's town planning objectives have been considered by the initiating agency or any other Commonwealth body. The minister, in referring to this, has dealt with construction and the needs of public servants; but it is the overall plan that is the important issue and it always has been. That is why Canberra is the beautiful city it is, and we do not want to spoil that.

At the present time in Civic the Commonwealth occupies about 310,000 square metres of office space; the ACT government, 50,000 square metres; and the private sector, 90,000 square metres—roughly 450,000 square metres in total. As to the proposals to move out of Civic at the present time, the Department of Industrial Relations occupies 11,400 square metres; the Australian Federal Police, 10,000 square metres—and let me say that there is absolutely no reason for them to be moving out of Civic, because there is no problem with their retaining the lease of the building they are presently in a very attractive building and well placed in Civic; the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories occupies 8,500 square metres; AusAID, 11,000 square metres; and the Department of Defence, 15,000 square metres. That is a total of just under 56,000 square metres. To take that many public servants out and to leave that amount of space vacant, when it is not possible to recruit other public servants at this stage to move into that area, would cause a huge impact on an area.

The other matter I ask the minister to take into account, which I think he obviously does not understand, is the actual role of the Public Works Committee and what they are required to look at. It is not the major planning issues. What has not happened, especially in relation to the building included in motion No. 1889, is that the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories requires a change to the plan before it can go ahead, and the matter has not gone before the Joint Committee on the National Capital and External Territories. Even if the Public Works Committee approves that building, it cannot proceed until the joint committee on the national capital has approved it also, and it has not come to that committee as yet.

That is another reason why the Senate, as it has, would support the motion that the matter not proceed before the Public Works Committee at least until it has gone to the national capital committee and proceeded in that fashion. That is why this motion specifically refers to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories.

I am sorry I have taken so long. I have dealt with only a small portion of my speech on this topic. The minister did make a quite lengthy statement and it seemed to me that that could not stand without some reply being given to it. It is an important matter and I am grateful for the Senate's support. I hope the government will act upon the decision the Senate has made this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the whips meeting this morning there was agreement that we would not oppose formality to motion No. 1892, but there was no agreement about formality to motion No. 1889. I was under the impression that Senator Reid was proceeding on motion No. 1892.

—by leave—There are two motions. I am told that the government would agree to motion No. 1889 as formal but make a statement. The minister has made a statement and I have made a response to it. In a moment I will seek to proceed similarly with motion No. 1892. If the minister speaks, I may have to speak; if he does not speak, I perhaps will not.
—by leave—I understand there has been some crossing of wires here. What Senator Reid has said is true.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not sure what we have just done. This is matters of formal business and there should be no debate. I have been studying a few things here, but I have also heard debate.
—You can do it by leave.

—I understand that, but I do object to this type of matter being so debated in what is a way of getting around the standing orders. I raise that as a very serious issue. Any senator listening would know there was a debate going on and would think it was done by leave. I knew that this measure was not to be taken as formal. Apparently, it has been taken as formal, but there has been a full-scale debate by leave. I do raise this very seriously, and I want to make it clear that I certainly did not vote on that particular matter because other members—

—Senator Harradine, I have allowed you to make a point, but you do not have leave to make a statement. I point out that others have been given leave by the chamber to make a statement and so were acting perfectly properly. Do you seek leave to make a statement?
—I do.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Quorum formed) The Senate is faced with a most unusual situation, I believe. We really should seriously consider what we have done this morning. The position is that Senator Reid had sought for one of her notices of motion to be regarded as formal. Under the standing orders, there should be no debate. If there is no objection to a motion being regarded as formal, there is no debate. The motion is put immediately and it is either adopted or rejected.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion, that did not occur. The situation arose whereby leave was sought by Senator Bolkus to explain why the government opposed the motion at the time. He made his statement for about five minutes, although I could be corrected there. After he resumed his seat, Senator Reid rose and sought leave to make a statement, which in effect was a response to the points made by Senator Bolkus.

Normally speaking, this takes place in the form of a debate. It was in effect a debate, because Senator Bolkus made some points—which were more or less clarification points—about Senator Reid's motion, and a response was made by Senator Reid. This clearly was a debate. Although it was under the guise of statements by leave, it was a debate, in my view, and I believe it thus transgressed the standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, in view of your saying that this situation transgressed the standing orders, can I just point out that both speakers sought and were given leave by the chamber. I believe they did not transgress the standing orders, certainly in a technical sense.
