DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation and References Committees

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Bob Collins)—by leave—agreed to:

That Senator Coulter be discharged from further attendance on the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation and References Committees, that and Senator Lees be appointed a member of both committees.
Consideration resumed from 14 November.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move on to those amendments, could I ask the minister a couple of questions on the general thrust of the bill with respect to the weight restrictions on the curfew?
—Yes, you may proceed on that.

—On 7 April 1995 a company called Charrak Air Pty Ltd was given approval to operate Lockheed Electra aircraft, which are chapter 3 noise certified, at Sydney airport during the curfew period. The approval was given by the then Civil Aviation Authority and, on the basis of that approval, the company involved from Victoria made a total investment of approximately $6 million. In fact, the letter from the Civil Aviation Authority to the Director of Charrak Air pointed out very clearly that there were no blanket restrictions on propeller driven aircraft, although I understand the reason for the weight restriction. That was to prevent very noisy aircraft such as Hercules being used for freight. However, this particular aircraft is a chapter 3 aircraft. It made the investment on the basis of the approval given by the authority, which also pointed out, I might say, that with the opening of the Badgerys Creek airport all freighters would be required to go to Badgerys Creek, which it did not object to.

PARA.TAB: The question I want to ask—this is apparently an unintended consequence of the bill—is: does the government believe that it is liable, or could be liable, for damages by Charrak Air for having given approval and then having introduced a bill which we are now debating which will prevent that aircraft from doing the job for which it was purchased?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that in fact no approval was given. I am advised that the department advised the company. I am also advised there is no unintentional consequence. It is a quite deliberate consequence, I might say, for the benefit of residents that the BAe146s have in fact been determined because of their particular flight characteristics—as Senator Parer knows, they are a particularly quiet aircraft—as being the standard, if you like, for aircraft operating. The intent is not to permit the opportunity for that to be circumvented by larger props which are in fact noisier. I know Senator Parer is fully aware of the particular noise problems of a Lockheed Electra. They are in fact significantly noisier than the BAe146.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that the operator was simply told of the then existing restrictions under the then regulations, and was advised of that simply as an information exercise. I am further advised that the operator of the company was specifically advised that, particularly after the establishment of the Morris committee—that is, the major examination of all of these issues before a parliamentary committee—the situation then had to be considered, by the operator, to be fluid and could change, consistent with what might happen in respect of any outcomes from that Morris committee.

My advice from the officers is that no formal approval was given; that the operator was advised of the existing situation and that that has been interpreted, I think by some wrongly, as an approval. But further, specific advice was given to the operator that that situation could not be considered to necessarily remain after the Morris committee, particularly, had been established; and that there is no unintended consequence. It is deliberately intended that aircraft that are noisier than the 146, those with large props like an Electra, cannot get around these provisions by coming in during these hours, and that is why the limit has been set at 34,000 kilograms. If Senator Parer has specific advice that a formal approval was given, I would like to see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do. It was an approval given on 7 April 1995. On the basis of that approval, this company went ahead and purchased the Lockheed Electra, which is a chapter 3 aircraft.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —But, with respect—and I am not complaining about it—something like this possibly would have been much more easily handled outside of the chamber in terms of getting this clarified. What I am now advised is that the approval of 7 April was probably given without having seen the thing—an approval given for the actual operation of the aircraft by the air safety authorities. That is, it is not an approval that is related to noise levels at all hours of operation; it is simply the formal approval that is required to actually operate the aircraft in Australian airspace.
—That is not correct.
—That is the advice I am given. I am as anxious as you are to have this resolved, but it is a bit hard to do so in a committee debate across the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, let me just give you a letter. There was a letter from Lee Kenner of the Civil Aviation Authority to a Mr Barry Miller. It was to do with the operations of aircraft into Sydney during the curfew period. It was not just in relation to the registration of an aircraft.
—This is the 7 April 1995 approval?
—Yes. In part it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The curfew regulations are set by the department. I would recommend you check that no changes are envisaged with Mr David Southgate of the environmental section.

That occurred and, as I indicated, it was drawn to their attention that there was a committee sitting. But, curiously, the committee was looking at jet aircraft. This company was not given the opportunity to make, nor would it have made, a presentation because it did not see itself at risk.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the officers are aware of that correspondence. It is totally consistent with the advice I have just given the committee. The Morris committee had not been established in April, and the advice is consistent.

PARA.TAB: I do say, with respect, that it is very difficult to easily handle this kind of detailed stuff—with correspondence which I do not have in front of me, I freely confess—in the committee stage of the debate. The officers are familiar with the letter. In fact, they have just advised me that that letter specifically, as well as saying what it says, directs or advises the company to contact the department for further advice. That further advice was given consistent with what I have just told the committee that, under the regulations that existed at that time, that would be permitted.

But I am advised that oral advice was given directly to the company by the department that that had to be considered to be fluid at the time of the establishment of the Morris committee, because there was no way that the department could judge what the outcomes and recommendations of that committee would be and, therefore, what parliament would subsequently do with respect to that issue. I have simply had all of that advice reconfirmed and I am assured that that is absolutely consistent with the correspondence that Senator Parer has just referred to, because the Morris committee was established post-April 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Barry Miller wrote to Mr David Southgate—
—We can table the chronology of all this.
—Have you got the chronology?
—We can get it.

—You will have the chronology there. The point I am making is that you have claimed some sort of oral advice was given to Charrak Air. But was there any written advice given to this company, because on the basis of written advice it received it went ahead and spent $6 million?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Parer understands the position I am in on as detailed an issue as this. I represent the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in here. Of course I am familiar with the bill and the amendments that are to be moved to it and I am prepared to debate those. As the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, I am not familiar with the issue of this company and its correspondence. It is very difficult on this nuts and bolts stuff to effectively progress legislation during the committee stage of debate. I simply have to rely on the advice the officers are giving me every five minutes in order to respond to your detailed questions.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that the officers are aware of this matter. I am advised there was no unintentional consequence in respect of this weight limit that has been set at 34,000 kilograms. These restrictions, for the benefit of the people of Sydney—and that is why I find it a little difficult, I have to say, to equate what you are saying now with the position that the opposition presumes to adopt on looking after the residents of Sydney—are not unintentional; they are deliberately intended to keep noisy aircraft like Electras out of the airport after curfew hours.

Everyone who has flown on a BAe146, even from inside it, knows what they are talking about. Those aircraft have a particular characteristic of performance in that they are one of the quietest aircraft in the world. The freight operators have bought them for that reason. The government does not want the standard that is set for a BAe146—and that is where the weight comes from—to be circumvented by allowing large prop jets, which are noisy, to then use the airport during the curfew hours. That is all I can advise you on, Senator Parer.

I am told that the company was advised. I am sure—I make the obvious point—if the company feels it has been disadvantaged and if it has a cause of action as a result it will take the appropriate action through the courts to do that. All I am saying is that I presume it is a matter for the courts. It is very difficult to have the matter debated in here during the committee stage.

There was no unintentional consequences. I make that clear. The government did not want aircraft of this type, which are noisy—and they are, as I am sure you know—operating during the curfew hours. The Electras are noisy. I have flown on the things. The BAe146 was the standard. That is what has been set.

I am advised by the officers the company was advised in conversation that after the establishment of the Morris committee there could be no guarantees given that the existing regulations would remain because a potential recommendation clearly was that the regulations would be tightened up for the curfew. Subsequently, that is what has happened. I freely say to Senator Parer that I am personally not across this issue because I am not the Minister for Transport. That is the advice I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue this at great length, but I do support the view that you expressed about noisy aircraft. I think in your second reading speech you referred to Hercules aircraft; that the reason for this measure was to prevent noisy aircraft like the Hercules being used during the curfew period, even though during the curfew period they must take off or land from the south.

PARA.TAB: Even though things do go to the Morris committee, it does not mean that the government is going to put them into legislation. I ask: was Charrak Air advised of this, bearing in mind it purchased the aircraft on the advice of agreements reached with the then Civil Aviation Authority at that time and the department, before purchasing aircraft?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice that I have had on this issue has come directly from the officer who personally spoke to the company. I am told that the company did not commit to the aircraft until July. I am assured, straight from the horse's mouth, by the officer who spoke to the company that prior to the company committing to the purchase of the aircraft it was advised of the potential difficulties it would be in if it went ahead and did it.

—I made statements last night indicating that I would listen to the debate, and now might be a good time to put our position on the line so that people on either side know where we stand. There are obviously a number of issues that we need to be dealing with relating to any increased use of the east-west runway. An obvious and important issue is to always put safety first; politics should not ever be the reason we make any decision on a matter of this nature. It should always be the best decision. I am not sure that the wording of this amendment will deal with the ability to make the best decisions in the way the runway will operate. If, by the best experts and those operating the runway—

—Senator Margetts, if you do not mind I will interrupt for a moment. At this stage we are not debating the amendments; Senator Parer has not moved them. We are dealing with the bill generally and an aspect of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 1, page 1, line 4, omit "Curfew", substitute "Operations".
2.After Part 3, page 15, insert the following Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART 3A-OTHER NOISE ABATEMENT MEASURES
Ministerial direction to AA

SPEECH.PARA: 20A. As soon as possible after the commencement of this Act, the Minister must give a direction under section 16 of the Air Services Act 1995 to require Airservices Australia to revise the noise abatement procedures for Sydney Airport to disperse more equitably the noise generated by the operation and use of aircraft landing at, or taking off from, Sydney Airport by increasing the use of the runway known as the east-west runway.".
3.Title, page 1, omit "and for related purposes", substitute "and to impose other noise abatement measures at Sydney Airport".

Last night the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) during his second reading speech invited me to make some comments. Senator Collins talked about political opportunism. If ever there was a bunch of political opportunists, it is the people who sit on the other side of this chamber. Senator Collins will remember that in 1988 he and I, both humble backbenchers, sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure. At the time, there was an FAC proposal for a new medium-spaced runway on the basis that all three runways would continue to be used.

PARA.TAB: The new runway would mean that there would be more take-offs and landings from the south; hence the reasoning given in the minority report—Senator Collins nods—that there would be less noise to the people on the north, the east and the west. The overwhelming evidence supported the fact that this procedure should take place, but because the government policy of the day had consistently—from 1983 on—been that it would not build a new runway, he vowed to sign himself to a majority agreement which said, `Let us go ahead with Badgerys Creek, and maybe down the track we might need to build a new runway.' That was the thrust of the report.
I remember saying to Senator Collins at the time, `Bob, I never thought you would put your name to an inherently dishonest report based on the evidence given.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't remember that conversation.

—I remember it well. His response to me—which you will love, Senator Collins, because it is right up your alley—was, `You would not want to stand in the way of a potentially brilliant political career, would you?'
—I tell you what: your memory's better than mine.

—I have a great memory. I remember it well because you were a very active participant in the committee. In fact, when I gave my speech on the report, I recall saying—I have not looked up the Hansard but I remember saying it—that, if we are going to go through all the hassle of having all these people come and give evidence before committees and then not come out with a report that really truthfully reflects the representations on that committee, it would be a waste of time. I make that remark because Senator Collins was pretty quick on his feet here to talk about political opportunism. I would say that he is right up there with the lot of them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins also cited examples of people who had opposed the opening of the east-west runway on safety grounds. He talked about Airservices. He went through all the presentations made to the committee on air services. But there are a few key issues. When you ask them the question: aren't you required to do what you can to promote government policy? their answer is, `Of course.' I understand that. Basically, the whole thrust of this operation of Sydney airport has been a political decision—not advice given by the old CAA or the old FAC—made to the surprise of former Senator Graham Richardson and probably to the surprise of Senator Collins because he never expected the government to turn 180 degrees on building the new runway.

We had Senator Evans here as the minister at the time saying, `No, we're going to go ahead with Badgerys Creek.' That was in 1989. Seven or eight years later what has been done out there? Very little. People believe this government. What happened? As former Senator Richardson said on the way to the forum, he does not know. I think he and Senator Collins suspect and a lot of people know that he got bushwhacked at a meeting with the then Prime Minister and the current Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't there.

—I know you can absolve yourself from all this blame, but then you had the job of carrying the can. You then go on to refer to organisations such as BASI and you keep referring to Simops. When I talk about the reasons for our amendment, I am not going to mention Simops or any other method of operation.
—It's a dirty word, is it?

—No, but let me say to you that, from the point of view of BASI, you do not want to misquote BASI on all this. BASI did not throw Simops out. When that near miss occurred at Sydney airport, BASI did not recommend that Simops be abandoned.
—I said that yesterday.
—I agree; you made the remark.
—They said the frequency slowed down.
—They did not even say that. Let us get the facts straight. What you did as minister was preclude international flights from using Simops but you allowed all domestic flights to use Simops.
—No, I didn't. The Civil Aviation Authority did that.

—Anyway, you talked about Simops and BASI. Let me talk about the Civil Aviation Authority, which is now Airservices. It is not credible. It has no option but to push the government's line. There is also another method of operation which can be used and which has been given to the committee by a lot of people, including Flight Transportation Associates, which you tried to denigrate yesterday. Flight Transportation and others talk about dependent operations. The regional operators, Tamair and the others, have come in and used a man of great credibility, as even Senator Collins will acknowledge—Alan Tirrell. Alan Tirrell and the regional airlines will argue that it is much more dangerous. Safety is all based on degrees of relativity because two runways are more dangerous than one and one runway is more dangerous than none. It is simply a matter of relativity.
—Even staying at home is dangerous.

—Of course, it is all relative. People are trying to run these scare campaigns. Senator Collins came in here and talked about royal commissions. He said that it will all be our fault and that this is a brave amendment. You should listen to the explanation and should not close your ears to what I am about to say because it makes a lot of sense.

PARA.TAB: Flight Transportation has made it very clear in a subsequent submission that these claims that are made are without foundation because a lot of work has not been done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this FTA you are talking about?
—Yes.
—I have the submission here.

—I was talking about the regionals. As I said, one of the most respected person in the whole aviation business has been Alan Tirrell. The regionals claim that it is more dangerous for planes crossing over in flight, which happens very regularly at Sydney airport, than crossing over on the ground.

PARA.TAB: It is also claimed, not just from the point of view of planes running into one another but from the point of view of safety in respect of residents, that it is more dangerous having that sort of flight pattern, where aircraft are covering urban areas of some 60 kilometres, when, with a more appropriate operation, those planes, when approaching Sydney airport, whether from the north, the west or the south, could have a more direct route.

I do not have to remind you of what happens. You go to Sydney from time to time, and you fly in towards Sydney airport. We all do. You will notice that, as you get almost on the approach to the old east-west runway, you go north, go up to the Pymble beacon, turn around and, depending on what other traffic is in the area, you may or may not cross aircraft coming in to the two parallel runways. Senator Collins referred to the air traffic controllers. He referred to selected pieces of the evidence given before the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The press statement issued by the president.
—The press statement put out by the president in December 1994 was the one you did not have. I will just quote what the controllers say. Mr Loreschy says:

SPEECH.PARA: Sydney airport's east-west runway can be safely re-opened . . .
He goes on to say:

. . . it would take some months to develop and implement revised procedures, ruling out any quick fix to the noise problems and increased congestion following the opening of the third runway . . . The controllers say they could devise new operational procedures to operate Sydney as a three-runway airport if the political and community will is there to re-open the east-west runway.
He also says, in answer to a question that I raised in the Senate select committee on 12 July 1995:
The use of certain runways is a political decision.

Senator Collins came in here yesterday and, in his second reading speech, said that the government is not in a position—he is right—to tell people how to run an airport, that it does not have that expertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what your amendment is doing.

—I will get to the amendment. What Loreschy said was that the use of certain runways was a political decision. Politicians made the decision about what is happening at Sydney, not the experts. Let me tell you the basis of our amendment. Our amendment is not intended to tell Airservices how to run Sydney airport. Prior to 4 November 1994, there were two runways at Sydney, both of which were active. Following the government's decision and the early opening of the new parallel runway, the CAA, as it was then, was given three runways, of which 1 were active. What we are saying in our amendment is that we want to give back to Airservices—and let them get all the expert advice in the world—three active runways. They can then make a determination, based on the three competing ends—capacity, safety and noise—and come out with the best possible solution.
—That is not what the amendment says.
—The amendment does not tell people how to open it. It just says `reopen it', and you go ahead and do it.
—It just refers to enforcing increased use. It does not allow the best judgment to be used.

—We are not, in the amendment, directing them how to do it. Bear in mind that in the past Airservices quite happily operated the old cross-runway—and not under the direction of politicians. I think, if my memory is correct, the usage of the east-west runway was about 46 per cent—or maybe a little less, 35 or 40 per cent. The decision was made on the grounds of weather conditions, safety, noise and so on. We are suggesting that they do that, because they can not use it now, except in extreme conditions. We spent all that money and we have 1 of the runways active, because you cannot take off to the north, again a policy decision—
—You want take-offs to the north, do you? Talk about two bob each way.
—If you want to seek balance—
—That was to reduce noise for the residents.

—I, Senator Bourne and others have been through this and all we can tell you is that you have to sort out the three competing ends, which are, to repeat them, safety, capacity and noise. You have to give Airservices that flexibility. They do not have it at the moment, and they do not have it because of a blatant political decision by this government which it took at the time. Evidence given to my own committee showed that there was no regard for safety. Safety was insignificant in that decision. There was apparently a telephone call from somebody to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the Treasurer (Mr Willis), or both. It took your party by surprise. For 10 years—
—Have you talked to Buck Brooksbank about this? Have you seen the statements he has made?
—What would you expect from the acting chief executive? What about Mr Pollard?
—Oh, I see.

—When you get up and respond to this, I will go back through all the others. I will go through all the people who have supported the notion that flexibility should be given to the operators of this particular airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The gymnastics Senator Parer has just been performing were extraordinary indeed in trying to portray this amendment of his as not directing the people who actually operate Sydney airport how to operate it. It absolutely confirms what I said yesterday: this is really one of the loopiest pieces of legislation that has ever been brought to this parliament. I am sorry it has got the imprimatur of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the guy that wants to be Prime Minister of Australia.
—The amendments are not too special, either.

—It is the amendment I am talking about. That is legislation. The opposition's amendment that has been brought in here for legislative change is loopy. As Sir Humphrey Appleby would have said, it is a very courageous piece of legislation indeed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer has delivered a whole lot of highly inaccurate stuff in the last 10 minutes, which he is well aware of, including the absolute whopper—it is nonsense—that I as minister directed that international operations should cease using simultaneous operations. That is nonsense. I did not run air traffic control, nor would I presume to. That is what you are doing. That is nonsense.

I remember the day very well—I will not forget it—when that conflict nearly occurred on that intersection because of simultaneous operations. I will never forget it. I was minister at the time. I know exactly how you would have felt if you had been sitting in that particular seat.

I tell you what, it gives you a different perspective about these issues, and I freely admit it. I spent 10 years in opposition and during those 10 years I was shadow minister for almost everything. It gives you a whole new perspective when you are actually sitting in the seat and you are a minister. It is a completely different situation.

It was not a happy situation, as you described it, Senator Parer. Airservices Australia, or the then Civil Aviation Authority, did not happily operate simultaneous operations with potential conflicts on the ground and in the air at Sydney airport. In fact, it cannot be said any better than by them. Senator Parer tries to insist that this amendment does not interfere with how Airservices Australia operates Sydney airport from a safety and capacity point of view. The statement they made this year says:

SPEECH.PARA: Air Services Australia today reaffirmed that while parallel runways were available at Sydney airport it would not be prepared to restore simultaneous, independent runway operations using the east-west runway in intersecting operations with parallel north-south runway systems.

That is their position, which this amendment seeks to direct them to change. The situation is that, yes, you can operate simultaneous operations on intersecting airports—they do around the world—but, as the evidence that has been given to your committee and was certainly given to me in the three years I was minister indicates, it requires a greater degree of constant diligence and professionalism, which is always there, by both pilots and air traffic controllers in order to do so, particularly when you are going to operate with frequencies of up to 80 movements an hour, which is going to happen at Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: The reason this happened, as Senator Parer knows, is that a lot of the airports around Australia and around the world which have this expensive infrastructure have got intersecting runways because they date from the days when aircraft could not do anything else except land directly into the wind.

TALK.START.PARA: —So does Sydney.

—That is correct. They are old airports. They have been continually upgraded and continually strengthened instead of being rebuilt. They are leftovers from the days when the aircraft's performance did not allow anything other than a direct landing into the wind for the safest landing. The high performance aircraft that are available now do not have to operate in such tolerances. That is why most of the new airports established around the world, including Badgerys Creek, have got parallel runways instead of intersecting runways. The aircraft available can now use parallel runways. They do not have to fly in the same tolerances they had to 20 years ago when all these other airports were built.

PARA.TAB: Why do you then have simultaneous operations? This is the huge hole in the coalition's position, and they know it. They just wash their hands and say, `Oh well, we're not actually telling them how to operate the east-west runway.' Although you will not admit it, Senator Parer, if you operate the east-west runway in the way you are suggesting—that is, without simultaneous operations—then you absolutely destroy the capacity at the airport; you slow it down. Simultaneous operations are implemented in order to increase frequencies. Yes, they can operate.

The cold, hard facts are that intersecting runways increase the number of potential conflict points between aircraft both on the ground and in the air. That is a fact. Parallel runway operations reduce the number of potential conflict points. I am glad that you have said that, Senator Parer, because you are absolutely correct: it is all relative. Parallel runway systems are safer than intersecting runway systems. Single runways are safer than—

TALK.START.PARA: —That assumes no use of the east-west.

—You are right. I am agreeing with every word you have said. It is all relative. In respect of no runways being safer than single runways, I give Senator Burns 10 out of 10 for his observation that that would not be the case if you were trying to actually land on one. It is true and I agree with you, Senator. Parallel runways are safer than intersecting runways if you have got them to use—we now have them at Sydney, but they were not there in 1991—and a single runway is safer than having more than one runway, whether it is parallel or intersecting.

PARA.TAB: I want to lay to rest this nonsense that was put earlier in this debate—I notice it has not been run lately—that the second parallel runway does not actually cross the east-west runway and, therefore, you do not have to worry about whatever complications would be caused by now operating simultaneous operations with two parallel runways instead of just one intersecting runway. Of course, that is nonsense.

The aircraft have to cross the east-west runway at a particular point sooner or later to get to the airport terminal. This means that you have got an aircraft crossing that runway about once every 45 seconds, Senator Parer, whether you like it or not. What is unarguable is the fact that parallel runway operations reduce the potential conflict points. Sure, there are potential dangers; of course, there are. If pilots do not turn the way they are supposed to turn, then there will always be problems. But the number of potential conflict points with parallel runways, both in the air and on the ground, is significantly less than the number of potential conflict points on the ground and in the air with intersecting runways.

Let me show how threadbare the argument of the opposition is on this matter, and Senator Parer knows it. I know that he would be horrified if this amendment got up and became law. He knows that it is not going to get up, and I know that he is secretly grateful for that. This is a political stunt of significant proportions. It is designed to try to con the people of Sydney, and I am sure it will not succeed. But let me show how threadbare this attempted con was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. When I left this chamber yesterday, Senator Parer said in respect of the report from the FTA, `Oh well, you haven't caught up with the second report they've given us. You've only quoted their first report.' As soon as I left here, I said, `Where's their second report?' There is no second report, Senator Parer. What there is—I have it here and I read it last night—is a five-page fax sent to dear old Tony Williams, whom I have not seen for a while but who has made a lifetime career out of this particular operation—
—We have seen a lot of him lately.

—I saw a lot of him then. It is not a report at all, Senator Parer, and you know it. There has been no new work done, no new analysis, since 1989. Tony Williams contacted FTA asking them to send him five pages of discussion, and that is your so-called report. It does not do what you assert it does, as you full well know. The new paper contains no new analysis. It is the same data that was used in 1989. Indeed this discussion paper says that the previous analysis would have to be updated and expanded to recognise the current and projected future situation at KSA. I am quite sure that FTA would be very grateful for the work, if they were given a consultancy to do it. All that discussion paper does is draw again on the 1989 computer modelling.
—What is wrong with that? It is all computer modelling.

—What is wrong with it? As I said yesterday, it is a computer model based on an actual situation that does not exist—that is, with the main terminal buildings at Sydney airport being located between the two parallel runways and fast exit taxiways and all the rest of it. That is what is wrong with it. The computer model does not reflect the situation that actually exists at Sydney airport. I would have thought there were a few holes in that. As far as the capacity problems are concerned, as I said yesterday—and it is true—the FTA paper supports what all the other experts have said about those operations; that is, it would result in a reduction in capacity at Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: I can tell you from the horse's mouth, Senator Parer, how happy everybody was with simultaneous operations, from me down, including the Civil Aviation Authority and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. I sat in the seat and got the advice. You can do it, Senator Parer, and you know you can do it. Pilots and air traffic controllers, being the incredible professionals they are, operate in a highly technological and professional occupation that places enormous demands on their skills and so on. That is why they have such early retirement ages and a high frequency of burnouts, particularly the air traffic controllers. It is a very stressful occupation, particularly when something goes wrong.

That is the other problem with reintroducing the east-west runway and simultaneous operations. Simultaneous operations are difficult enough and it requires—the evidence has been given before your committee and it was always given to me—a very high degree of application by both pilots and air traffic controllers when every minute or so aircraft are on a potential collision course both in the air and on the ground. That is how they work. When there is something wrong and pilots have to keep going around and aborting landings, it makes the operation even more difficult and stressful. That is also a fact, Senator Parer, and you know it.

I can tell you that there was a sigh of relief around the place when those international operations were suspended at Sydney. They have never been restored. The only operator that was ever allowed to come back internationally operating Simops at Sydney airport was Qantas. The ban was never lifted from the day that it was imposed after that incident at Sydney airport.

What I said to Senator Parer was not simply political rhetoric—and he knows it—about royal commissions and so on. As I am sure most ministers do, when you go through the accident reports that you get from BASI and you go over to BASI and get briefed on all the incidents—I think of Seaview, Monarch and all those dreadful tragedies—particularly when you fly as often as we do, you can't help going over it in your own head when you take-off in situations that you really shouldn't be flying in.

I remember a particular flight I made in a Beechcraft Baron about two years ago from Canberra at night across mountains in bad weather. No doubt it was technically safe but I was very happy when I got on the ground at the other end. Our take-off was late because cabinet was delayed. We were supposed to be flying in daylight hours. You mentally sit in the aircraft and construct the accident report that is going to be written afterwards where BASI puts forward all the systemic things that went wrong that day that added up to a problem at the end of the day.

I can tell you that I have never seen anything asking for that like this loopy amendment. You have got the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation saying that you should not do this, you have got the people that run air traffic control at Sydney airport saying that you should not do this, and you have got Senator Parer and the people who want to be members of the government of this country telling us that the parliament should tell everybody they can do it. It is irresponsible and it should not be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there have been two points—not just two, but certainly two points—from the evidence to the airport committee that have been very clear to me. The first is that, yes, of course political decisions are made in relation to aviation and it is done all the time. The second is that far too many of those political decisions have been made in an ad hoc manner and not in a holistic manner that looks at all the technical reasons that should be looked at adequately or that takes account of everything that ought to be taken account of.

PARA.TAB: Operational decisions will always have a political dimension. I hope, and I do believe, that safety is always the primary political objective when politicians make decisions in relation to operational objectives. I think that is what has happened with this government and I think that would be true of any other Australian government. I certainly hope so.

Solving the disastrous noise problems associated with KSA will require a comprehensive approach. It will probably need to be innovative. It will almost certainly need to be highly technical. I have now come to the conclusion that just opening the east-west runway or indeed just doing what my second amendment would have done, which would have been to restrict movements per hour, are things that should not be done in isolation.

They may well be part of the ultimate solution that we come up with in the committee, but I do not believe they should be in this bill. Even though one of them is mine, I do not believe they should be done at this time. They should be done in a couple of weeks, if that is the case—if that is what we come up with in the committee.

We should wait until the committee responds and we have a comprehensive approach to this whole issue, then we should act on that comprehensive approach. I certainly hope that when the committee does respond the government does not agree with some pieces of what the committee recommends and disagree with other pieces, because I believe the committee will recommend something which is comprehensive and which should be looked at as a whole. As a result of all that, I will not be voting for Senator Parer's amendment; nor will I be moving the second part of my amendments, which would have been from No. 13 onwards.

I have been working with a group of very able residents who have been working with a group of experts and have been hoping to get together what I believe will be the basis of what the committee can look at for something comprehensive to come up with for KSA. I am hoping to speak with Senator Parer, Senator Forshaw, Senator Sandy Macdonald and other members of the committee and to see what they think of it. These may well be parts of what the committee comes up with, but I think now is not the time for us to move just bits and pieces of what should be a comprehensive response to the problems—and they are very major noise problems that Sydney's Kingsford-Smith has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few words to the comments made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). I would also like to take up the points just made by Senator Bourne, because I think she has brought us back to the proper perspective on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I have lived in Sydney all my life. I can remember when proposals about a second Sydney airport at Towra Point were talked about. I am happy to say that I was part of a campaign that stopped that, because it would have been an environmental disaster.

Of course, there have been proposals over the years about fixing the problems of Sydney airport. It probably is in the wrong place, at least on some arguments that can be advanced, but it is where it is and we cannot wish it away. It is certainly too small to handle the degree of traffic that any international city like Sydney has to cope with. Of course, it is also surrounded by heavily populated areas. So it is not a simple problem to fix.

Over the years we have continued to lurch from crisis to crisis or ad hoc decision to ad hoc decision to deal with the problem. What we now have in the amendment moved by Senator Parer—of course, it is really the proposition advanced by the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard—is another one of those ad hoc, knee-jerk, hopefully quick fix solutions. It is no solution at all, as the minister has outlined.

To me, that is a real problem because we are never going to fix the problems of noise, congestion, et cetera at Sydney airport by reacting in the way that this amendment proposes. There is a major problem now of increased noise for a reduced number of residents in Sydney—and that is a severe problem. We would like to fix it quickly if we could, but we are never going to fix that problem by just simply saying let us reopen the east-west runway and, not only reopen it, let us direct the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) to reopen it irrespective of what advice may come to the contrary from various safety experts. In some ways, that is how we got the problem we—the community and those on all sides of the chamber—have today; that is, in the past we have looked at just bandaid solutions to Mascot airport.

It was finally this government that took the decision to construct a second airport. It had been long talked about but very little had been done about it. We have got to get away from this sort of ad hoc approach. There are very good reasons why this proposal to reopen the east-west should not be implemented. It is quite clear that it is simply a reaction by a worried member for Bennelong trying to find a quick fix solution.

We can find proof of that by looking back at the campaign to build the third runway. I used to do a lot of flying during that time—more than I do now. I used to travel around the country quite a bit, and I do not know how many times I would have sat in aircraft or in airport lounges in Melbourne and other cities and been given messages that my plane was delayed because of congestion at Sydney airport. When I finally got on the plane, the pilot would say that we were going to sit there for another 10 to 15 minutes because of the problems at Sydney airport. We would get this PR line from pilots and everyone else that there are these problems at Sydney airport and the sooner somebody does something about fixing them—like getting a third runway—the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I used to listen to them myself.

—That's right. It was just this constant campaign. Then we used to get developers like Sid Londish who would get on the radio every morning and say, `You've got to get this third runway built because we've got to solve this problem of congestion at Sydney airport.' Alan Jones and all these other commentators were continually running this line: solve the problems of congestion—that's the immediate issue, so solve it. How do we solve it? With a quick fix solution: build a third runway. There were none more vocal in promoting that line than the Liberal Party.
—And the member for Bennelong.

—The member for Bennelong and the then Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, who fortunately lived nowhere near a flight path. He lived north of the harbour and has never been affected by aircraft noise. What concerns me is that back then the issue was congestion. As Senator Parer said in his own minority report, which I quoted yesterday, the major issue at that time was to solve the problem of congestion; to solve the problem in the shortest time span and with the least inconvenience to travellers.
—And noise.

—No, you never mentioned noise. Noise was not mentioned here. The only time noise was mentioned in your minority report was that, as a by-product of building the third runway, solving the problem of congestion and removing the inconvenience to travellers, there would also be a halving of the number of residents affected by noise. But it was not the major consideration at the time. You have now moved from that to all this concern about the residents and the noise impact. And, of course, it is a real impact. But one has to question very seriously the motivations of the opposition in all of this. Because that is now the political issue of the day. That is the concern that is being expressed to you in the community. So what is your solution? Another ad hoc, quick fix solution: reopen the east-west runway.

PARA.TAB: As the minister has said, and as all the evidence that has come before us has shown, parallel runway operations are safer. That is as logical as day follows night. Those operations are safer. As I said yesterday, you only have to look at the situation on roads. Whilst it may be safe to drive down an undivided road, there is a risk of a head-on collision. Similarly, when you drive through an intersection there is a risk of a collision. But when you drive along a divided road you remove those risks and thereby make it safer.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the ground—not in the air.

—What we are talking about here, Senator Parer, is aircraft on the ground. We are talking about the potential for on-the-ground collisions at Sydney airport through the use of intersecting runways—the very situation which was within three seconds of occurring at Sydney airport in August 1991. Three aircraft within the vicinity of that intersection—two were landing and one was parked nearby ready to taxi out—and over 600 people were three seconds away from a huge disaster. Thank God it did not occur. It did not occur because of the skill of the pilot who got that Ansett plane to abort the landing and clear the Thai aircraft that was on the ground, and the skill of the air traffic controllers.

PARA.TAB: That risk has been removed because we have removed intersecting operations. We have a situation now that is clearly safer. The false argument constantly put throughout this entire debate and the proceedings before the Senate committee by members of the opposition, particularly Senator Woods, has been, `You have said it is less safe.' As representatives of Airservices Australia and other safety organisations—and indeed government members—have said all through, we are not saying that it is unsafe to use intersecting runways. But what is clear is that it is safer—it is more safe—to use parallel runway operations instead of intersecting runway operations. The fact that intersecting runway operations may be used throughout the world at other airports, or indeed in Australia, is no reason to take a system which is safer, which is more safe today, and go backwards.

I have never heard it seriously suggested in any area when looking at safety, and if you have a system which maximises safety, that you should reduce safety. Nobody in their right mind would seriously suggest that, where we have the divided sections of the highway between Sydney and Canberra so that we avoid head-on collisions, we should fill in all that area between the two sections of the road and bring back undivided roads and bring back the risk of collisions.

That is really the parallel of your proposal. You are suggesting that, instead of having a safer system which avoids the risk of on-ground collisions at intersections and all of the attendant problems that go with it—as the minister has quite rightly pointed out, the fact that you do not have collisions does not mean that everything is hunky-dory—you have greater pressure on the air traffic controllers and you have greater risks because of the increased need for go-arounds, aborted landings and all of those other attendant problems. It is just illogical to suggest that we should reduce safety in order to supposedly spread the noise. On the key ground of safety, we have a safer system now. Why go backwards?

The second point relates to congestion. With that safer system we are now able to maintain the rate of movements and we are able to improve the rate of movements through Sydney airport and therefore reduce congestion with the new parallel runway operations and the introduction of the new radar system. We have improved the situation for the travellers by reducing congestion—and it will get better—and we have increased safety. Yet you want to go backwards. You want to go backwards because there are people affected by noise.

I would like to solve their problem today—I think we all would—but this is no way to solve their problem. As we know, you will actually make it worse. Let us look at it. You will increase substantially the number of residents that will be affected by aircraft noise. You will bring it back for all of those areas on the old east-west flight path. Whilst you may reduce the intensity of it to some extent, you will open up opportunities through some of the proposals to put more jets on the north-south runway and increase the level of noise to the north. You know, Senator Parer, and we all know, that we are endeavouring at all times to keep the airlines from increasing those movements through Sydney airport. The best way to do that at the moment is to continue with these operations we have now and not provide opportunities for greater pressure to be brought to bear to increase the number of movements and increase the noise.

Finally, I say this: this whole proposal is put up as supposedly reducing the noise for one group of residents and sharing it with the rest of Sydney. Allegations have been made about political bias. As you said yesterday, Senator Parer, it is still Labor electorates that are copping a lot of this noise—like they copped it for years and years when you were in government and did nothing to solve these problems. It is the Liberal electorates particularly to the north of Sydney that will never cop the noise no matter what proposition you implement. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bourne said that there was a requirement for an innovative solution to the competing requirements of KSA with regard to capacity, safety and noise. Whilst I do not disagree with her, I really think the compromise that is required is provided by the amendment proposed by Senator Parer.

PARA.TAB: The government, and specifically Senator Bob Collins, has never denied—and it is obviously the case—that the east-west runway has not been closed. At the moment it is used about three per cent of the time. It is used when necessary: when weather conditions require it, and when airline pilots make the decision in conjunction with air traffic controllers.

There is the view, which is taken by the government, that the continuation of the use of only the parallel runways is to meet the airport's capacity requirement of up to 80 movements per hour. This has never been achieved; presently it is about 55 movements per hour. Part of the reason for its not having been achieved is that the ground radar, which is necessary for parallel runways, is not in operation and neither is the new control tower.However, I cannot see why at the very least the east-west runway cannot be used at less busy times. Taking an extreme view, why can't it be used as if the third runway had never been built?

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that do for the noise?
—It would spread the noise.
—But when?

—Senator Forshaw made the point about the increased number of people being affected by aircraft noise in the event the east-west runway is reopened for greater usage. Yes, there have been a greater number of people affected by aircraft noise. But it is the intensity of noise, which has been made very clear to members of the committee, that makes their lives—
—Nobody worried about that before.

—That is all right. They may not have been worried about it before, but they are now. In terms of seeking a compromise and a solution which meets the expectations of a great number of people, I cannot see why you cannot use the east-west runway, in times certainly that are off-peak, as the runway of choice.
—That would have a big effect.
—Huge!
—It would, and it would be a logical way to spread the noise.
—That's not where the problem is.

—I would like to have the minister's view on that. Also while I am on my feet, I would comment on the point that the minister made yesterday: he was the minister responsible at the time, in 1989 I think, when there was the decision for the original EIS to be done. I would like to have the minister give some indication of what instructions he gave to the consultants about the closure of the east-west runway, whether it was proposed, and what the instruction process was.
—Very easily. We will readily make that available to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to put a few things on the record in response to the remarks of both Senator Forshaw and Senator Bob Collins—and I do not think we want to prolong this too much longer. Senator Forshaw talked about safety in regard to crossing on the ground. What he did not refer to, of course, was safety in regard to crossing in the air. What we have in Sydney at the moment is a lot of aeroplanes crisscrossing in the air. That concern has been expressed by regional airlines—and they have been very concerned about it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Forshaw also said that he was not aware of any situation where you would downgrade a safety system that had been maximised. I would just like to draw his attention to a number of areas where this has occurred just in the recent 12 months. One is the introduction of D class air space of regional airports, which does not provide for separation of VFR aircraft. That is simply because the capacity is not there—but there is a downgrading of safety. Another is the decision to change the downwind limitation at Sydney from five knots to 10 knots, which a lot of pilots will not support. Also, there is the decision to allow a 25-knot crosswind on runways. Then there is the minister's really crazy proposal, which was not accepted by anybody, to increase the glide path angle from 3 degrees to 6 degrees.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not a proposal.

—The pilots would not accept it. Even the Airservices people and the sycophants have been forced into it. The other thing I would like to refer to is that Senator Collins has gone down the scare campaign line yet again.
—I tell you what: if you had been sitting in the seat where I am you would be scared too.

—What on earth flying in a Beechcraft Baron, which I have done for many years in the past, has to do with Sydney airport and the opening of the east-west runway is totally and utterly beyond me. That is the sort of crazy stuff, kindergarten stuff, we are getting from a senior minister of the Crown.
—You were not listening to what I said, Senator Parer.
—Also he quotes, of course selectively, people who support his position.
—Selectively!

—Let me give you the views of those particular groups who support three runways that have been provided to the experts in the field, Airservices, so they can come up with a proper solution. The international pilots made their position very clear.
—It is a different position from the one they had three years ago.
—They are the experts. No-one listens to the pilots. They are the ones who know all about it. Dr Fred Bell, who was a government environmental consultant—
—Pilots will never admit they cannot do anything; they are like astronauts.
—That's a nice reflection on the pilots.
—It is a positive reflection on pilots.

—I have quoted the air traffic controllers. Senator Collins himself tries to duck and weave and says that things were different back in 1991. But in relation to that near crash when he was the minister you have to repeat the exact words he said. I asked this question of the Airservices people. Senator Collins would not have made this up, I am sure. He would have been advised by somebody.
—Correct.

—I asked whether you were advised and the Airservices people said, `We don't know. We were not around at the time.' They were trying to duck and weave like you wouldn't believe. In response to a question from Senator Brownhill, Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are—
he is talking about simultaneous operations—

that simultaneous operations are in operation at many, many major airports around the world. There is absolutely no reason whatever why simultaneous operations, if conducted efficiently and professionally, cannot be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no longer efficient.
—No longer efficient, says Senator Forshaw.
—But parallels are safer, Senator Parer.

—I am saying that you cannot duck and weave. We have talked about flight transportation, so I won't go into that. Bill Pollard, the CEO-designate of Airservices Australia, first cab off the rank, was phoned up by a radio station and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the world in my past experience there are many airports that have intersecting runways and they are used quite safely.

He was nobbled a few hours later and told, `You'd better change your view on this. We have a political problem in Australia.' But I like his style. At least when we get some flexibility into this game we might have some sensibility at Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: I will refer to the regional airlines later. But I want to quote Captain Westwood, a pilot. I have not had a pilot, domestically or internationally, contact me and say this whole situation at Sydney isn't crazy. They say it is crazy. We are the laughing stock of the world. Captain Westwood said in a 2BL interview:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . operationally, we use cross runways at many of our ports. A couple come to mind, or several: Christchurch, Melbourne, Perth, Adelaide, San Francisco, when we go there, Frankfurt. Plenty of airports use crossing runways. That's not to say they're the most efficient way to use two runways but when they are used they are certainly not used in a way that compromises safety.
It does not compromise safety. The Premier of New South Wales said he would prefer to see the east-west runway reopened.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, and I say this for the benefit of Senator Margetts, the situation as it now is is because of a political decision made in 1989, not because of any other reason. The people who run Sydney airport and operate traffic are precluded from using a major runway except under extreme conditions—that is, when there is a very strong wind, I think it is 30 knots or something, that blows from the west or the east.

This amendment does not say you are going to have to use the cross-runway 50 per cent, 60 per cent or 70 per cent of the time. It will give a direction to Airservices to require them to revise their noise abatement procedures for Kingsford Smith to disperse more equitably the noise generated and so on.

To his credit, Senator Forshaw raised the issue of the noise problem, which is a major problem and has been for quite some time. It is fascinating that not once did the minister refer to the noise disaster in Sydney caused by his government. The government should listen to these people. It has lost touch. This is noise pollution at its worst, brought on by a government and a minister, who did not even refer to it. The minister is running a scare campaign. When talking about capacity, he was at odds with Senator Forshaw. He said that if you go down this route you want to go you are going to reduce capacity, but Senator Forshaw said that you are going to increase capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—He did not!

—You are going to have more jets flying north, or words to that effect. I will not go into the debate on all these other issues, but I thought it was important to put on the record the point that I am making: it is not the intent of this amendment to direct them as to how to do it; it is to give them the flexibility with three active runways to come to some sensible decision based on these three competing ends—capacity, noise and safety. That is the position we take. It is the reason for the amendment.

—I started making some comments before Senator Parer's three amendments were actually moved, and I would like to conclude them now. One of the comments I also made by way of interjection was that the statement by Senator Parer that the intention of this amendment is to allow for the safest decisions, the best decisions, to be made by the operators is not actually what comes out in the wording of the amendment. It does not say `by allowing increased use if circumstances allow maximum safety', or whatever. It simply says `by increasing the use of the runway known as the east-west runway'.

PARA.TAB: In none of my statements on this matter have I not said that I understand and fully sympathise with the agonies that those people living directly under the flight paths of the Sydney airport operation have undergone. They have been misled, and that is a very important part of the anger involved. The anger, as mentioned before in this chamber, has resulted from the way they have been dealt with as a result of the impact. I am sure that if many of those people had been dealt with more fairly they would be feeling a little better about it. But they do not feel that the government has been dealing with them fairly. The safety angle obviously is important to them. But they just see their lives as intolerable.

I do not see that this amendment, which simply says `by increasing the use of the runway known as the east-west runway', is an answer which is any less political than possibly the original decision that was made. Without having had the opportunity of seeing the results of the committee deliberations, I am not in a position to make a decision on the safety or otherwise of this decision. I do not feel that by simply putting in an amendment which says `by increasing the use of the runway known as the east-west runway' we are going to get to a decision where safety is necessarily placed as the highest priority.

If that had been the intent of the amendment, I am sure it could have been written in a way that signified that intent. But it did not. Under those circumstances, in the absence of the report from the committee, which did have the opportunity to deal with all that evidence, I am unable to support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with Senator Parer that it has all been put on the table and there is no need in uselessly wasting the time of the committee in more prolonged debate, and I do not intend to do so. A number of specific questions were put to me just then, and I will answer and respond to some of the things that were said. Then I will say no more, Senator Parer; I will be brief.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the question Senator Sandy Macdonald put to me about what political instructions I gave to Kinhills in respect of the EIS, the answer is none. The only instructions at the many briefings that I gave Kinhills were to get it done on time, on budget and accurately. I can assure Senator Macdonald that in terms of me trying to second-guess one of the more competent consulting and engineering firms in Australia—I do not think Senator Parer would deny that—I certainly did not and no such instructions were given.

As the minister who simply got the job first cab off the rank of oversighting the actual EIS if the decision to go ahead with construction had been taken, there is one little matter that has not been raised in this debate so far, particularly post-Sackville, that I might just intrude. One thing I know about the EIS process is that the entire process—all $7 million of it, from memory—was predicated on a reduced use of the east-west runway at Sydney airport. The whole premise on that was that on both safety and operational grounds, parallel runways would be more effective, efficient and safer and would result in a net reduction in the number of people seriously affected by noise at Sydney airport. The entire EIS was predicated on that. It would be a moot point that if this amendment was carried, to the horror I am sure of Senator Parer, before it could even be implemented you would have to implement a new EIS.

I am not a lawyer, but I am familiar with a few forestry and mining decisions that have been taken recently. In fact, I have been the designator of a number of those post-Sackville. The basis of the Sackville decision was that if things had materially changed since there had been an EIS, even in the forestry area with such things as new technology or new proposals that indicated that the original environmental impact statement had not properly addressed those changes, it would not be sufficient to say that that environmental examination of the issue would suffice.

Again, it is pure speculation on my part but I simply see the elements here very clearly on a number of the matters that have been raised recently with regard to mining and forestry operations that I am familiar with. I do know intimately that the entire EIS process was done on the basis that there would be a reduced use of the east-west runway and use of parallel runway operations. So it could well be that any such proposal would have to be designated and that it may well be that the environmental authorities, who would have the final decision, may well take the decision that a new EIS would have to be done before such a thing could be implemented. I had not heard it canvassed in debate and I thought I might, for the completeness of this debate, make that point. That is those two issues covered.
In respect of Senator Parer's—I am not quite sure why he even did it—allusion to the story I told about the Beechcraft Baron—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't know why you raised it.

—I guess it was because I was minister. You have not been and you may well be and you might reflect on it. As minister I have to routinely be involved in the examination and dissection of accidents. That is why I have such a high regard for the professionalism of people involved. I worked with them for three years and I have great regard for not only their skill but also their application and dedication to the job. They take themselves very seriously, as you know.

PARA.TAB: The common thread through most of the serious accidents, as again you know, Senator Parer, is that when major accidents do occur in what is a very safe industry, it is rarely because one or two things go wrong and it is very rarely these days because of any mechanical or technical failure of the aircraft or equipment involved. It is usually because a whole series of things go wrong that normally would not and the combination of all of those events culminates in an accident. That is a common thread that runs through all major accidents around the world.

The reason I reflected on the Baron incident is very simple. I have seen references in accident reports to what precedes an accident. You try to get it out of your head, but you cannot when you are flying at night in a little aircraft. There is nothing wrong with Barons. I was getting to a situation where you are supposed to have left at three in the afternoon, flying in daylight hours, but, because cabinet was delayed, you did not. You thought that day you were going to be travelling in a 12-seater twin turboprop, but, because you did not leave at 3 o'clock, that had to be diverted to another job. When you got there you found that not only were you flying at night but you were flying in a Baron instead of a 12-seater. You sit there composing the accident report and saying, `What happened on this day was . . . ' You know that that was what I was referring to. There were three other individuals there too. I am sure we were perfectly safe, but, particularly coming from the Northern Territory, it was an interesting experience for me—because it was winter time—to look out of the window of a tiny little aircraft and see, only 200 feet below the aircraft, it seemed to me, mountain peaks covered in snow. In a lot of the Northern Territory, you have the advantage of being able to find a flat spot if you do need to put down.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the no runway option.

—Correct, that is the no runway option. That is the reason I referred to it, Senator Parer. I was not joking, and Senator Parer knows it, when I looked at this amendment and thought about what the royal commission would say about it afterwards. I watched with great interest the royal commission that was held into the Mount Erebus disaster. Senator Macdonald, if you have not seen it, I commend to you the television special that was done on the royal commission. It was a very accurate portrayal.

PARA.TAB: One big thing about royal commissions is that, no matter what they are investigating, they have the wonderful advantage, with hindsight, of 20-20 vision. Everything after the event looks as though it should have been done another way, and things that were absolutely commonplace at the time they were done can be made to look very sinister afterwards. That is why I say—and I say it again—that this is a very brave amendment when the head of BASI is saying, as the chief investigator of air traffic accidents in Australia, that it is better to operate parallel runways. Yes, of course you can operate intersecting runways.

I was not criticising the pilots; I was in fact doing the reverse. Both pilots and air traffic controllers are consummate professionals and they do not like to admit—and I know this—that they cannot do something. If you put to them a theoretical operation, they will say to you, `Yes, we can do that.' It is a `can do' type of profession, I am pleased to say. They have a predisposition to being able to say, `Yes, we are capable of solving just about any theoretical problem you want to put to us. We can handle it. We can make our own separations and we can do this and we can do something else.' But the bottom line still is that the consistent advice I have had, over five or six years now, from everybody connected with the operation of Sydney airport is that it is better to operate a parallel runway system, which provides fewer conflict points on both the ground and in the air, than a system of intersecting runways, even though that system can be operated safely.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
