As I said before, I am not moving the second part of my amendments because I believe they relate to what ought to be part of a holistic operational approach. I will look at them in my response and, I hope, in the committee's response to the airport noise committee.

PARA.TAB: The first part of my amendments—Nos 1 to 12—relates to this bill and to the curfew. The object of these amendments is to increase the time of the curfew by an hour. At the moment, the curfew period exists between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. My amendments would extend that curfew by an hour so that it would exist between 10.30 at night and 6.30 in the morning. The reason for this is that we believe the seven-hour curfew is particularly inadequate to meet the sleeping patterns of children, of the sick, of the elderly and of shift workers. An extended curfew is something that would be very useful. One of the things that has come out of the airport noise committee is that probably the two most obvious ways people believe that their lives could be improved would be with more sleeping time—sleep is so important to us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean you are going to abolish Senate estimates?

—I acknowledge that quite delightful interjection from the minister. Having been present at the hearings on Monday night, I would quite like to. However, sleep is still important to us and, even though we have not caught up, we should allow people living under the flight path to do so. So I would like to extend the curfew in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that has been found to be very important is frequency. The two things that people find most annoying are the frequency of flights over them and the lack of sleep. While there are a lot of ways that those issues can be dealt with, most of them are operational. This one just deals with the curfew.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing these amendments. I am grateful to Senator Bourne for moving them together. I will reply to them together so that we do not delay the debate unnecessarily. It is true that the night-time hours are the really important ones. That is why I pointed out by way of interjection a few moments ago that the proposition that you can somehow operate the east-west runway during the day when the traffic does ease off and that that would have some dramatic effect on noise is a fallacy. It is true that the curfew tolls the knell of parting day. It is those night-time hours that are the crucial ones.

PARA.TAB: I want to take this opportunity to point out what everybody knows: a great many of us want to use airports and fly. As I said before, Australia has got a small population and is highly urbanised in cities that are separated by enormous distances. Due to the technology available in Europe, Japan and other more highly populated centres, they have very high speed trains. The traffic and the relatively short distances can make such a service pay, or not lose very much. I regret to say—because I would be a regular user of them—that such services are not available as easily in Australia.

I look forward to seeing the day when there is such a service between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne, which is what the proposition is. It is not the buses that that affects, because of the cost of the tickets. The competition for such a service is flying. It is the airways that would, in that sense, be the losers once such a service is established. But those options are not readily available yet in Australia.

The point I am making is that everybody wants the convenience, speed and safety of air travel but nobody wants the airport in their backyard. One of the things that have irritated me about this debate in terms of the backflips that have been done on it—I am not directing this at the opposition; I am talking about all the groups that are protesting, understandably, about the third runway—is that the public debate has gone a long way beyond the third runway at Sydney airport. It seems to me to be polarised very strongly in no airport at all. People are protesting strongly, and they are entitled to do so from their perspective. The foundation on which this debate is now based is that people want to see Sydney airport closed down completely and moved out to Badgerys Creek where it will operate for 24 hours a day.

I will not go on any further about this, but I want it to be noted that the inevitable has already happened; that is, that very active movement has begun—it started some time ago—of the residents of Badgerys Creek protesting about the noise at Badgerys Creek. I am sure Senator Bourne is well aware of that. As someone who is interested in these major public policy debates, I have noted that meetings are being held regularly in the Badgerys Creek area and are routinely attracting hundreds of people in Badgerys Creek who do not want the aircraft at Badgerys Creek.

At the time everyone thought it would be terrific to have an airport out there as it would bring industry to the area. No doubt there will still be a strong debate. All this does is indicate just how typical this debate is around the world. People are starting to think that somehow this is unique to Australia, that somehow these problems at Sydney airport are unique to Sydney airport. As everybody knows, they are not. This is a major debate around the world, particularly with major international airports in capital cities. You have only to go to Japan to see how intense the debate can become. People have actually lost their lives over it.

There is a problem with those competing uses, as Senator Parer correctly pointed out, that constantly have to be faced of noise, capacity, safety and, of course, the commercial advantages that operations such as this bring to a community. I am advised that the last meeting that was held at Badgerys Creek by residents to protest at any aircraft going into Badgerys Creek was held only last week and attracted an audience of close to 500 people. I simply wanted that to be noted.

I will address all the objections to these amendments. The reason we are opposing the amendments is that all operations that are currently planned between 2200 and 2235 would have to be moved to prior to 2200 to ensure arrival or departure by 2230. This would impact seriously on the freight industry—that is, those freight aircraft that operate late in the evening but include curfew hours. It would also exacerbate problems of moving current international flights back from the 2300 to 2400 shoulder. As far as the 0630 start of the curfew is concerned, this would have a major impact on international flights to Australia during the northern summer season which runs from March to October.

The government's objective is to progressively reduce the number of flights arriving in the 0500 to 0600 shoulder period. The effect is that often the existing gate and terminal capacity at Sydney airport becomes fully utilised for about three hours. Extending the curfew to 0630 would exacerbate the situation. Flights may transfer to other Australian airports, but it is more likely that they will be cancelled as Sydney is the preferred destination for many tourists.

I suppose the one option that is available is that, if people do not want the airport at Sydney and if people now do not want the airport at Badgerys Creek, you could possibly move the entire operation to Melbourne and then have people travel by train from Melbourne to Sydney if they want to visit Sydney. As someone suggested, the international airport could be moved to Canberra and we could have people moving from Canberra. All of these things are being proposed. I do not think they are achievable solutions.

I am concerned about the possibility that one reaction to this change in curfew hours would mean the cancellation of flights rather than having them diverted. It is also the government's wish to phase out the curfew shoulder periods. But the government would prefer to do so as additional gate and terminal capacity becomes available, either at Sydney or with the completion of Sydney West at Badgerys Creek, so as to minimise all of the impacts that I have mentioned above on both freight services, which this proposal would impact on quite seriously, and international travel to and from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not support these amendments. Basically the reason we will not is that all this was canvassed by the Morris committee when the original bill went off to it. To a large degree, Senator Collins has reflected the views expressed in the position taken when there were changes to the original John Howard bill, which we support. Those changes were reflected in the bill itself.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Bourne made the remark that there were two aspects to the noise problem. One was night time, when noise is exacerbated—we all know that—and there is not the background noise that dulls the noise of aircraft. The other one is frequency. From the evidence we certainly received, I think frequency is the one that has caused major problems. This would not affect frequency, depending on the time of the day, but the peak periods could be stretched out, depending on when international flights and so on came in. But I am not sure it would do anything.

The other problem is the one that Senator Collins referred to. Certainly a vast number of people genuinely believe that they were deceived over the whole Sydney airport thing, but this has now flown on to Badgerys Creek. Senator Collins is quite right. People are concerned that what happened at Sydney airport will happen to them.

He also mentioned quite correctly that to some degree it is not just an Australian problem, it is a worldwide problem. Even though I am going down the Senator Collins path, I am not going to talk about Barons. I noted with interest the other day that the second runway at Narita airport in Japan is now being built after 20 years of dispute. But it is real and the concerns of those people must be taken on board.

I am not sure that these amendments proposed would achieve anything, from the point of view of the people who are affected. I am not even sure whether it would politically, from Senator Bourne's point of view, because if you go there then maybe it is not enough—maybe it should be two hours or three hours and so on. Reflecting on what Senator Bourne said earlier, I think a total approach is something that should be looked at. It is something that I think we will look at in the coming couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some of the comments made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), especially in relation to a possible alternative to noise which might occur as a result of Badgerys Creek. It will be very important for the government—whichever government is involved with Badgerys Creek—to make very clear to the people of Badgerys Creek exactly what kind of aircraft will be used in that location, what kinds of flights there will be and, if there is to be a major airport at Badgerys Creek, to clarify what kinds of development issues might arise if there are in fact conflicts of interest in some sort of land use that the government is involved with in that area in relation to the development of an airport.

PARA.TAB: One that springs to mind is the development of the St Marys site. Australian Defence Industries are wishing to sell that to a very large number of people as a housing development—for very considerable prices, I imagine, in order to develop it as a desirable suburb. If the government is, on the one hand, wishing to make money from an ex-military site by creating a very extensive and perhaps somewhat exclusive housing suburb—which is going to be right under the flight path of what may well be, from what we hear from the minister, the major Sydney airport—then people would be entitled to know whether there might not be a conflict of interest in what the government is doing. So, with the credibility gap that has arisen as a result of what has happened at Sydney airport, the people at Badgerys Creek may well be wondering whether or not these positions have been clarified.

The possible outcome of these amendments might signal to the airlines that there might need to be some rationalisation of services, which might mean some air travellers will have to put up with fewer services but which are rationalised through Sydney airport. If that is a signal to airlines that they could be part of the solution, then I am inclined to support the amendment. I am aware of the numbers, but I think it is a good signal that we must all be part of the solution. I hope that that will give some incentive for everybody to work together to solve the immediate problems that arise at Sydney airport.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Childs)—The question is that the amendments moved by Senator Bourne be agreed to.

However, I see that it is after 12 o'clock and I, like my colleagues here, probably ought to be in the Great Hall at the state luncheon for the Prime Minister of Canada. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sale of the ANL has been a tortuous process for this government. It has highlighted once again the ineptitude of a government in dealing with any matters of a serious financial consequence. It has also highlighted once again the obvious fact that this government is now more than ever quite willing to adopt the policies and the programs which have been advocated by the coalition for many years. This is a catch-up government—a government which is trying to catch up on the ideas and philosophies of the coalition.

PARA.TAB: The sale of ANL was first announced in the 1991 budget following a study by Price Waterhouse-Potter Warburg to investigate the disposal of 49 per cent of ANL. Not surprisingly, their report concluded that a 49 per cent share in ANL would be unattractive to buyers and, accordingly, they recommended a complete divestiture of the Commonwealth's holdings in ANL.

Senators would be aware that ANL has reappeared in every Labor budget since that announcement yet, as we all know, it still remains unsold. One of my colleagues in the other place, Mrs Bishop, the shadow minister for privatisation and Commonwealth-state relations, described the ANL Sale Bill 1995 as the `ANL liquidation bill' and, in that regard, Mrs Bishop is certainly correct.

The bill contains provisions relating to the transition and saving arrangements for employee entitlements prior to the sale. It also includes provisions relating to the transfer of ANL assets, liabilities and the rights of the Commonwealth. It attempts to cover the possibility of performance results worse than forecast and expenses incurred transferring items out of ANL. Under the bill, no levy will be imposed on ANL's borrowings after the sale day and further capital injections from the Commonwealth to ANL will stop.

This bill was referred to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee—of which my colleague Senator Gibson played a very significant role—for examination. Although at the end of the day the coalition is prepared to support the passage of the bill, it nevertheless should be noted that there are a number of concerns which we feel have not been adequately addressed. In particular, I refer to clause 67 of the ANL Sale Bill 1995, which appears to provide the Minister for Finance with a very wide discretion in relation to the payment of up to $15 million for costs associated with the sale of the Australian National Line. The matter is further complicated by the absence of any specific guidelines in the bill to govern such payments.

At the committee hearings, the departmental officers were unable to allay any concerns and instead referred my colleagues to a letter which was provided to Mrs Bishop on a commercial-in-confidence basis. It is on that basis that we in the coalition will be supporting the bill today.

As I said initially, one of the key failings to emerge in the government's handling of the sale of the ANL was the performance of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who must surely be, like Carmen Lawrence, a millstone around the neck of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as he heads to the next election. These matters have also drawn the attention of the Auditor-General. The performance audit of the Australian National Audit Office entitled Matters relating to the proposed sale of ANL Ltd was presented to the parliament on 22 August 1995. That report was extremely critical of the high level of attrition that existed between the various parties involved in the sale. It noted:

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore difficult not to conclude that there would have been a better chance of achieving the Government's objectives if there had been a better meeting of minds to overcome any identified obstacles or difficulties.
It further noted:
A degree of uncertainty surrounding the objectives of the sale and the means of achieving these objectives would have aggravated any sale process.

So we see that the concerns regarding the government's handling of this matter are concerns not only of the coalition but also of the Auditor-General, as they are plainly reflected in the Auditor-General's conclusions.

PARA.TAB: The same report also raises some additional concerns, including the fact that the losses of ANL from 1991 to June 1994 were $53.7 million. This loss does not include a provision of $78.87 million for restructuring in the accounts to 30 June 1994. These figures should leave no-one in doubt that the financial position of ANL has had the potential to be a considerable financial burden upon the Australian taxpayer. We all remember the statement by Minister Brereton on 22 August 1994 that `you couldn't give ANL away'. This was a most peculiar statement from a minister responsible for devolving an asset on behalf of the Australian taxpayer.

We need to go back to 1 March 1994 to further examine the efforts of Minister Brereton in undermining the whole process of privatisation. On that day, Minister Brereton put the interests of his union and Labor mates ahead of the interests of both the Australian National Line and the country by sacking the entire nine-member ANL board. This was a lawfully constituted board and Minister Brereton deprived it of funds for carrying out its commercial operations without his approval.

Minister Brereton took control of the Australian National Line by stacking the ANL board with some of his old mates. I am sure the names Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull are familiar to all of us in this chamber. They, along with another director, were appointed by Minister Brereton to do the jobs that the previous board refused to do. The previous board wished to undertake a detailed study before signing off on their obligations under the Corporations Law. This new threesome were obviously much more inclined to go along with the whims of Minister Brereton, and the Australian taxpayers paid them in excess of $816,000 for their services. Not only was this a disgraceful rorting of due process; it has also proved to be a disgraceful rorting of taxpayers' funds to assist old Labor mates.

The date of 1 March was also when Minister Brereton ensured that the Task Force on Asset Sales operating through the Minister for Finance was to be the first point of reference for all inquiries relating to the sale. The minister changed the articles of association of ANL Ltd to make sure that the directors could not take any action or enter into any transaction that could be perceived as prejudicing the Commonwealth sale options. In doing this, Minister Brereton effectively squeezed the old board out of the process because they would not play ball, but the reality is that neither ANL management nor ANL workers have ever been given a fair go by Minister Brereton. They have never been given a fair go because they did not fit in with the minister's agenda.

It is a disgrace that the ANL board had to find out about the future through the newspapers. The evidence given to the committee by the former chairman of ANL, Mr Bill Bolitho, a man well respected in maritime circles, is evidence enough that the ministers and his predecessors have simply been fooling around with ANL. Since Mr Bolitho and the former head of the Seamen's Union, Pat Geraghty, were sacked by Minister Brereton, the Australian taxpayers have paid a high price. In fact, taxpayers have lost $146 million as a direct result of Minister Brereton's meddling.

On top of that $146 million, the minister has also sought to placate the maritime unions with a $20 million handout to shipowners. This has been a very expensive blunder on behalf of the government. I wonder, as I am sure many around here wonder, what special skills Mr Wran, Mr Turnbull and their fellow board member have in the shipping industry. Senators would probably be very interested to know that Mr Neville Wran, the old mate, collected $301,000 for a mere two days work a week over a period of 12 months.

In providing evidence to the Senate inquiry, Mr Bolitho indicated that the minister informed the Maritime Union of Australia that he was out to get the board of ANL. I am sure my colleague Senator Gibson will illuminate on this particular part of the minister's action.

Those ill-judged comments by the minister were based on a valuation of ANL carried out by Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers. The minister would not discuss this valuation with the board, nor would he discuss it with anyone else. He simply acted on his own judgment, which has since been proved, like a lot of other things he has done, to be deplorable.

If this minister was really serious about the future of ANL, why did he sack the board and why did he replace it with part-time directors whose background demonstrated Labor Party affiliations but no experience whatsoever in operating a shipping company? Further, what value have the taxpayers got from the $816,000 they have paid to Neville Wran, Malcolm Turnbull and one other gentleman to resolve the problem? It is now over 12 months since we were told that Mr Wran and his cohorts would fix the problem. The only evidence we have seen of their efforts to date is that they have accumulated an additional $24 million worth of operating losses for ANL and it succeeded in deteriorating its value substantially.

Whilst the minister has been trying to save his face within the Labor Party, the sorry saga of his handling of ANL and its sale will haunt the government right up to the next election. The former chairman of ANL, when providing evidence before the Senate inquiry, indicated that one of the major assets of ANL, Australian Stevedores, was sold to Jamieson Equities for $10 million—and that is $11 million less than its true value. How could a minister let these sorts of things happen?

Minister Brereton has proven that he is totally unable to handle this type of asset sale. He has concentrated solely on keeping his union mates happy and in a job and on passing over taxpayers' money to his union mates. As a result, all that Australian taxpayers have inherited is a lemon.

Of course, this is not the only failure we have seen from Minister Brereton. We have just completed here, this morning, the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill. We all know of the mess he has made of the Sydney airport. That is just another one of his abject failures. His industrial relations record is another absolute mess. We are seeing evidence of that in Queensland. We have a national strike coming up about which he has been critical. I notice that he has come out of the woodwork and had a few words to say today about the Comalco effort and the national strike. But, really and truly, he sat back and let all this happen—without any intervention, without trying to fix it in any way.

As I have said, Minister Brereton must be at least at the top of the hit list to be sacked. If he is not, then I do not know who it would be—perhaps Carmen Lawrence, or someone else. Mr Brereton must be sacked from his present ministerial position if the government is to retain any credibility at all. For the government to do anything else but sack him after his inept handling of this particular sale would be further evidence of its inability to soundly manage this country's finances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Calvert on the ANL Sale Bill 1995. There is a saying: the fool does think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool. If this government honestly believed that it was wise to sell the Australian national shipping line in the manner in which it has, then we are left to conclude that this government is truly foolish.

PARA.TAB: There are many nautical analogies which one could make in respect of the ANL Sale Bill 1995. However, I believe that it is most appropriate to commence by stating what many would consider to be the obvious. Without any hesitation or doubt, this bill marks most definitively the high-water mark of public administration incompetence by the Keating Labor government. How else can you characterise the sale of a public asset in which it is more likely than not that, at the end of the process, at the end of four years, at the end of an acrimonious and tortured demonstration of bureaucratic stumbling and ineptitude, the seller may well be forced to pay the buyer to take the asset away.

How the true believers must be turning in their graves this day, knowing that a Labor government would actually pay the private sector to take away Australia's national shipping line. It would have been high treason in the Labor Party to have even proposed this sale just 10 years ago. But then Paul Keating was not Prime Minister 10 years ago.

It is uncontestable that the ANL has not been in a strong financial position for very many years. Indeed, for the entire life of the governments of Labor Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating, ANL has been hung out to dry in any true commercial sense, starved of the one element that could have kept the line afloat—capital. For most of the last 15 years, the ANL ships have been inefficient, outdated and inappropriate. Such facts, however, have not recently come to light; they were well known more than 10 years ago.

Why then would a Labor government not find it within its heart and soul to provide the capital that was needed—not last year, not three years ago, but at least 10 years prior to now. The answer is a sad reflection on this government and its capacity to either manage the economy or to be honest with the citizens of our nation.

ANL never received the funds it was seeking because of the mess Labor made of successive federal budgets. Because promises had been made to interest groups to keep Labor in power, there was no money available to pay for the vital capital requirements of the shipping line. Should this be a surprise to anyone? Not at all.

I can imagine former Senator Graham Richardson, as the face of the ALP, rationalising this seeming incongruity with bland indignity. ANL, and in particular the workers of ANL, would be considered hard core Labor supporters. They would never vote for the coalition, so why bother providing their company with funds to keep it afloat and in government hands?

Besides, if the ANL collapsed, the MUA and its members would be the only ones to really suffer and they were hardly the government's favourite trade union. So, as neither the Hawke nor Keating governments were in a position to give ANL its lifeline, the government simply decided, probably as long ago as 1989 or 1990, to abandon the ANL, its employees, its heritage and its symbolism for Australia.

Instead, the Hawke government first and, for the past four years, the Keating government have tried to hide the shame of ANL. I say `shame' advisedly because without doubt the government should be ashamed of how it has handled this sale. Most particularly, it should be ashamed that it was never prepared to tell the Australian people the truth about ANL. It should be ashamed that it was prepared to allow the sale process to be ill-conceived, undefined, badly managed and ultimately to have degenerated into farce.

It should be ashamed that it was prepared to sacrifice the commercial reputations of the distinguished and committed Australians on the former board of ANL under the stewardship of Mr Bill Bolitho. It should be ashamed that it was prepared to play internecine factional politics within the ALP at the expense of taxpayers' money. There is much for the government to be ashamed about in the sale of ANL, but I doubt we will hear any remorse from those on the government benches.

Just so those opposite do not seek to brand me a hypocrite, let me be quite clear—the opposition has long believed that ANL should not have been in government hands. The opposition believes that there has not been for some time now a reason, a justification, for the government running a shipping line. Even given the arguments about the Australian island nation and national pride, the government of Australia has no place operating a commercial shipping venture. The coalition has consistently argued that ANL was a government business that Australia could not afford. The coalition has been consistent on this issue and even now believes that the line should be sold.

How then does our position differ from that of the government? It is clear now that the government always intended to rid itself of ANL. Nevertheless, it could not bring itself to tell the Australian people the truth. It could not bring itself to level with the Australian taxpayer. Instead it hid its true intentions even from the board of the company until it was too late for any possible outcome other than the one we are now witnessing.

While the coalition agrees that ANL should be sold, it does not accept that the process that the Labor government has undertaken to sell the company reflects well upon Australia. The coalition does not believe that this particular sale has been well managed or executed. Even now we must rely on commitments given privately to our shadow minister by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) as to the manner in which the $15 million allocated in this bill will be spent.

We cannot tell the Australian people what those commitments are or what they mean as the government has refused to tell a parliamentary committee how it intends to spend the money. The Australian people will just have to rely on the word of a Western Australian Labor politician that everything is going to be okay with their money. They must accept what the minister believes to be necessary and desirable for spending $15 million and that it will be in their interests. Some less charitable than I may say they have heard such promises before.

Regardless of these concerns, the coalition does not believe it has any option but to allow this bill to pass. It is now a necessary element of the sale process established by this government and, regardless of its theoretical unsoundness, the coalition accepts that the end in this instance may justify the means.

Given that the coalition will not oppose the bill, what, you may ask, is the difference between the coalition's position on the ANL sale and that of the government? The difference is clear. The coalition would never have allowed the ANL sale process to have become such a farce. The coalition would not have sought to deceive the ANL's directors, its management and the Australian people about its intentions. The coalition would have listened to the advice of the ANL board and would have facilitated the sale of ANL when there was a real chance for a positive and productive sale in November 1992. I repeat: that was back in November of 1992.

It is clear that the ANL was always a bit player in the world maritime industry. It was competing as a small, respected player in a fiercely competitive and distorted market without the equipment and resources to achieve a proper return on invested funds. It is equally clear that the Keating Labor government, which was intent on buying electoral favours and feathering the nest of its allies and supporters, was never going to provide the ANL with the assistance it desperately needed.

Regardless of these obvious facts, there are many questions as yet unanswered. Why did the Keating government allow the failed sale process to drag on for more than four years? Why did it waste over $110 million—costs of consultants, delays in the process and losses by the company over that period of time—when there was a real prospect of selling the company four years ago? Why did it devastate the morale of the staff—of all employees—of ANL?

Why did it sack the hamstrung former board of ANL and then let the new board take full control of the sale process without the interference of bureaucrats? Why did it immediately grant to the new board a financial guarantee that the previous board had sought for the previous three years? Why, after four long years, did it eventually leave the fate of the whole sale process in the hands of the militant Maritime Union of Australia, which had long ago proclaimed its conviction that the ANL would never be sold to the only bidder, the P&O group? Moreover, why was the sale process placed in the hands of well-meaning but uninformed officers of the Department of Finance with little or no experience in the maritime industry, its complications, priorities and intricacies?

Why was it necessary to spend thousands of dollars purchasing professional advice from external consultants when that advice existed already within the board and management of ANL? Why was the task force on asset sales, belonging to the Department of Finance, ultimately removed from the sale process? Finally, why did the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) act so quickly to remove the former ANL board when a preliminary report, which was not a full due diligence report on the company, had recommended that further work was needed before any action could be taken on the sale? These are questions that only the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his closest ministerial advisers can answer.

The Senate, through its Finance and Public Administration Committee, has conducted an inquiry into this matter, and its conclusions should make for interesting analysis. In the meantime, should we see a conspiracy in all this? Should we see a cunning and devious scheme by the ALP Right to destroy the left-wing MUA, its leaders and members? Perhaps, with just a touch of the cynic, we could paint such a canvas.

I prefer to think that this government is not that clever, even by half. Instead, I see in this unfortunate mess the clammy hands of incompetence and indifference. I believe that many will be seen to have lost something as a result of this failed and ignominious saga. ANL employees will ultimately, no doubt, lose their jobs, their incomes and their dignity. The former board members of ANL have already lost the gleam of their hard-earned reputations. Taxpayers have lost, and will most probably continue to lose, their money. The Department of Finance and the Department of Transport will lose much credibility and integrity in the eyes of many who have, and will in the future, study this sale.

Perhaps, however, the saddest loss of all from the sale of ANL will be the loss of faith in government and its processes. That faith, which has already been so cruelly distorted by the Labor government, is at the very core of our democracy. As other nations have found to their horror, once that faith has gone the democratic foundation of our government can never be the same.

If it is one day shown that the ANL sale really was more than an exercise in dreadful incompetence and was, in fact, a sham, a fraud or a case study in the ruthless pursuit of political expediency, our democracy will be the loser. I do not seek this day to ascribe blame to particular groups or individuals. I believe that there will be much acrimony before this epic sale is finalised.

Perhaps it is unfair to isolate the sale process of ANL from its entire history. Perhaps we should reflect upon how political and economic power have always been closely intertwined with the ANL, the waterfront and the maritime industry. Nevertheless, I do sincerely believe that the sale process of ANL has been more than just difficult. It has been more than just different. It has been, if I may paraphrase Shakespeare, a story about which there has never been more woe. This bill facilitates the sale of ANL to P&O. I hope that as politicians, as holders of the peoples' trust and mandate and, indeed, as all Australians, we will never again see a sale process like that of the ANL.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been reminded that the ANL Sale Bill 1995 will eventually end up as an act of parliament to facilitate the sale of the Australian National Line to a private company. We are discussing whether such a bill should pass this parliament. It is a sad day that we see yet another of the jewels in the crown—another one of the assets of Australia—being sold. In this case there is a great deal of debate about whether cash money will actually find its way to the government or whether it will simply be a removal of obligations and a removal of debt which will no longer accrue. There have been various estimates as to how much money it costs the government each month to continue to operate this particular enterprise.

PARA.TAB: We have heard from the coalition, who spent some considerable time illustrating the problems with the process of the sale. We have had some discussion about the need for the sale. What has fascinated those who have commented on this particular saga has been the process. In fact, I chaired the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee which has inquired into the process and is about to present a report on that investigation. The Senate has also been presented with a report from the Australian National Audit Office on matters related to the proposed sale of the Australian National Line Ltd.

As Senator Calvert pointed out in his contribution, we have also seen a new board appointed by the government which was paid a considerable amount of money—I will not go into that—to facilitate the sale process, a process which the previous board did not endorse. That is not surprising because that previous board had been the operating board—the body charged with the responsibility of operating the enterprise and conducting the business of a shipping line. That is what they have done. We should not be surprised that that operating board was not keen to progress the sale. The new board was appointed to facilitate the sale.

Rather than make comments about the efficacy of that or enter into the discussion about that particular process, I would like to observe that the irony of this debate so far is to hear the coalition reminding the true believers that this ALP government is prepared to pay private enterprise to take over the Australian National Line. The irony continued while Senator Gibson reminded us that the Australian National Line has been denied sufficient capital to maintain a viable business.

Here we have a government which has been trying to copy the market-driven, profit-seeking, money-chasing philosophy of the economic rationalists, a government eager to play the game of big business, trying to out-commercialise, out-corporatise and out-privatise the private sector. We have in this place a fairly good illustration of that same group falling flat on their face while trying to do it.

That is what happens so often in the private sector. I do not want to catalogue the failures of entrepreneurs. I merely have to mention that entrepreneurs fail to remind people of that catalogue. There is nothing to be gained by listing the corporate failures in Australia's history, but this is what happens: when you try to play the big game, collapses occur and situations are reached where enterprises no longer continue.

However, we are talking about a government undertaking in relation to the national line of this island continent, the national shipping line. We are told that the reasons for the sale include that it was not the government's business to conduct such a shipping line, that the ANL was only a bit player on the international scene and that the ANL was not operating well as a commercial enterprise.

We believe that it is the government's business, on this island continent, to ensure that there is an alternative to being held to ransom in a strategic sense by other enterprises and overseas interests. It is in Australia's interests and the government's interests to ensure that we are not wholly committed to those who have their interests elsewhere. As an island continent, it is of strategic benefit to ensure that we have some maritime capacity. To criticise ANL for being only a bit player has nothing to do with the reasons why we may or may not have a shipping line. After all, small, active, well managed enterprises are always capable of providing something which large and clumsier organisations are not able to do.

The fact that the ANL was not operating well is not contested, but the question of whose fault it is is a matter of discussion. We were reminded by Senator Gibson of the constraints of capital that were placed upon the operation of this organisation. The enterprise itself may well have been sound; it is the way it was asked to conduct itself which was not sound. They were the criticisms that were offered as being a reason for needing to sell this government undertaking.

Then we have the question of what it is that is being sold. Essentially, we could look at ANL as consisting of ocean-going vessels, the company infrastructure, onshore facilities, staff, obligations, and other advantages that may have accrued to the name. The question of whether the corporate infrastructure had a value or an economic disadvantage is a question which has never really been answered, because it has been very hard to determine exactly what it is. The ships undoubtedly have some sort of value, but it is hard to determine whether the state of repair, the suitability or the design of the ships is an advantage or a disadvantage economically. Some of the onshore facilities, as has been mentioned, have been sold off, and some of the staff have gone. That changes the nature of what is finally being offered for sale.

The point I would like to make is that, while the Finance and Public Administration Committee was conducting its inquiry, Mr Neville Wran, in public evidence, offered us a truism: anything is worth only what the market will pay for it; that will be determined by the market, and that is its value. However, it is very important to consider that, if we take anything which is offered in the commercial market, how it is offered is almost as important as what it is.

We have struggled to find out what it is that is being offered for sale. The `how' has been very hard to chase. The factors of whether it is offered over a period of time, whether it is offered as a result of what is euphemistically described as a fire sale, whether it is offered as a going concern with some support, whether it is offered encumbered with debt or whether it is offered in a short period of time or a long period of time greatly influence the price that is eventually obtained, as any house seller would be aware.

When looking at this particular bill, which is needed to facilitate the proposed sale, it is very important that we do not bring to this debate a superficial understanding of what it is that is being sold. Nor should we allow ourselves to be seduced by any superficial description of what it is that is being sold—superficial descriptions as we have already had from the minister responsible, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). I do not think anybody could justify his comment about what is being sold as being a responsible and helpful one.

With those differences in mind, I remind the Senate that we are talking here about the actual sale rather than the process. I will excuse myself and add to the discussion of the process because the process has in some ways influenced the argument about whether it is worth selling or retaining it. Page 18 of Audit Report No. 2 of 1995-96 by the Australian National Audit Office, entitled Matters relating to the proposed sale of ANL Ltd, states that there are a number of factors that have impacted on proposals for the sale of ANL. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: .TFAS documents refer to the lack of cooperation from the previous ANL Board and on some occasions from ANL management;
.the delays in ANL's providing its business plan to the consultants undertaking in the 1992 scoping study;
.ANL stated that it wanted the sale to be deferred for a number of years to allow a return to profitability;
.the delay in changing ANL's Articles of Association earlier to ensure cooperation in the sale process;
.the need to resolve maritime policy issues, including consultations with the unions regarding the sale;
.the uncertainty of a sale outcome as reflected by the wide variation in values attributed to ANL by Price Waterhouse Potter Warburg in the first scoping study;
.the need to complete a review of Part X of the Trade Practices Act which would determine the future regulatory environment for ANL;
.the need to amend the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Platform to allow a sale beyond 49%; and
.the 1993 Election and a number of Ministerial changes, particularly the Transport Portfolio.

I think that list illustrates that when we are contemplating the sale of a government business enterprise, there is more to it than just hanging out the `for sale' shingle and sitting back, waiting to see what happens. That is the implication given in public evidence by Mr Neville Wran that the market would determine the price. These other factors come into it. These other factors which encumber a government business enterprise come into the price somebody is prepared to pay for that, and the other processes that need to be gone through.

PARA.TAB: It is not a simple matter and it is not a matter which should be treated in a simplistic way. It concerns me greatly that we have these truisms brought to the argument. They sound plausible in other commercial senses, but we have to come back to the question of what it is that is being sold, and the question of how to sell that is determined by what is being sold.

We have to recognise that this is an enterprise which has been built up over the years—paid for by taxpayers and supported by taxpayers, for taxpayers' benefit. In some instances, there is a valid criticism of some of the things ANL was asked to do: to support unprofitable shipping routes and to actually purchase ships which had been built in Australia for strategic reasons. By the way, I support that but it did nothing to improve the commercial returns of the shipping line. It provided other returns to the nation.
Debate interrupted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Western Australian royal commission has found that Carmen Lawrence lied to the Australian people and, further, that she acted improperly, first, in supporting the use of a petition in a private matrimonial matter for her own political purposes at the expense of the interests of the family; secondly, in falsely denying her knowledge of and participation in the events preceding the presentation of the petition; and, thirdly, in denying the public its right to judge her actions by untruthfully denying that participation. Under such circumstances, why won't Mr Keating show some national leadership and dismiss her as not a fit and proper person to hold ministerial office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you just imagine Senator Hill in 16th century Spain when the inquisition brings down its verdict and he says, `Why don't you accept the umpire's decision?' Normally, if we believe a royal commission is fair and properly constituted, we would take into account the commissioner's findings. But it has been our assertion that this commission was a political exercise; a malicious star chamber concocted for political purposes.

PARA.TAB: We still don't know whether Mr Court and Mr Howard concocted this thing. Mr Court can't remember; he can't remember an event that occurred only a few months ago. He won't come clean and say whether he concocted this royal commission in collusion with Mr Howard. One of the things we do know is that royal commissions usually look into matters of criminal behaviour, financial impropriety, misuse of public funds for public office for private gain, national security, maladministration or failure of public administration, or specific public policy issues. They do not normally look, and never have looked, at matters of cabinet deliberation.

We all know—and this is relevant, Senator Hill—that the terms of reference of this royal commission were extremely restrictive. Even the royal commissioner himself in the transcript acknowledges that he had extremely restrictive terms of reference. There were no terms of reference dealing with Mr Court. Mr Court had raised these issues in the state parliament years before the tabling of the petition. There was no inspection of that whatsoever. Those matters, of course, were not for consideration. The recruiting of the royal commissioner again remains curious. The order of witnesses, the refusal to call Dr Lawrence early—all this reinforces our view that this royal commission was not fair.

The really defining moment of this royal commission came on 30 August. That is when Mr Gyles QC challenged Mr Marks to state the case which Dr Lawrence had to meet. The royal commissioner's reply was: `If you don't know what it's all about, then you'll have to work it out for yourself.' How Kafkaesque can you get when the royal commissioner gives that response! The one remark made by royal commissioner Marks that I agree with appears on page 2216 of the transcript. He states:

ANSWER.PARA: The sooner this commission comes to an end the better. I think that the experience here has demonstrated the usefulness of royal commissions is fast receding.

This opposition expects us to take into account this political star chamber's conclusions. You yourself sit in the shadow ministry, Senator Hill, with a self-confessed liar, Mr Tuckey. A self-confessed liar you are happy to sit next to in the shadow ministry.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We will not continue until we have some order. There will not be so many interjections on the left-hand side or we will have to stop this.

—In conclusion, in terms of opposition standards and taking note of inquiries, we can go back to Mr Justice Cross's inquiry into Mr Sinclair when he was Leader of the National Party. There was no challenge to Mr Justice Cross's credentials when he conducted that inquiry. He found that Mr Sinclair was basically a liar, and you kept him on for another three years. The conclusions of this particular royal commission are in doubt because the methodology is flawed. Why should we accept a political kangaroo court? No way!

—By way of supplementary, I will tell you, Minister: because witness after witness gave overwhelming evidence that Carmen Lawrence lied, and those witnesses were former ministerial colleagues of Carmen Lawrence and her own staff. So not only were they Labor witnesses who caused the commission to be called because of their public statements but also they damned her with their evidence. But, rather than face up to national responsibility, you will condemn the commissioner and you will call it an inquisition in one of the most offensive answers that this parliament must have ever experienced. Why don't you stand up and show a bit of the national leadership that your Prime Minister will not show and say, `The commissioner made a finding on the basis of overwhelming evidence; we will respect it'? She should stand down.
—Senator Hill will not even concede the fact that this was a politically concocted royal commission without precedent. There was evidence on both sides before the commissioner—
—They were Labor witnesses.
—They were Labor ministers.

—You have to shout me down. You are not willing to listen to the answer. You have to shout down the answer because you do not want to hear it. You demand answers, but you get up here and try to shout me down so that I cannot give the answers. The fact is that conflicting evidence was given on both sides. Even in the royal commissioner's report he does not go to the method of his thinking and how he distinguished evidence between conflicting witnesses.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. I understand that Wednesday, 22 November is the closing date for submissions in relation to the proposed amendments to the Trade Practices Act which will prohibit harsh or oppressive conduct in existing commercial relationships. I ask the minister what the response has been to these proposed amendments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Denman for her question. Overwhelmingly the organisations that genuinely represent small business in this country have strongly supported the draft legislation that has been put out as an exposure draft over the last three weeks. The closing date for their responses, or for a response from any member of the public, is 22 November. In that category I would put such organisations as the Motor Trades Association of Australia, which represents over 50,000 small businesses, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, the Australian Small Business Association and COSBOA—the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Only last night at COSBOA's annual dinner I am told that people present indicated their strong support for these amendments. COSBOA is made up of organisations which are all representative of genuine small business. It is a long list, but I think the Senate should be aware of it: the Civil Contractors Federation; the Food Retailers Association of New South Wales; the Queensland Retail Traders and Shopkeepers Association; the Small Business People (Hunter Valley); the Motor Inn, Motel and Accommodation Association; the Small Business Combined Association; the Australian Gifts and Homewares Association; the Furnishers Society of Australia; the Food Retailers Association; the National Australian Retail Grocers Association; and the West Australian Retailers Association. They are all represented in COSBOA and all strongly support the government's amendments to the Trade Practices Act.

Some organisations have either not expressed support or have opposed the amendments. One of them is the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and another is VECCI, the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which has members representing both big and small business. They are in the position of working out who they ought to represent in this case. They should look after the interests of the overwhelming majority of members, which is small business, or some of the very few big businesses that they represent. Not surprisingly, the Bankers' Association and the Law Council of Australia are opposing such changes. Again, all those organisations have affiliations with large and big business in Australia, so this result is not surprising.

But every genuine small business organisation in Australia has put their hand up for these amendments to the Trade Practices Act. What is very surprising is the actions of the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow spokesperson for small business, Mrs Moylan. Even though they have been going around and saying that at the next election the No. 1 issue for the coalition will be helping small business, they have not declared their view on this legislation. Even though an exposure draft with the actual details of the amendments to the Trade Practices Act is now available for public comment, they still will not make up their minds about what they want to do in supporting or opposing this legislation.

Only yesterday, when Judi Moylan could not give any indication to the Australian Small Business Association about her view on this, Mr Peter Siekman, the president of that association, said that the opposition should not take them for granted. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: They certainly haven't got us on board—certainly they shouldn't take us for granted.
We want to follow policies, not Parties, and therefore we have to look at the policies.

So far, the opposition cannot declare their policy on whether they support these amendments to the Trade Practices Act. Every genuine small business organisation in this country says that it wants to have them voted through before the end of this parliamentary session. Within the next three weeks, the opposition will have the opportunity to decide whether they will support them. They will have to make up their mind in this chamber. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Do you agree, as recently affirmed by the High Court, that to maintain our system of government effectively Australians must have the right to know, and the freedom to discuss and judge, their elected representatives, which freedom can only be exercised if that conduct is known or made known? Do you also agree that for a minister to falsely deny and seek to hide from the public the truth of his or her involvement in a matter of political importance is to deny the public their right to fully participate in the democratic system? How can Australian citizens judge a minister's or premier's conduct if the minister or premier lies to them about it?
—I agree with that general approach. The question I have been putting on the record today, when I have been so impolitely shouted down, is who judges. Under what circumstances—
—When you made the point, you were the loudest in the place.

—I know. Who appoints the judges? What is the motive for the appointment? How much can you rely on the veracity of that judgment? So the general pretext of the question is right. It is the electorate as a whole that makes a judgment individually and collectively on those matters. In our modern-day society, one is entitled to question why a royal commission would be set up by Mr Court, who was involved in this issue prior to the tabling of the petition. Why were no terms of reference given to look at Mr Court's behaviour? The conclusion I draw from that is that he did not want his behaviour judged.
—Therefore she didn't lie; is that what you are saying?

—No. He did not want his behaviour judged. Therefore, we argue that it is about who does the judging, who appoints the judge and the methodology used by the judge. It was grossly tainted in this case by the fact early on that when Dr Lawrence asked to appear she was denied and she had to come on last. The witnesses were ordered in a particular way, as you well know.

PARA.TAB: All these things amount to a political exercise. So the answer to the question whether these standards should exist is yes. Then you go on to ask who should judge them. If you have a decent, independent inquiry, I would normally accept the judgment of such an inquiry. When you have a politically concocted one, then the broader judges of that will be the electors themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supplementary question, it is not easy to understand what the minister is actually trying to say by that answer. Are you trying to say that the judge appointed as a royal commissioner was a biased judge, that you have no confidence in the experience that he brought to the matter and that you do not think he is experienced in assessing the credibility of witnesses and marshalling facts in order to come to some conclusion? Is that what you are saying when you query the appointment of the judge? Isn't what is important not the motivation behind a commission but the finding—whether or not someone lied and whether they behaved improperly? Don't the facts speak for themselves? Secondly, do you not understand—as indicated by your answer that you do not understand—that this commission was set up, started off, because two of Dr Lawrence's Labor colleagues came out earlier this year and said that she lied? It is her Labor mates that started this off.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Lastly, do you not understand that Dr Lawrence was—
—Order! The senator's time has expired.

—On a point of order, Mr President: if you cannot keep sufficient order in here for me to ask three simple questions, you should give me time to finish the question. You ask these people to be quiet; I haven't heard you telling them to shut up.
—You have not been listening, and you have not got a point of order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I am sitting four seats away from Senator Vanstone here and can hardly hear a word of the question because of the verbal diarrhoea from the other side. This rabble called a government on the other side were interjecting continually and you did not call them to order once, or if you did you refused to name names. I suggest that Senator Vanstone be allowed at least another 30 seconds so that the chamber can actually hear the question.
—Seek leave.
—The Leader of the Government has indicated that I should seek leave, so I do.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lastly, I ask whether you understand that Dr Lawrence appeared before the commission in the week that she herself nominated was suitable for her to appear when she came back from Beijing?

—On the latter point, you would acknowledge, Senator Vanstone, that she applied to appear earlier and was denied. On your first point, you said you do not understand the point I am making—am I impugning the commissioner. What I am saying is that the commission was set up for political reasons, the terms of reference were political, it had an unprecedented scope of inquiry for a royal commissioner and it was a commission set up which did not have to obey rules of evidence, as you know. It could take hearsay and any other evidence. It could do all those particular things. I said that I regard the appointment of Commissioner Marks, going to Victoria to find him, and the consultation with the Kennett government, very curious indeed.

—My question is directed to Senator Crowley in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. The minister will be aware of recent debates about the degree of income inequality in Australia. Is the minister aware of evidence about public attitudes to this issue and does this evidence support the alarmist claims of the opposition in this particular area? I further ask the minister whether she is aware of international evidence comparing income inequality in Australia with that in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Colston for his question because much has been said, particularly by the opposition, in recent times about income inequality in Australia. Many of those opposition claims are very wild and are not factual. This is from an opposition whose only policies so far seem to be labour market deregulation and public spending cuts, both of which would increase inequality.

PARA.TAB: It turns out that these claims are very much at odds with the attitudes of the Australian people. I quote the results of the recent International Social Science Survey as reported in the Canberra Times last month. It finds that an increasing proportion of Australians think that Australia is a relatively egalitarian country. The authors of the study say:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no sign here that recent economic reforms have polarised Australian society. If anything, they seem to have led more people to see Australia as a society offering abundant opportunity for a prosperous, middle-class life.

The reality is that the Australian people know the truth. They know that under this government there has been massive and spectacular job growth; there has been a very successful and substantial increase in social security payments, particularly family payments, especially payments that are targeted to low income families; and there has been a reformed, more equitable tax system.

PARA.TAB: As well as those things, there has been an enormous increase in the social wage: Medicare, child care, education participation, superannuation and others. The Australian people know that this is the record of a government that is really committed to a more equal society and that the opposition's claims are measurably rubbish. They know the opposition's policies would only increase that inequality.

Further, Senator Colston asks about recently published OECD figures and a report about the inequality comparisons with OECD countries. That report clearly gives the lie to opposition claims that the top 20 per cent of income earners in this country earn 10 times as much as the bottom 20 per cent. In fact, the ratio is four to one, less than half of that claimed by the Leader of the National Party. In addition, the report shows that Australians have the most progressive system of income taxation and the most progressive social security system amongst the OECD countries in the study.

A number of features of the report lead to the report actually understating Australia's true position compared with that of other countries. For one thing, the study did not include indirect taxes, which Australia relies on much less than other OECD countries. Nor does it include spending on the social wage: health, education and the like—a point we have constantly raised in this place but which you over there choose to ignore. Nor does the report include home ownership. Australia has the highest and the most equitably distributed level of home ownership amongst the countries in the study.

If you take all these things into account, there is very clear support for the idea that Australia is one of the most egalitarian countries in the world, with a government second to none in its commitment to a fair go for all and a fair distribution of the wealth and skills in this country. The Australian people know it. It is about time the opposition faced it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following Minister Brereton's obfuscation on ABC radio this morning, will the minister categorically state whether the government condemns the secondary boycott action being proposed by the ACTU in relation to the Weipa dispute, including the crippling five-day strike on the waterfront and the proposed seven-day national coal strike next week, or is the government so compromised by its desire to avoid conflict with its mates in the ACTU that matters of national interest are once again taking a back seat?

—Far from obscuring issues this morning, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, described the third-party knock-on effects of that as entirely regrettable. It is the view of this government that these matters should be settled between the parties and, if not settled by them, through the processes of the Industrial Relations Commission.
—What about your own law? Aren't you going to uphold that?

—This dispute has occurred not because of our law but in spite of it. This is a dispute involving a company that is using individual contracts. The company is rewarding people for individual contracts not on the basis of advanced efficiency or anything else but to punish the collective bargaining process. That is what this is about. It is about deunionisation, reward for those that are not part of that process and a punishment of collective bargaining.

PARA.TAB: The government has said that it finds, if you like, the third-party knock-on effects of industrial action extremely regrettable and is calling on the parties to settle this and, if they cannot settle it, to use the Industrial Relations Commission as a mode of settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister at least confirm that the secondary boycott activities proposed by the ACTU are illegal under his legislation? If so, will the government support whatever action occurs or is required to uphold its own laws?

—I cannot give a legal opinion on that. My understanding is that a 72-hour period of notice is required. But I will ask the minister to try to establish the facts, as it applies in this case, related back to the Industrial Relations Act and give you a response, hopefully, by tomorrow.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, who I believe is Senator Bob Collins today.
—You can believe it.

—Thank you. I ask: will the continued funding of the ABC's international television service be achieved, in part, by the closure of the transmitter at Carnarvon used by Radio Australia? If the Carnarvon transmitter is closed, how will the ABC ensure that Radio Australia's programs are received in central and eastern Indonesia, including East Timor? If other transmitters are used to replace the Carnarvon transmitter, have tests been undertaken to ensure they provide the same signal strength for broadcasting to the eastern and central Indonesian region that is now provided by the Carnarvon transmitter? Will the closure of the Carnarvon transmitter jeopardise potential arrangements with other international broadcasters, such as the proposed arrangement with the BBC World Service under which Radio Australia's coverage of northern Asia would be greatly improved?

—I will take the opportunity that has been given to me by this question to applaud strongly the decision taken by this government to provide significant additional assistance to the ABC to keep the television service going into Asia. Certainly, on the feedback I have had on that and the Northern Territory government has had on it, it is having a very positive effect in improving Australia's standing in Asia, and I am glad that the government took a decision to continue to support it.

PARA.TAB: I am personally certainly very familiar with the Carnarvon transmitter because the Carnarvon transmitter was directly established to replace the transmitters that were destroyed in Darwin during Cyclone Tracy in 1974. That is why they were put there in the first place.

The government has agreed to provide additional funding to the ABC of $6.2 million in 1995-96, in 1996-97, 1997-98 and 1998-99 for the operation of the Australian Television Service. That is a total of $18.6 million over those three years. The government has further agreed to savings of $2 million per annum from 1996-97 onwards from Radio Australia's transmission costs deriving from the closure of the Carnarvon transmission facility.

I do not have specific advice, I am afraid, as to whether actual tests have been conducted at the facility. I will inquire and find out whether they have. But the advice that I have been given is that Radio Australia's services are currently transmitted to Indonesia from short-wave transmission facilities owned and operated by the National Transmission Agency at Carnarvon, Shepparton and Darwin.

Capacity at the Shepparton and Darwin sites, which were recently upgraded at a cost of $12 million, will permit continued coverage of the Indonesian region, including East Timor. Priority for particular targets is, of course, ultimately a matter for the decision of the ABC itself, consistent with its programming requirements.

The National Transmission Agency and the ABC are currently discussing the use of the remaining short-wave transmission facilities to maximise their effectiveness. The primary purpose of the NTA's short-wave transmission facilities is the efficient and effective transmission of Radio Australia's services.

As I said, the Carnarvon facility was actually established in 1975 to compensate for the loss of the transmitters in Darwin during Cyclone Tracy. It has the highest operational costs of the NTA's four short-wave transmission facilities at $4.9 million per annum and it would have required capital expenditure of $2 million to $3 million in the near future.

As to any proposals with other international broadcasters, Radio Australia will continue to have the ability to develop cooperative arrangements with other broadcasters for the leasing of on-air time at the NTA's remaining short-wave transmission facilities consistent with Australia's foreign policy and international transmission interests. But the bottom line again is that I am assured that the facilities at Shepparton and Darwin are capable of continuing those broadcasts, including to East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Three weeks ago you said in the Senate that your industrial relations record was `a golden achievement by this government' and that `the only workplaces in Australia' where industrial harmony `is being upset are where there are state Liberal governments'. Minister, is it a fact that the destructive industrial action against the coal industry is in the only two Labor held states, Queensland and New South Wales, and that the proposed national stoppage of waterfronts under your industrial law is just part of the Jennie George threat that industrial action will continue on an industry by industry basis? Even though Prime Minister Keating and Minister Brereton are not prepared to stand up and be counted, will you accept your responsibility as the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and take action to protect your `golden achievement'? (Time expired)

—I am holding up a graph. Do you see those very tall timbers? That is the level of industrial disputes during your time in office. Do you see the very short stumps? That is the way the level of industrial disputes per thousand employees has come down.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Previous Presidents have ruled that the use of displays in the form of graphs were out of order. I ask that you so rule in this case.
—I have indicated before, as have other occupants of the chair, that that is an improper use of materials, but it is very common and has been used several times by your side.

—All I was doing was pictorially presenting on the graph the argument that industrial disputes under those opposite were high and that when we came to office they went down. What I was referring to in the quotation you fed back to me was that very fine record of industrial relations achievement that has occurred under our stewardship as the government of Australia. The fact is that that has been widely recognised. In the surveys of popular opinion about who handles industrial relations better, the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, Australians overwhelmingly believe that we do—and the statistics support that assumption.

PARA.TAB: This morning I was at the textile, clothing and footwear conference. As an industry sector they have decided that confrontation is out and cooperation in the workplace is in. They have achieved an enviable industrial relations record in that industry sector that has underpinned their global competitiveness and has enabled this industry, in the face of tariff reductions, to readjust and become world competitive. They exported $645 million of product from Australia last year when critics said that this industry would die.

What we are seeing is a contrast: a government that works with people, not against people, and in Queensland a company that works against people, not with people. That is the basis of this industrial dispute. The best advice that anyone can offer is to the company to start working with its work force, not divide it and not say to workers, `If you accept a wage increase as an individual contract we will pay you more than if you negotiate collectively.'

On the World Today program that I heard when I was driving into Parliament House at lunchtime I heard a worker say, `I do exactly the same job as my best mate. We both drive a truck. Sometimes we both drive each other's truck. He is a contractor. He gets $55,000 a year. I am on the award and I get $35,000. We do the same work.' That is what the principle of this dispute is about; it just ain't fair. I think he has a case, and that's the issue that ought to be resolved here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my point of order is on the question of relevance. We have now listened to the minister's comments for 3 1/2 minutes. I have given you, Mr President, sufficient time to make a judgment. He has not addressed the substance of my question, which was very simple: firstly, in terms of this dispute, whether it is being held in the Labor states of Queensland and New South Wales and, secondly, with regard to the comments by Jennie George, whether it will continue on an industry by industry basis. The minister has not addressed either of those two points. I would respectfully request, Mr President, that you bring him to order and ask him to address the substance of the question.

—The question was couched in much broader terms than you have cited. I believe that all that Senator Cook has said has been relevant, but I would ask Senator Cook to get to the points that Senator Crane raises.

—I was going to the core point. I would rather deal with the core point than the effects created by the ripples from that core point. The core point is simply the injustice being perpetrated by this company in its dealings with its work force at that particular site.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the site is located in Queensland is neither here nor there. The truth of the matter is that Liberal state governments, as a general rule, are more incompetent in industrial relations than governments of another colour and Labor state governments are vastly more competent than Liberal governments. That point, which was the point I was making, is true.

The serious thing about this dispute is it reminds me of the Robe River dispute in Western Australia. Remember Robe River? Remember Charles Copeman, the executive of that company who led that dispute? He was a Liberal Party candidate for Phillip and he conducted one of the most divisive anti-worker disputes in Australia. He embodies and typifies the industrial relations policy of the Liberal Party, no matter which way John Howard wants to cut it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In your answer, Minister, you made reference to work with the company. I therefore ask you: in view of the fact that some 11,000 employees who started soon after the 1994 Industrial Reform Act came through this parliament have now signed workplace contracts with this company, why have you now chosen with your mates from the ACTU to bring this massive industrial disputation to this country both in the coal fields and on the waterfront? When will you stand up as a minister of the Crown and accept your responsibility?

—I think there is a basic injustice at the centre of this dispute by treating people who do the same work differently in their remuneration levels. As soon as the company deals with all their workers fairly and squarely, this dispute will go away.

PARA.TAB: Meanwhile, there are consequences for the Australian economy, and I regret those sincerely.
