In regretting them, it is not good enough just simply to regret them; it is good enough to point to what the basic problem is. If you remove the basic problem, all the rest fall to the ground. Let us concentrate on the basic problem: treat workers who do the same work equally and this dispute ends.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the incident at the Australian Defence Industries site at St Marys yesterday in which a number of women workers were injured, one very seriously, as a result of a grenade exploding. Can the minister assure the Senate that Australian Defence Industries had not withdrawn or downgraded safety procedures or equipment prior to the imminent removal of the ADI facility from St Marys to Benalla? If he cannot provide such an assurance, why can he not do so? Does the minister anticipate any criminal proceedings as a result of this incident?

—This regrettable accident that occurred yesterday is being investigated by Comcare and state authorities. They are conducting a statutory investigation of the accident required under the occupational health and safety legislation. ADI is fully cooperating in that investigation and has also launched an internal investigation of its own.

PARA.TAB: It is for that reason that I will await the results of those inquiries before I make any comment as to the procedures that were being used and, if necessary, where any fault lies. I can assure Senator Margetts the investigation will be rigorous. It will, I hope, turn up the cause of this particular accident and will obviously investigate the sorts of matters you have asked about—whether proper safety procedures were followed and whether there was any relaxation or any abrogation of responsibility by management.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Deer Park Hotel in Victoria has struck the pub industry's first workplace agreement. Even though the employees voted in favour of the negotiated agreement and no employee is a union member, the union has protested against and blocked the agreement. Does your government support union interference in non-union workplaces? Does your government support union interference contrary to the democratic vote of workers? Is it not the case that enterprise bargaining has been so successful that workers are now voting with their feet away from collective bargaining and union representation? Is it not the case that such action is driving the increasingly desperate union leadership to take the only action they know—that is, holding the country to ransom?

—I am not aware of the details of the Deer Park Hotel resolution. The basic fact is that individual bargaining is allowed under the Industrial Relations Act, as you would be aware because the Senate passed it, but that there are no disadvantage tests. It is for that reason that unions may intervene and take a case against any particular employer.

PARA.TAB: I am sure Senator McGauran is aware that in some of these negotiations—I am not saying this specific one—employers have tried to strike bargains that do away with basic tenets of Australian life such as sick leave. The no disadvantage test does come in here. In setting precedents, unions are anxious to make sure that the no disadvantage test is properly applied. Whether this has occurred in this particular circumstance, I am not certain, but I am giving you the general attitude of the government to these particular matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. For some time I have been chairing a committee looking into the role of AQIS in Australia, and I have also recently chaired an estimates committee, where a lot of unfounded criticism was levelled at the organisation in relation to the way it operates. Has the minister's attention been drawn to a front page article in today's Weekly Times headlined `Exotic scares triple'? Can the minister advise the Senate whether exotic pest and disease outbreaks in Australia have almost tripled over the past five years as claimed in the article and whether this increase is due to the shedding of jobs in Australia's quarantine service?

—This is a very important public debate, and the media coverage is also important. As I said some weeks ago, because this is so important—and nothing could be more important than the quarantine protection of vital Australian industries—it would be something of a relief if the debate was centred on facts rather than fiction. I am sure Senator Boswell is genuinely interested in what I have to say about this. The article was largely based on Senator Boswell's claims to similar effect the other day in Senate estimates. Indeed, Senator Boswell is quoted in the article. He has given an undertaking to the committee to provide a list of the pests and diseases to support those statistics. I have been following up the claim since.

PARA.TAB: A lot of the coverage has been hysterical and a lot of it has been poorly based on facts. Sadly, the article just referred to falls into this category, because it is based on the information that Senator Boswell provided to the committee. The article claims that exotic pest and disease outbreaks in Australia have almost tripled over the past five years, which is precisely the assertion Senator Boswell made to the committee. That assertion is a nonsense.

The basis of the policy guidance given by the government on the cost efficiency exercises that were conducted in AQIS—and the coalition strongly urged that those cost cutting exercises be conducted in AQIS—was that the quarantine barrier services were not impacted on negatively. So the connection between this supposed increase in disease and the cuts in AQIS staff simply does not stand up.

The reductions in AQIS staff—and this can be demonstrated, as Senator Boswell knows—have been principally on the export inspection side of AQIS's services, particularly meat inspection, where a range of measures has been adopted to improve the efficiency of the service. These include the introduction of quality assurance systems under which the companies assume responsibilities for a range of inspection processes.

On the barrier protection side, reductions in staffing have been taken only where they have not impacted on the efficacy of the programs, principally again as a result of the introduction of new technologies. These include automated systems for clearance of cargo and the introduction of mobile teams with modern communication equipment. Of course, at the airports, where there have been significant increases in passenger movements, AQIS have actually increased the number of staff working in those areas.

The comparison of pest and disease detection in recent years with those of earlier periods as a measure of quarantine effectiveness is a fundamentally flawed comparison. Of the 13 plant related pests and diseases referred to as detected since 1990—these are the ones on the list and the ones Senator Boswell refers to—at least six entered Australia many years prior to detection, in some cases up to 40 years ago. For example, dry wood timber borer—and it is on the list—which was listed as being detected in 1990 was in fact first discovered in Queensland in 1952. One disease, pawpaw ringspot—God preserve us all from that—has since turned out to be almost certainly the mutation of an existing virus. Others like spiralling white fly have in fact been spread by natural means.

The animal related diseases on the list appear to include three outbreaks of diseases known to have been introduced naturally by migrating water birds—avian influenza and Japanese encephalitis. Other detections also do not reflect a breakdown in quarantine. The equine morbillivirus—and I have spoken about this before—that has been constantly quoted in this regard was in fact discovered only recently in Australia for the first time. Prior to that, as Senator Boswell knows full well, it was unknown to science.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, there has been a lot of misinformation put about by people who are mischievous about the introduction of disease.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —All that lot over there. Are you saying to us now that the date of the indication of the disease being known in Australia is the same date as that on which it was introduced?

—As anyone will tell you that works in the area of entomology or plant diseases, you cannot equate detections with introductions. In fact, not only can't it apply; it often does not apply. Many exotic pests and diseases that have been detected because of the new techniques available for detection were already present in Australia for lengthy periods. There is a long list of them: siam weed, dry wood timber borer, potato cyst nematode, black sigatoka disease—all recently detected but known to have existed in Australia for years.

PARA.TAB: It is not unusual, I am advised, for an exotic insect to remain largely unnoticed for up to 20 to 30 years before the population reaches a critical level where it is therefore detected. One of these, of course, the famous changa mole cricket—that is the one that looks like Senator Ian Macdonald—was detected in 1995 but, according to the experts, could have been present in Australia prior to its detection for up to 45 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one looks like you, Bob?

—That is the one that has a body like mine and a head like his—a little fat body and a big boofhead with no brains in it. That is the one. Mr President, you cannot make these comparisons. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, yesterday in parliament you named 10 child-care centres for failing to register for accreditation. According to the Melbourne Herald-Sun today, you have promised that no parents would be disadvantaged by their centre's decision not to register for accreditation. But, according to your own legislation, the step after naming centres in parliament is to remove the parents' fee relief. Would you care to explain to all those parents who will be financially worse off as a result of your coercive legislation how they will not be disadvantaged by the removal of their fee relief?

—It is a brave question from Senator Troeth because she is one of the opposition members who persistently opposed the introduction of quality care in child care. That is what the accreditation process is. That is what it has delivered. Some 3,600 centres are part of the accreditation process and a mere 10 have not participated.

PARA.TAB: The concern I have had in particular is that no family be disadvantaged because of decisions by centre directors, operators or owners. It is not the centre's child-care assistance; it belongs to the parents. So, at the same time as naming the centres, I have also written to parents—

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll redefine the question for you.

—I am very happy answering this, Senator. I have written to the parents advising them that I have no intention of seeing them disadvantaged. I will do everything I can to make sure that they are not in any way disadvantaged by this.
—Who gave you the list of the parents?

—There are a number of things that I can do, Senator. First of all, I have said—you should understand the legislation—that the right to name and the removal of child-care assistance from any centre is a matter for my discretion. I have made a great effort to make sure that the centres have had every opportunity to participate, but they have held out. So, in the end, I have decided to name them.

PARA.TAB: I have set in train a process to make sure that families are not disadvantaged. For a start, they should be informed of the facts. I have already had families ringing my office saying, `We did not know. We have not been told the full story by our centre director.' It may well be that the parents will meet—I am perfectly prepared to attend those meetings and to provide any assistance I can—and ask their directors to proceed with the process, in which case their child-care assistance will not be in jeopardy. I would certainly like to see that system adopted before I move to disadvantage any of those parents.

Secondly, I have asked the department to make sure that there are as many alternative places for child-care assistance available as possible should those families decide to move or the centres decide to not proceed and participate. Already I have had acknowledgment from one centre director that she will now participate in the process, having not fully understood it before. In fact, every assistance has been given to those centres to make sure they know of our major concern, and that is that all families participating in child care across this country can be assured of quality.

It is what parents say is their primary concern, and it is what this opposition is determined to dismantle, to wreck, to break down, if they should ever get into government. I cannot understand why they would want to ask a question about quality when they will do away with it. I will be making sure that parents are protected and that, as much as possible, centres are encouraged to participate in the process. We do not want to disadvantage parents. We want to be able to give every parent the assurance of quality care. That is my intention, and that is how I intend to behave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you know very well that on the one hand you are saying that this system is not coercive and that on the other hand you are saying that, if centres do not participate, their fee relief will be cut off. On 26 May at Estimates, you said, `What we want is that that opportunity be provided to all centres, and we have made it mandatory.' How can they have an opportunity on one side and it be mandatory on the other. Is this not just another example of how coercive and contradictory your system is?

—Absolutely not. This place has voted on it, Senator. Every centre has got a choice. If it wants to participate in the process, it can. If it chooses not to participate in the process, it puts in jeopardy its eligibility for child-care assistance. That is very clear. It is what the legislation says. It is what this place voted on. It is part of this government's commitment to ensure that all families get quality care. If those centres do not want to participate, then they should examine their own selves about why not. If they do not want to, they are perfectly free to do that. They have every right to make that choice and not participate, but they will then forfeit the right to be labelled as an eligible centre and therefore able to get child-care assistance.

PARA.TAB: In the meantime, I am determined to talk with the parents to see whether they can work with their child-care operator or director to make sure that those centres participate. They have been provided with all the information. I insisted that all those centres—registered or not—be provided with full information. Some of them have done the self-study. They simply are refusing to pay the registration fee. They are holding out. I am determined to protect the parents. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. My question is about the CRA-union dispute. Without regurgitating the debate about who started this confrontation and without trying to blame the unions, the contract workers or the company, will the minister please tell ordinary Australians who might have to pay the price for this symbolic war that you are all so keen to fight what the Minister for Industrial Relations is going to do to prevent the escalation of this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The substantive issue at question here is whether there should be a differential pay rate based on individual contracts or collective bargaining when there is no other differentiator. It may be the case at times that someone on an individual contract would receive more money for higher productivity or for certain other rights traded away, but in this case it is apparent to us that CRA are rewarding people on individual contract merely to make the point to those who prefer collective bargaining that they will receive less money for doing exactly the same thing. That is what is at question. It is very much an ideological rather than a practical industrial relations matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell asked what the attitude of the government is to resolving the dispute. It is for both parties to come together and negotiate on reasonable terms and to accept the fact that if they cannot resolve it they can take it to the Industrial Relations Commission and ask the commission to resolve it. We do not support the broadening of this dispute, as I said in answer to a question earlier today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you condemn it?
—The broadening of this dispute is a matter that we would not endorse.
—Are you going to condemn it?
—Senator Panizza keeps on saying, `Will you condemn this dispute?' Let me read a quote from an eminent political person:

ANSWER.PARA: I think the people of Australia will understand this. Whenever parliamentarians get involved in these industrial disputes, they raise the stakes and they make it more difficult for those disputes to be settled. I have seen it happen time and time again because a different agenda is injected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—John Howard in the House of Representatives on 2 June 1992.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. At least the minister's answer indicates that the government is contemplating some action. What I would like to know is whether the minister is going to convene this meeting that he says it is desirable to have and, if so, when.

—From my knowledge, the minister has been active this morning in having discussions with a range of people on this issue. It is one of those cases that I do not want to come in here and put on the public record whom he has spoken to, et cetera, because that will probably only hinder the process. But he is active on this in trying to get it resolved.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the alleged financial crisis to suddenly hit Telstra. Did Telstra's representatives inform the government about its funding difficulties during government negotiations on lifting the dividend payout in the current year to 55 per cent? Further, was the government aware of such a crisis? If it was, was such a government grab for money from Telstra not an imprudent decision?

—My advice is that the minister was advised by Telstra that the revenue adjustments will not in any way affect the achievement of its target of 100 per cent network digitisation by the year 2000. Network digitisation is currently on target, including in rural areas.
—What's that got to do with it?

—I am hit by a devastating interjection which says, `What's that got to do with it?' because it is all about the dividend. Senator Watson's question, with due respect to Senator Watson, was about the dividend. The issue that has been raised around this matter has been, given the size of the dividend, whether that affects the other work that Telstra is doing. One of the key elements of the other work that Telstra is doing is rolling out its digitisation network. I would submit that my answer is to the point and that the advice from Telstra is no, it will not affect that part of its work.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order, seeing that Senator Cook took it upon himself to basically make a submission on the point of relevance. The question inquired as to whether this matter was raised during discussions with the government in the context of the increase in the dividend payment—in other words, at the very time Mr Keating was trying to rip the heart out of Telstra and flog off Yellow Pages.
—What!

—That is on the public record. Don't question me. Therefore, the question is a very simple one: did Telstra inform the government about those funding difficulties during the government's negotiations? Senator Cook ought to be able to concentrate on that part.
—The minister is representing another minister, as he said, but I would ask him to take that into account in his answer.

—I am also advised that it is normal and responsible commercial practice for the board to revise and, if necessary, make adjustments to its expenditure plans and review cost reduction strategies in light of experience during the financial year. The company—that is, Telstra—has indicated that the changes it is considering are directed at ensuring it can meet its budgetary earnings before interest, tax and dividend payments.

PARA.TAB: As to what may have transpired in a discussion on dividend between the government and Telstra, I do not have any further information, but I will take that part of Senator Watson's question on notice and obtain an answer, preferably before the parliament rises this week.

The other point worth making here is that Telstra is a very effective and efficient operation. It does pay a substantial dividend to the Australian people because of that efficiency. That is what we as the shareholders on behalf of the Australian people, if you like, expect it to do while maintaining a highly competitive operation itself. What this government has done by introducing competition in telecommunications has been to ensure greater efficiencies and greater savings to the Australian community, who are users of this service. That is a positive change introduced by this government.

I juxtapose that against the opposition's intention of auctioning off Telstra and selling it to the private sector, and probably to a foreign company. That would just not be in the national interest. Where you need a national carrier such as Telstra to provide the services that it does to areas where the cost factor alone is not the only determinant but where communities in remote locations require a high quality service and cannot afford those costs, you require a government owned carrier like Telstra in competition with the private sector to ensure that you have both the profit to the community and the spread of services properly managed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I, too, recognise the leadership provided by Telstra in telecommunication advances, but my question related to the imprudence of the government in increasing very substantially the dividend in circumstances where there is an impending funding crisis. Was the government informed of that crisis prior to or during those discussions? If so, wasn't that an imprudent decision? I welcome Telstra's decision to provide funds to the Sydney Olympics, but that was not the question and nor were the other ancillary things you raised.

—Unfortunately, in political debate words are often devalued by overuse and by being used to exaggerate a position. Let us not devalue the word `crisis'. There is no crisis in Telstra. Telstra is a robust financial going concern, and there is no crisis in it or threatening it at all. That is a clear and unequivocal fact.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the findings of the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The sighs from members on the other side I think demonstrate their lack of interest in ministerial standards and their apparent willingness to accept lies from a minister as being legitimate political behaviour. We on this side of the chamber happen to hold a different point of view.

PARA.TAB: I was about to point out the urgency for debating this matter, but I think my friend is prepared to allow the debate, so we may save that time—except that Senator Kernot wants to propose an amendment, if it is any help. If the Acting Leader of the Government (Senator Robert Ray) will allow Senator Kernot to move that, we might reach an arrangement that will facilitate the debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not oppose Senator Hill's motion to bring this on, on the basis that it would probably be futile. Secondly, we understand there is broad agreement that there will be a division of time with an overall time limit of two hours which the Senate will meet and there is a fair distribution of speakers among the parties. I understand Senator Hill will move the motion and we will get a speakers list from there.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That a motion relating to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and the findings of the Western Australian Royal Commission on the Easton matter may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot can now move her amendment, which is to provide time constraints upon the debate.

PARA.TAB: Amendment (by Senator Kernot) agreed to:
At end of motion add ", but that the question on the motion be put at the expiration of two hours or at the end of the debate, whichever is the earlier."
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to show national leadership by removing the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) following the findings of the Marks Royal Commission that she lied and otherwise acted improperly.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is absolutely necessary today, particularly after what was, I regret to say, one of the most offensive answers that I have heard from a government minister in this place, and that was from Senator Robert Ray. Senator Ray, in answer to my question, basically said that the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) intended to disregard the findings of this royal commission because the government regarded it as an inquisition and a Star Chamber.

PARA.TAB: What an offensive thing to say in relation to former Judge Marks—a person of high public standing who, in the public interest, undertook this task and acted with great dignity and great restraint despite enormous provocation within his commission and the most offensive attacks by the Prime Minister of this country. Never in the history of this country has a Prime Minister attacked a royal commissioner during his commission in a way that Prime Minister Keating attacked this man. It was one of the worst attacks to undermine the credibility of a commission that we have experienced. I start by quoting the Hansard of 28 August 1995. It was Mr Keating who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I insist that, in the performance of their public duties, in their dealings with the public and in the parliament, ministers tell the truth and behave honestly at all times.

He insisted that `ministers tell the truth and behave honestly at all times'. Now the finding is that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) not only lied but otherwise behaved improperly. Who is the first person to renege upon that undertaking given in the parliament on 28 August? Mr Keating.

PARA.TAB: But that is not surprising, because the Prime Minister had predetermined his attitude to the findings of the commission, whatever they might have been. You will remember not that long ago—in fact on 25 August—when asked about the potential findings of the commission, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we'll reject them; it's a kangaroo court. It's a crook commission.
Again on 15 May 1995, he said:
So even if the thing `found against Carmen'—
the `thing' happens to be the royal commission—
it doesn't matter a tinker's cuss.

So the Prime Minister had indicated—even before the findings were brought down—that, if the findings were against the interests of his minister, Carmen Lawrence, he had no intention at all of respecting them. It is not surprising then that, when the royal commission's report was brought down yesterday and the findings were damning in relation to Minister Lawrence, the Prime Minister immediately said that he would take no notice of them. He said:
It was conceived in political malice. It was constituted with extravagance and partiality . . . an act of political malevolence by the Court Government.

He said, `We will disregard it.' That is a convenience for this Prime Minister. He said, `If we don't like the composition of the commission or its findings, we are entitled to disregard it.' That is after he got up in the parliament and said, `I expect my ministers to tell the truth.' It is his failure to stand up and meet his own claimed standards and his failure now to take a lead that forces us to bring this action today.

PARA.TAB: The debate has really moved on beyond Minister Lawrence herself. The public will make their judgment on her in the light of the findings made against her. The real issue now is what position the Prime Minister will take. Will he demonstrate for once a level of national leadership? Will he demonstrate that ministers within his government are expected to tell the truth and are expected to behave in a way in which the community can have confidence in them? Of course, when the test was put to him in those terms—because it was politically inconvenient for him to meet that test in a positive way—he said, `I will disregard the findings.' Right from the start, he indicated that.

Madam Deputy President, you will recall the attempts by this government to discredit the commission right from the start. Firstly, there were attempts within the court, using taxpayers' money, to try to close down the commission—they took the matter to the most senior courts in this land but were unsuccessful. Then there were the attempts to attack the motivation of the commission—which were totally irrelevant actually—on the basis that it was a Western Australian commission set up under the Western Australian Royal Commission Act.

When that did not work, the Prime Minister then sought to attack the royal commissioner himself. As I have already indicated, there is little that is more offensive than a Prime Minister, with his whole public profile and standing, attacking a royal commissioner who is simply doing his job in the public calling. When that attack did not work, Senator Gareth Evans came in here and attacked the counsel assisting the commission.

Senator Ray today accused this royal commission—and therefore the commissioner—of behaving as if it were a Star Chamber. There has been only one other occasion when I have regarded the words of a minister in this place as being more offensive—when Senator Evans not too long ago attacked the counsel assisting the royal commissioner on this matter on the basis that she was related to a Liberal parliamentarian through marriage.

That was most highly offensive, but it demonstrates the extent to which this Prime Minister will go to avoid his leadership responsibility on this issue. I can only say that I am saddened that he seems to have so much power and influence over Senator Ray that Senator Ray would stoop to the level he did—the level of a Prime Minister who has clearly lost any sense of national responsibility.

What I said in my supplementary question today—after Senator Robert Ray asked whether there was a reason why the government should take note of the commissioner's findings—was that, yes, there was a reason. The overwhelming balance of evidence was consistent with the royal commissioner's findings, and the overwhelming balance of that evidence came from Labor Party people—from former Labor ministers, from colleagues of Carmen Lawrence and from her own staff.

I think we all remember how distressed these individuals were when they were giving evidence before this royal commission, but they had no choice because under oath they would say the truth. What they said was that Carmen Lawrence was lying. One after another, they, Labor people, came before the royal commission and said Carmen Lawrence had lied to the Australian people.

She did not lie once. She lied and lied and lied and lied. She lied to the National Press Club because when the same issues were put to her in the parliament and she was asked whether she stood by what she said at the press club, she avoided answering the question. In other words, she believes telling the truth to the parliament in some ways to avoid the technicality of lying to a parliament and the consequences is more important than telling the truth to the Australian people. If that is her standard, she will be judged by that standard.

But the real issue here, as I said, is: what will the Prime Minister do about it? Will he indicate that this is not a standard that he will accept? Previous leaders of the Labor Party would have so acted. I cannot imagine Gough Whitlam behaving in the way that this Prime Minister has in these circumstances. I cannot imagine Bob Hawke behaving that way. I remember when his then Minister Brown had to go because he misled the parliament, maybe inadvertently, maybe not. Nevertheless, Hawke said that if you mislead the parliament—in other words, if it is an untruth—you have to go.

But none of that is in the ballpark with what Carmen Lawrence has done. What she has done was to avoid political difficulty for herself in the circumstances of the Western Australian government at that time. She sought to find a diversionary opportunity. That diversionary opportunity was to pick up a matrimonial matter, a private matrimonial matter, and to exploit it within the parliament to her benefit without concern about the interests of the family concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who brought it up first of all? Your side did.

—It is a credit that the royal commissioner said—this is over and above the question of lying—`I find that behaviour by a minister', in that case a Premier of the state, `to have been improper'. It is a credit that the

SPEECH.PARA: royal commissioner put that down in black and white before the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: But of course that has been disregarded by the Prime Minister as well because he does not care two hoots. He in turn has a political interest at a difficult time to maintain the integrity in terms of the whole of his government. In other words, `It is too politically awkward at this time to sack Carmen Lawrence and therefore I, Mr Keating, am not going to sack her no matter what she has done. Whether she has lied and lied and lied again, I will not sack her.' By not taking that action, he, the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, condemns himself.

Under the arrangements I must come to a conclusion. What I wanted to say, however, is that I thought it was put so well today by another Labor man, former Western Australian Labor minister Keith Wilson. What did he say, a man of very high public standing? I do not think even Senator Ray will object to this. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that the commissioner has come out with a thoroughly objective assessment of what has occurred. I think it is an assessment that should be accepted by everybody.
He is a former Labor minister in Western Australia, but he is a realist. He said:

I don't really think that the outcome of this inquiry will be what it should be because I think the Prime Minister has very successfully scuttled it by enforcing his own questionable ethics on his federal colleagues and on others.

That is the problem. The Prime Minister has forced his questionable ethics upon his ministers and none of them will stand up and now say that lies by a minister are intolerable. None of them will go to their Prime Minister and say, `We must get rid of her because it is important that ministers be treated with respect and confidence and if they lie to the Australian people they will not be so treated.'

PARA.TAB: We acknowledge, more with regret than anger, that it is our responsibility today to take up this issue and call upon the Senate to do what the Prime Minister will not. We ask the Senate to pass this motion which calls upon the Prime Minister, in the name of the parliament, to take action now and get rid of a minister who has both lied to the Australian people and otherwise acted improperly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of Senator Hill today indicates that this remains just a purely partisan political matter, as it has always been. But I want to make this point about Senator Hill's speech: he says that Dr Lawrence in some way—
—You can't defend this. You're too much of a straightshooter to defend this.
—Senator Boswell interjects; the former friend of Bjelke-Petersen interjects. Really, if I were you, with the track record of the National Party, I would sit there in silence.

PARA.TAB: These issues first appeared in the Western Australian parliament, put there by Mr Court and Mr Lightfoot. So, when Senator Hill comes into this chamber and condemns, by implication, Dr Lawrence for being involved in some way in the introduction of Family Court matters into the state parliament, he condemns Mr Lightfoot and he condemns Premier Court. Of course, he would never ever acknowledge that. But they were the ones who put this in the public domain first of all.

As I said earlier today, no-one doubts that there should be standards of office for ministers and office holders in this country. No-one would condone the telling of deliberate untruths. But what is at question here is who determines what is truth and what is not truth, and in what circumstances do governments take their advice on these particular matters. One of the traditional methods of establishing the truth has been royal commissions.

Royal commissions are very much a reserve power, if you like. Because they do not go on laws of evidence, because they have extraordinary power, because they can go on the basis of hearsay evidence, they should be used discreetly and for proper purposes. They should not be perverted for political purposes. They are supposed to stand above the political process—not be part of it.

What we have in the case of this particular royal commission is its setting up by a partisan political person and its being directed at a former political opponent, in an unprecedented way, to look into the deliberations of the executive at cabinet level, which has never been done by a royal commission before. It has been done on the basis of restrictive terms of reference, with no mention of what role Mr Court has had right throughout this, from 1987 to the tabling of the petition in 1992. Oh no, do not employ a royal commissioner to look at that sort of activity; just concentrate on your political opponent!

How was this commission set up? We still do not know because neither Mr Howard nor Mr Court will tell the truth. What conversations occurred in Western Australia? What conversations and discussions occurred between Mr Court and Howard—before Mr Howard scuttled out after the Crichton-Browne fracas—on the setting up of this royal commission? Mr Court was asked, `Did you discuss this with Mr Howard?' `Sorry, I can't remember' he said. As those conversations and discussions had been held only a few months previously, that answer had a certain ring. Why does Mr Howard come clean? Has he a better memory than Mr Court?
Mr Wooldridge blew the whistle on the setting up of this royal commission. Mr Wooldridge said that Mr Howard was liaising with Mr Court `looking for the best way to do it'. He let it out of the bag.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Wooldridge to you.
—Dr Wooldridge to me. He let it out of the bag, didn't he, when he said that Howard was liaising with Court. Come clean with the truth on this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I would like you to come clean with—and maybe some of the Victorian senators could—is: in the search for the royal commissioner, did Mr Court liaise with his colleague Mr Kennett? What were the nature of those discussions?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is entirely offensive to Marks.

—It is not offensive to Mr Marks at all. It has no implication for Mr Marks on this occasion at all. I want to know whether Mr Court rang Mr Kennett and said, `I need a royal commissioner; who have you got?' That does not mean the person they came up with is crook. It does not mean that at all. I want to know whether they had conversations and, if so, what they discussed in those conversations.
—What the hell has it got to do with you?

—I want to know, Senator Boswell, whether there was collusion between Liberal and conservative leaders around this country to arrange a fit-up. That is what I want to know. I said earlier today that royal commissions traditionally look at matters of criminal behaviour, financial impropriety, misuse of public funds, national security or maladministration—none of this was alleged here whatsoever. You can have a parliamentary inquiry into these things and so they did. The royal commission then was set up to go into areas never gone into before. If you like, it was a Star Trek royal commission. It went into areas of what was discussed in cabinet.

PARA.TAB: We could have set up a royal commission in 1983, if we had been unscrupulous, into the Howard budget fiasco. We could have demanded all the Treasury officials to come over, to see whether Mr Howard lied about the budget deficit or failed to disclose it when he knew five days before the election it was not $6 billion but $9 billion. We could have had a royal commission into that if we had wanted to act in a partisan way. We could have called everyone in and then censored Mr Howard for not telling the truth. But at least we had the standard of not to abuse and misuse royal commissions, and we continue to acknowledge that standard.

Having stated here that the royal commission was set up by politicos in collusion possibly with Mr Howard—the commission was appointed in possible collusion with Mr Kennett—having stated that the terms of reference were highly restrictive in order to protect Mr Court, having said that this was an unprecedented royal commission on the basis of looking at cabinet decisions—that has never occurred before—we then look at the way the processes worked at the royal commission. Mr Court did not offer legal funding for those people he believed to be affected, like Mr Halden and Dr Lawrence, and what has come in dribs and drabs has had to be squeezed out of Mr Court months later. So do not tell me that Mr Court was looking for justice, truth and the Western Australian way—not at all; he was involved in a shabby political exercise.

The order of witnesses, the way the evidence was constructed and the way the witnesses were led by the counsel all led towards a massive fit-up, and you know it. When Mr Gyles QC finally asked halfway through the commission, `Look, commissioner, what is this really about? What are the charges against my client?' the commissioner responded, `If you don't know what it's about, then you'll have to work it out for yourself.' That was straight out of Kafka's trial—`It is up to you to know what the charges are; I am not about to tell you; you should know what the charges are; just because you are a QC you should know what is going to be brought against your client; you should anticipate it', et cetera.

From the moment Commissioner Marks made that statement, he should have given it away there and then. But he himself, in moments of self-reflection, indicated what he thought of the royal commission. Commissioner Marks stated before he brought down his report:

SPEECH.PARA: The sooner this commission comes to an end the better. I think that the experience here has demonstrated that the usefulness of royal commissions is fast receding.
So even Mr Marks himself started to understand that maybe he had been sucked into this particular royal commission. There are other similar statements that he made to reinforce that particular view.

PARA.TAB: What we have heard from Senator Hill today was that people who do not tell the truth should not be in public life. What I have argued is: who determines that truth? Every now and then you do get some enlightenment. Every now and then a politician will come out and admit to having lied. If you happen to be a Liberal politician and chairman of the Western Australian Turf Club and have been convicted of assault, you are entitled to come out in 1989 and say, `I am a liar.'

That is what Mr Wilson Tuckey did on Four Corners. He professed and boasted to the world that he was a liar. And where does he sit at the moment—in the shadow ministry next to Senator Hill and next to Senator Vanstone. Did you throw him out? Do you object every time he comes into a shadow cabinet meeting, when he is a self-confessed liar? No, not at all. Those standards do not apply to the Liberal-National coalition. There is no denial of the facts, one will notice—none whatsoever. There is just a little dissembling that the circumstances are slightly different, when this one was self-admitted. The Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell, is a great supporter of Mr Sinclair. Mr Justice Cross effectively described him as a total liar but you kept him for another five years.
Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got our 50 minutes, Senator; we will divide it up as we like. The opposition did nothing about it. You were still an acolyte of Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and a crawler to him, so you went along with it. You said nothing at the time of the Cross inquiry—absolutely nothing—and you know it. So do not try to bring in a set of standards and apply it to us when there is no conclusive proof, and when you have self-admitted liars on your front bench and you do nothing whatsoever about it.

PARA.TAB: It is our contention that people in public office should be truthful and should look to their public duties. If they are to be judged, then they should be judged fairly and not in a set-up. That is what occurred in this royal commission—no question about it. Ultimately, in our society we have other judges—the electors of Fremantle and others—who will make their own judgment, based on their balancing up of the arguments from both sides. I do not know whether this motion will succeed or not succeed. There have been many such motions of a similar nature passed in this chamber. All the motion will reflect is a partisan line-up, and nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us start, at least in my contribution to this debate, by dispelling the great falsehood that has been used as a defence of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in this matter—that this royal commission has been a fit-up, that it has been a witch-hunt. They are the protestations that have been made. That defence is as false as just about everything else Dr Lawrence has said on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Let me explain why that is the case. How did this matter start? Why did we end up having a royal commission into this matter? Because two of Dr Lawrence's Labor colleagues came out earlier this year and said that she lied, that what she had been telling us is not the truth. That is where this matter started from.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not Liberals.

—It was not Liberals chasing Dr Lawrence; it was two of her Labor colleagues. Then we moved into a royal commission. What did we find there? We found plenty more of her Labor colleagues saying that she must have lied. It was her colleagues—people who worked with her daily, people who knew her well—not Liberals who perhaps had some interest in bringing her down. You would have thought that her Labor colleagues, former mates and people she worked with, would have bent over backwards to support her. But, as Senator Hill said, under oath they found out they simply could not go before a commission and tell lies—as it has been judged that Dr Lawrence did.

PARA.TAB: She was condemned not by a Liberal witch-hunt but out of the mouths of her own colleagues and, if one bothers to read the report, out of her own mouth, and now by the royal commissioner. The royal commissioner was at pains to say that he was not relying on hearsay evidence. There was plenty there, yes, but he was not relying on it. At page 59 of the report, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There was, however, other evidence which strongly undermined the credibility of Dr Lawrence. It did not depend on belief or disbelief of another witness, but solely on what she herself said.

Anybody who bothers to read the report will see that that is how Dr Lawrence stands condemned today—out of the mouths of her colleagues, her staff, her former friends and out of her own mouth by her lack of credibility before the commission. So let us not hear that this is a Liberal witch-hunt. Why don't you write a letter? Let us go and tell Kovacs, Willoughby, Imms, Sullivan, Estelle Blackburn, Marcelle Anderson, seven cabinet ministers and Kobelke that they are all liars and they are in some sort of Liberal plot to get their former boss and their former mate. That is how she stands condemned—out of the mouths of Labor members, not out of the mouths of Liberal members.

PARA.TAB: This royal commission was set up and we had the usual approach we get from Labor: `If you can't run it, wreck it. Start off from the very beginning. Say anything and do anything to undermine the commission.' That is exactly what happened from the moment it was announced that a commission was going to be held. We had bully boy warnings from the Prime Minister, saying, `Any judge or former judge who takes part in this will never get a job from us. The same applies to anybody who takes a job as counsel assisting. You watch out because if you want to participate in this commission and one of our members is at risk, sooner or later we will get you. We will fix you up and you certainly won't get any jobs out of us.' That was the message. Then we move to vicious attacks on both the commissioner and counsel assisting. It is just common practice for Labor. It is the same modus operandi they always operate under—if you can't run it, wreck it!

We see some of it here today. Poor Dr Lawrence! She did not like the order in which the witnesses were called, forgetting to say that she was called in the week that she nominated herself as being suitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —After being denied an earlier hearing date.

—Senator Crowley intervenes and says that Dr Lawrence asked for an earlier date. She may have subsequently asked for an earlier date. When a commission is being run and when she is called on the date on which she asked to be called, she rings back or sends a message saying, `Oh, it doesn't suit me now. Why don't you rearrange the whole commission to suit me? After all, I have to go to Beijing. I'm very important.' She is a very important woman. She rearranged the whole witness structure to suit her because she changed her mind. Let's get real about this. She was called in the week in which she asked to be called. Today's Australian Financial Review says:

PARA.TAB: A clearly angry Dr Lawrence said that anyone whose views concurred with hers was not believed while the memories of others who didn't were favoured.

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who reads the commission report will be left in no doubt as to the veracity of the commissioner's findings that Dr Lawrence was untruthful and acted improperly. Fourteen persons, including seven cabinet members—they were Labor supporters—contradicted her claim of non-involvement. What are these people? Liars? People we have bought off? Is this the claim you want to make? The evidence of those whose evidence was not inconsistent with Dr Lawrence's was fully considered by the commission. It was overwhelmingly against Dr Lawrence in the end.

PARA.TAB: Eight people present said that Dr Lawrence did raise the Easton matter, which she denied. Seven others were somewhat equivocal, but of those seven only one said she was sure she would have remembered if it happened and even she conceded she may have left the meeting and would not know. None of the others were any help to Dr Lawrence at all. Smith refused to answer, Edwards was not present, Bridge left the meeting, Hill left early, the remaining three said they did not remember but conceded they might not have been present.

What do we end up with? Eight ministers saying, yes, it happened, and of the other seven, one feeble bit of support for Dr Lawrence's position. Let us not hear any rubbish that this is some Liberal plot to get to Dr Lawrence. She is condemned out of the mouths of her former colleagues, workmates and her own staff. That should tell you something. As the commissioner says:

SPEECH.PARA: It goes without saying that each of the persons eligible to be present at the meeting at which Dr Lawrence spoke on 2 November was a supporter of her government and might be expected to be reluctant to give evidence damaging to Dr Lawrence and the political party to which they are or were committed.
They are the people who gave the evidence that is now so damning to Dr Lawrence. In any event, the commission was set up and, I think, properly conducted.

PARA.TAB: What we have here this afternoon is an attempt to say that it was not. We have had Senator Ray saying that they took hearsay evidence. So do lots of courts. So do lots of commissions. But if you read the report you will understand that it was not relied on. Senator Ray does not bother to make that point. Senator Ray's contribution concentrated on anything but the facts as revealed by Dr Lawrence's Labor colleagues. And those facts were that she lied and that she acted improperly. Everything else is absolutely irrelevant.

It might be appropriate to concentrate, just for the moment, on what the commissioner did actually find. Firstly, he found that Dr Lawrence was untruthful. I notice plenty of people on this side are seeking to say that memories differ. If you accept that somehow all these other people have a recollection that is incorrect and that it is only Dr Lawrence that has the true version, you could let her off for lying, if you were prepared to be so stupid. You could but, in any event, when the weight of evidence says that the facts show that this meeting was held and that these discussions took place and reveals the involvement she did have in this matter, even if you let her off the lying charge you cannot let her off for behaving improperly. You simply cannot unless you want to say that all of her former Labor colleagues who spoke against her are in some way acting to bring her down.

Dr Lawrence's conduct was judged to be improper because she supported the use of Easton's grievances and allegations for her own personal interest. She falsely denied to the public her knowledge of and participation in those events and in doing so she deprived the citizens of Western Australia of their right and freedom to discuss and judge what it was she was choosing to do as a minister and as a premier. That is the very basis of our parliamentary system. The public must be free to know what happens, free to understand what has happened and free to judge accordingly—give you a tick in the box for a stay in government and out of the box if you are not going to stay in government. That system will not work if the public are not allowed to know what has happened. And they will not know what has happened if they are not told the truth.

But now the truth is out and now we have to decide what to do. Labor has clearly decided what to do. They decided what to do the day this commission was announced—rubbish the commission. It is the only thing they can do if they want to keep Dr Lawrence. So they decided to say that a former judge with extensive experience—calling witnesses, judging the credibility of witnesses, marshalling a lot of facts, deciding the truth of matters—someone who has made a career of this, has somehow got it wrong. They said, `We are going to rubbish him because he does not like Dr Lawrence. He has drawn bad conclusions about her.' You could do that.

Secondly, there have been some weak in the community—very weak, in my view—who choose to ignore the findings. They do so out of some misguided view that because Dr Lawrence is a successful female parliamentarian, because she is a role model to other women, we should forgive her almost anything. I have actually read one feminist view that she should be forgiven everything because she is a positive role model for young women. Like hell she is! I do not want young women coming into parliament learning that it is appropriate to lie, to behave improperly and still keep your job.

I certainly do not accept the misguided view that we can accept lower standards from women to keep more women in. I think that is rubbish. It is an insult to every woman here and any who want to come in future. Quite the opposite: I would claim that when more women are here the standards in this place will rise, but certainly not if the likes of Dr Lawrence keep their positions. So they are the first two choices: just rubbish the commission or ignore it.

The third choice is to act on the findings. If you read the report, you will get a very clear outline of the basis of our representative democracy, if you do not already understand it. The commissioner rightly identifies the basis of that—that power lies with the people, that the parliamentarians act in a sense as trustees of that power and they must therefore act in good faith and be honest with the people so that people can judge whether we keep our jobs or whether we get the sack. In order to do that, they must have the information. That is what freedom of information is all about. And you do not have freedom of information if ministers lie about what they have done. If premiers lie about what they have done, then the public cannot possibly have a proper chance of saying whether someone should keep their job or not. They cannot properly participate in the parliamentary process if ministers are allowed to lie about what they have done.

Should we have to act? Should we have to consider this motion today? Certainly not. I do not fancy myself as weak. I do not think I am weak-kneed at all, but I will tell you this: if this report was about me I would not be showing my face in public for several weeks, I would not be able to put out my hand and take a cheque from the taxpayer as pay for doing my job and I would be far too embarrassed to come in and take a seat in the chamber, let alone on the front bench. I would do the right thing; I would resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this motion. I do so because I know Carmen Lawrence. I have known Carmen Lawrence for a long, long time. I know her to be a truthful person. I believe wholeheartedly that the findings of this royal commission are wrongly based—demonstrably wrongly based—and are part of a political campaign to hound Carmen Lawrence from political office. I think this is a disgraceful turn of events and those who have lent their names and their prestige to this matter stand condemned. I have no hesitation in coming to any of these conclusions.

PARA.TAB: This is a sad day for the judicial system in Australia and sets back the standing of royal commissions a long, long way. I repeat: I know Carmen Lawrence and I believe her to be a truthful person, and none of these findings, or the reasons offered for them, shake me in that conviction but, indeed, solidify me in it.

It is predictable, of course, that an opposition in this place will endeavour to make political capital out of these findings. It is predictable and it is part of the robust nature of the democracy of Australia. But the startling element of the presentations we have heard in this chamber this afternoon is that the members of the opposition appear not at all to have their hearts in it because they know at the bottom of their hearts that this is in fact a political fix. It is a fix which has not come off in any convincing way. A media commentary about these findings reveals that. I refer the Senate to a number of the analysts and columnists—not the reporters—who comment on the significance of the news, not those who carry the news, and their conclusions on this matter which have been reported today.

The truth here is that there is a controversial set of circumstances. There are a number of recollections about what happened in those circumstances. There are differing recollections for each individual as to what happened in those circumstances. But, because of its restrictive terms of reference, this royal commission was not allowed to explore those differences and investigate those outcomes and come to conclusions about all of the actors in this sorry story. The terms of reference were focused narrowly on one person in a use of judicial power to assassinate the career and the reputation of an individual. That is why it is a sad day.

What is common knowledge in Western Australia, and what has been reported in the newspapers in that state, is that a Mr Richard Elliott, who was the dirty tricks operator for the Richard Court administration, concocted this conspiracy theory, planted it on the royal commission in two days of pre-match briefing, and the royal commissioner has delivered the verdict that that conspiracy theory invited him to find.

The second thing that needs to be said in this debate is that this government places the highest seal and responsibility on ministers in this government for probity and honesty in the execution of their office. None of us will resile from that and all of us will answer that question whenever called upon to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: the minister, if he does uphold those standards of probity, will actually walk 10 yards to courage and say what he has just said about Richard Elliott outside the chamber and suffer the consequences if Mr Elliott seeks to take action. Mr Elliott, unlike the minister, does not have a position in parliament where he might defend himself. He does not have the coward's castle surrounding him as this coward across the aisle has.
—There is no point of order.
—That was an offensive reflection upon me but I will not claim the protection of the chair. I think it is a hypocrisy of the gravest sort and that you are indeed a monumental hypocrite when you are—
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President: the word `hypocrite' directed at another senator is out of order and you should make Senator Cook withdraw it unconditionally.
—I did not hear it because there was so much noise. If you said that, Senator Cook, would you withdraw it.

—I did use that word, but I withdraw it in deference to you, Madam Deputy President. The truth about all of this is that the terms of reference of this royal commission were drawn in order to attack the credibility of Dr Carmen Lawrence and not to discover the truth about these circumstances. It is no reflection on Commissioner Marks to say that; he never drew them. The terms of reference were decided by the cabinet of Western Australia and delivered to the royal commissioner by the political enemies of Dr Carmen Lawrence. They wrote those terms. These are Mr Richard Court's terms.

PARA.TAB: I think it is sad that the commissioner accepted those terms. During the royal commission, he said how restrictive they were and commented on the very limiting nature those terms imposed on his inquiry. The first thing to know about this royal commission is that the terms were written by her political enemies for a political purpose. Not surprisingly, those terms prevented the royal commission from looking at Mr Richard Court's conduct in this affair. He is a leading actor in this whole sorry story, but that was put away from judicial scrutiny.

One point about these terms, of course, is that, with Mr Richard Court out of the way and unable to be examined, the issue of Dr Carmen Lawrence was seen in isolation. I repeat that I believe Dr Carmen Lawrence to be a truthful person and this to be a judgment of error. I think it absolutely wrong that it should be visited upon Dr Carmen Lawrence that she started this affair. The record is true, and the Hansard of the Western Australian parliament reveals that. The people who started this affair were Mr Richard Court and Mr Ross Lightfoot. That is a matter of public record. It now seems that the broad conclusion is that they did not do it because they are not included in the terms of reference and Dr Carmen Lawrence was the only one involved.

The second point about this royal commission is the manner in which it conducted itself. It streamed witnesses in an accusatorial way in order to create a trial, not an inquiry. A royal commission is not a trial. Judge Marks was a former justice of the Supreme Court of Western Australia. When he sat as a royal commissioner, he was not a judge; he was an inquirer sitting on an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why did you call him `Judge'?
—Because it is an honorific title he bears in public, Senator.
—No, he doesn't. You are quite wrong.
—Then I do not call him `Judge'.
—No, you don't.

—I will call him Commissioner Marks. I will accept your correction. It was streamed as if it was a trial. The terms of reference were an allegation against Dr Carmen Lawrence, against which she had to defend herself. It was not an inquiry to get at the facts, but a proceeding to convict her. That was the structure of this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The royal commissioner himself has expressed his opinion about this. I have here a copy of the transcript of the royal commission of 8 September this year. Speaking to some questions raised by Mr Gyles QC, Commissioner Marks makes this revealing slip of the lip:
That's mainly because I do regard myself as independent and here to perform a judicial function.

SPEECH.PARA: He is not performing a judicial function. Nonetheless, he ran it as if he were performing a trial. He goes on:
The terms of reference have turned out, of course, to be fairly restrictive.

Even this commissioner recognises the restrictive nature of the terms of reference and says so on the record. He goes on: The fact is that I took on the task of being a royal commissioner without actually realising the storm that was likely to be unleashed or the issues that might be sought to be canvassed.

Again, he was reflecting on the fact that he may well have entered into this office not acknowledging the circumstances in which he had invited himself in. That therefore goes to the credibility of his findings in this case. He says again:
The sooner this commission comes to an end the better. I think that the experience here has demonstrated that the usefulness of royal commissions is fast receding.

All I can say is that that is exactly true. If royal commissions are used for base political purposes and not for getting at the truth, and they are used as weapons in political conflict and not as efforts in discovering information, then royal commissions are misconstrued, misused and misapplied and should be disregarded. He then goes on:
. . . has made virtually the result of this commission probably open to some doubt.
So out of the commissioner's own mouth are these reflections on his commission, on the limiting nature of his terms of reference, and on the possible doubt that is to be created.

PARA.TAB: You have only to look at the findings of this commission to find another flaw. Only those witnesses who gave evidence against Carmen Lawrence are believed; those witnesses who gave evidence for her are not believed. There is no analysis in this decision to say why he holds that view, other than to say that he does hold that view. There is no sifting of the evidence by saying, `Well, on this hand or on that hand, considering these circumstances, I therefore come to this view'. He just declares it. There is a declaration that `This is my view' without any justification behind it.

The purpose of an inquiry is to get at the facts and sift the reasons. There was no effort to do so on this occasion. There were two witnesses who gave evidence for Carmen Lawrence who are not dealt with at any length in this finding at all—Ross Love and Joe Berinson. I know both of these people. They are well-conducted, upright individuals. I know Joe Berinson better than I know Ross Love. Joe Berinson is a man who would die rather than mislead anyone, but his evidence is not analysed; it is lightly put aside because his evidence in fact confirms the Lawrence recollections. There is no analysis of that evidence at all. In this case, the accepted evidence has been basically hearsay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know Keith Wilson?
—Yes, I do know Keith Wilson.
—What do you think of his reliability?
—I do not have a high regard for Keith Wilson or for his probity, I might say, and I only say that because you asked me, Senator. You asked me and I will be honest with you: that is my view.

PARA.TAB: This is not a royal commission in the normal sense. There was no allegation that Carmen Lawrence endangered national security, that Carmen Lawrence misconducted herself in public office, that Carmen Lawrence financially mismanaged the state, that Carmen Lawrence got personal gain from what she did or that she endangered the public interest. There was an allegation that, in circumstances where there is conflicting recollection, she lied, and I do not believe that that is at all true. This royal commission was got up to assassinate her character, and I am not surprised that it has now achieved that result.

I will conclude on this matter, Madam Deputy President. The precedent of using a royal commission in this manner is something that the parties in this chamber and in other parliaments of Australia should pause and think seriously about. We have had a qualitative change in the role of royal commissions here. This royal commission is not about any of those things I mentioned a moment ago that normally you would have a royal commission into; this is a royal commission into a political foe in order to bring that political foe down and to accuse them of impropriety in office. If that becomes a tradition, then there are lots of other royal commissions in this country that could easily be slated.

Let me go to the evidence of one day, today, about that. In today's Bulletin, I refer senators to the Laurie Oakes column headed, `The ghosts that walk'. I will quote the concluding paragraph of this column:

Speaking of consistency . . . Howard was asked on the Sunday program why, as treasurer in the 1983 election campaign, he had stuck to a budget deficit prediction of $6 billion even after Treasury informed him it would be $9 billion. Howard replied: "The $9.6 billion figure I was in fact told the night before the election."

SPEECH.PARA: Oakes goes on:

That was "Honest John" fudging things. The truth is that the then Treasury secretary John Stone met Howard on Monday, February 28, five days before the election, and advised him the projected deficit was about $9 billion. There was plenty of time to come clean.

There we have an allegation that the then Treasurer of Australia withheld information vital to the national interest—something that the citizens of this country, about to vote, were entitled to know. Should we have a royal commission into the honesty of John Howard in not telling them?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook says that there has been a qualitative change in the use of royal commissions in this country. In the Democrats' view, the circumstances surrounding the debate today highlight what we see as a qualitative change in the political morality, or at least the kind of conventions, that we operate under in politics in this country.

PARA.TAB: There are three symptoms of this new political `morality'. The first symptom is the extraordinary use of a royal commission, the second is the politicisation of a family law matter and the third is the new `tough it out at all costs' model of ministerial responsibility and accountability. The Democrats do not like or accept any of these features, but the contest is being conducted under these rules, and that fact makes it very difficult to reach a clear resolution.

This is not a black-and-white matter. The first complicating factor is the jurisdictional argument, the overlap of the actions of the same person: in the first instance, a premier in a state parliament, and after that a federal minister in this parliament—in the state parliament a premier accused of misleading a parliament. I have raised this point previously.

The jurisdictional argument may sound technical, but I think it raises an important question. If a politician moves from one jurisdiction to another, as is happening frequently these days, does that politician take with him or her the baggage from the last position? We do not have an answer to that under our new political morality, but in this particular case the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, herself made a link between the two jurisdictions. I see that link as Dr Lawrence's Press Club appearance. I believe it was initiated by her to defend her position in the light of the Easton matter resurfacing through the comments of the former Labor minister, Mr Keith Wilson.

The second reason this is not a black-and-white issue concerns the matter of the tainting of process. In the Democrats' view, that started the day that Richard Court decided to move from the traditional, respected use of royal commissions, whereby we respected their authority and, consequently, their conclusions. Following on from that, we have seen an array of actions—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) attacking the credibility of the commissioner and seeking in advance to undermine his findings, and the commissioner, apparently feeling the political pressure from both sides, acknowledging himself the politicisation of his commission and seeking to extend, and succeeding in extending, the grounds of inquiry. We have seen the government attacking the counsel assisting for being related to the shadow Attorney-General, an attack I said at the time—and I still believe—had no foundation.

What all of this did, in my view, was turn the royal commission, from day one, into political theatre. Despite that, I cannot say that the entire episode, with all the reservations and qualifications I have expressed, does not raise serious questions about Dr Lawrence's fitness for federal office. I think it does raise those questions. The best construction you can put on this episode is that a senior minister, a serious contender for the Deputy Prime Minister's job, was pursued, for purely political motivations, in her home state. The worst construction is that, despite a flawed process, Commissioner Marks's findings are correct—that Dr Lawrence has lied and, what I think is worse, has maintained a lie.
If I did not have such serious question marks about the process, I would be able to say categorically that I believe Dr Lawrence should be sacked. But the question marks remain.

What is clear is that there has been a great cost—a cost apart from the millions of dollars to the taxpayers of Western Australia and federally. The cost has been to the credibility of a senior politician, a state Premier, the future of royal commissions and, most importantly, the political and parliamentary processes.

It must make us ask the question: do the last 12 years of Labor government and does the shift to the `tough it out at all costs' model of ministerial accountability now mean that ultimately there will be no ministerial accountability and that the only limit is what you can get away with and how tough you are seen to be while you are doing it. The new morality prescribes, in our view, a much greater value to being seen to be tough than being seen to be honest.

All around Australia today some people are saying that Dr Lawrence lied and others are saying that it was a witch-hunt. I can only repeat the Democrats' view: if these findings had been reached by a different process, by a less tainted, less flawed and less politicised process, then we could have all just about agreed that that would be sufficient cause to call for a minister's resignation. But the fact is that the process was tainted, it was flawed and it was politicised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were the results correct?
—Senator Boswell, can the results from a tainted process ever be correct?
—Did she lie to parliament?

—Can they ever be correct? That is a fundamental point, Senator Boswell. We cannot get away from that. But there is another catch which goes to what you are saying, Senator Boswell. In seeking to have us call on the Prime Minister to sack Dr Lawrence, you are therefore asking us to endorse Premier Richard Court's abuse of power to establish a royal commission.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President. It might be of assistance if Senator Kernot could address the Herald-Sun editorial today which says that it does not matter why the commission was established. It says, `What counts is that it was a properly constituted legal tribunal at which a succession of Dr Lawrence's former Western Australian cabinet colleagues and staff on oath overwhelmingly contradicted her version of events.' Could you simply tell us why that is not a valid conclusion.

—Senator Alston made his usual good submission, but it is a wrong one. Senator Kernot is very directly on the point, which is whether or not those who got the royal commission going should be rewarded for what she says is a tainted process, and the reward is the scalp of Dr Lawrence. That is the very important point we are talking about. I would have thought that her contribution was as directly—if not more directly—on the point as any contribution made so far.
—There is no point of order.

—I say to Senator Alston that if you look at all the editorials you will see that they are as divided as this nation is about this matter. I think that is regrettable because it is my view that we should have really clear-cut guidelines on which to act and then we would know, wouldn't we?

PARA.TAB: As I was saying before that point of order, in seeking to have us endorse your motion, you are then seeking to have us endorse what we see as the abuse of power of a government by Premier Richard Court to establish a royal commission for an unprecedented political purpose. The Democrats do not endorse these actions. That reservation, that catch, means that we cannot support the motion calling on the Prime Minister to sack Dr Lawrence. I want to say that the entire episode has brought parliament and politicians into even further disrepute.
