Finally, the reality of this existing political morality is that the fate of Carmen Lawrence will be decided by herself, by the Labor Party and by the electors of Fremantle. They are the ones who will decide. But what it points to urgently is that we need a clear and tough code of conduct. We do need a clear shift away from this `tough it out at all costs' model of ministerial accountability. It is an unacceptable model. Unless we take action, the high jump bar of accountability will be raised higher and higher each time something like this happens but for exactly the wrong reasons. It will be raised higher to protect at any cost rather than to exact decent standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 May 1995, Commissioner Marks was appointed to be a royal commissioner to inquire into and report on whether the circumstances and events preceding and following the presentation of a petition to the Legislative Council of the Parliament of Western Australia on 5 November 1992 by the Hon. John Halden MLC on behalf of Brian Mahon Easton involved conduct that was an improper or inappropriate use of executive power or public office or was motivated by improper or inappropriate considerations.

PARA.TAB: That is what this royal commission is about. It came about as a result of a call for an independent inquiry into this whole affair. That call came from a variety of people, including Professor Patrick O'Brien. I understand that Senator McKiernan, in response to a speech by Senator Campbell, called for an inquiry. Also Keith Wilson, a former Carmen Lawrence minister, called for an inquiry. So it was not just Richard Elliott in the backroom, as Senator Cook maintains, or Richard Court trying to get even. It was on the basis of a call for such an independent inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Penny Easton's mother, too.
—As Senator Campbell says, there was a call by Barbara Campbell, Penny Easton's mother. Today's West Australian newspaper summed up the comment by Commissioner Marks. It was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The preservation of our system of government depends on the preservation of public power to learn the truth of events in which there is community interest. The power needs to be strengthened, not weakened.

That is what this royal commission was about. This royal commission went to the heart of how public office should be used. I can think of no better reason for the calling of a royal commission than that. But let us look at the facts. Let us sift through the facts and get the reasons, as Senator Cook says. Firstly, we look to the finding that Commissioner Marks made. At page 115 of this report he stated:

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances the conduct of Dr Lawrence in the use of her office as Premier was improper :

(a) in supporting the use of Easton's grievances and allegations for her own personal interests at the expense of the interests of the parties to the Easton matrimonial dispute and members of their families;
(b) in falsely denying to the public her knowledge of, and participation in, the events and circumstances preceding the presentation of the petition;
(c) in depriving the public of its right and freedom to discuss and judge her participation in the relevant events by untruthfully denying the existence of that participation.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see no more serious damnation of a politician than that. This was a thoroughly thought-out report which exceeded 130 pages. This commission was conducted in an erudite fashion by a former judge of Victoria whose credentials were impeccable.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Cook has suggested, I will now sift through the facts. It is interesting to note that Commissioner Marks found that not only did he have to rely on 14 witnesses who refuted Dr Lawrence's evidence—14 witnesses whom he found had no motivation to find that she was untruthful, they being either supporters of her previous government or ministers, and I believe some seven of them were ministers in her government—but also on her own words she was damned. He also said there was other evidence which strongly undermined the credibility of Dr Lawrence. It did not depend on belief or disbelief of any other witness, but solely on what she said herself. He pointed to the National Press Club. On 19 April this year Dr Lawrence stated to the Press Club:

SPEECH.PARA: I clearly want to debunk the claim that I seized on this petition as a way to deflect attention from a police inquiry into my imprest account. The fact is that by the day before the tabling of the petition I was already aware that the inquiry was completed and that I would be exonerated and I checked that detail with the lawyer involved yesterday.

Commissioner Marks found, on the irrefutable evidence before him, that on the day before the tabling of the petition Dr Lawrence could not have been already aware that she would be exonerated because the decision not to charge her was not made by the police commissioner until the day following the tabling. She could not be mistaken about that.

PARA.TAB: He also found that in a doorstop interview on 10 April she had said that Keith Wilson was mistaken. She recalled a discussion about the tabling of the petition; but it was not on 2 November 1992, three days before the tabling, it was after that. The Marks report states:
The existence of any such discussion after 5 November in Cabinet or Caucus or elsewhere was extensively explored by counsel for Dr Lawrence.

SPEECH.PARA: They could not find any event which matched that description. Therefore, it was that Commissioner Marks found:

PARA.TAB: Dr Lawrence clearly fabricated the later discussion thesis as a device for nullifying Wilson's contention without accusing him of lying, which was potentially damaging politically. Wilson commanded a degree of respect. She gambled against the emergence of evidence which put paid to the suggestion that the same conversation occurred after the petition was tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: So by her own words was she condemned. This well thought out report does not jump to conclusions but sifts through the facts, as Senator Cook said, and it comes to very cogent reasons indeed. But if you do not think that is enough, look to her seven former ministers who said that it was discussed in cabinet prior to the tabling and look to the seven other people who worked for her government who said that it was discussed with her prior to the tabling. Contrast that with the answer she gave in the parliament of Western Australia on 10 November 1992, when she was asked:
Did the Premier—
that is, Carmen Lawrence—
have any knowledge of the petition tabled in the other place by the Hon. John Halden prior to its tabling at 2.35 p.m. Thursday 5 November and, if so, when?
Dr Lawrence replied:

This is a matter that must be dealt with extremely carefully, and I hope all members of the House will do so. I did not see that in the evidence earlier this afternoon it is the case that the Hon. John Halden presented the petition to the House and as I understand it he has made a clear and detailed statement this afternoon of the process involved in that.
She was asked:
Did you know about it prior to the petition being tabled?
Dr Lawrence replied:

After discussions with the petitioner on the advice of the clerk of the Legislative Council, the Hon. John Halden adopted the process and tabled the petition at a time of his choosing. I was informed that he was to do that and I learned the detail of the petition and its general thrust upon its tabling.

What she said there was that she maintained that she learned the detail of the petition and its general thrust upon its tabling. That is at clear odds with what happened—clear odds with what those other witnesses said took place. The report states:
On 23 March 1993 Janine Cohen asked her for the purpose of her article published in June 1993 in The Australian Magazine:

PARA.TAB: "You didn't know about the details in the petition?"

SPEECH.PARA: Carmen Lawrence said:

PARA.TAB: "No. God, if I had I wouldn't have let them go near it, that's the point isn't it, surely . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Of course she would not have let them go near it. Nobody would have if they had known what was involved. That went to the absolute root of this inquiry: the question of propriety in office. What Carmen Lawrence has done here is to compound her position by repeatedly untruthfully stating what she knew, because she states that she did not know the detail and the thrust of this petition. Yet, on her own words, as I have outlined from the report by Commissioner Marks, and on the words of 14 witnesses, who had no motivation to lie, she was found to be untruthful. You can understand that the press would be saying such things as what Michelle Grattan said in the Age. She said:

"If Lawrence is thinking of anything more than her own skin, she must be feeling God awful. First, she has been labelled untruthful by a judicial inquiry. The fact that inquiry was established as a political hatchet job doesn't offset the impact of being called a liar, because the weight of evidence supported the conclusion."

The heading of the editorial in the West Australian reads `Lawrence fails the test of truth'. Indeed, in other reports across the nation we find the press, too, were unimpressed. The editorial of the Age states:

The Marks Royal Commission has branded federal health minister, Dr Carmen Lawrence, a liar. Decency would normally dictate she step down as a minister of the Crown. But, in keeping with latter day political morality, both the government and Dr Lawrence are determined to ignore propriety and tough it out.
And there is more. The West Australian states:

Even allowing for the intensely political nature of the royal commission and the restrictiveness of its terms of reference, it is hard to escape the conclusion that they are not the sort of MPs in whom people can have much confidence.

That is where this all lies. This commission was set up to look at the probity in the exercise of executive power and the use of public office. The findings of Commissioner Marks are cogent, they are relevant and they are damning for Dr Lawrence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to put on record first of all my utter confidence in Dr Lawrence and the utter confidence of the Labor caucus in Minister Lawrence.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not want to interrupt Senator Crowley before she gets too far into her speech. Even though the arrangement was for 10 minutes per speaker, the previous two government speakers have each gone for just under 15 minutes. Even though Senator Robert Ray made the point that the government would take its time as a block, I wonder whether Senator Crowley might indicate which speaker from the Labor side of the chamber will give up some of their time to make an allowance for the fact that the first two speakers have taken 50 per cent more than their allotted and agreed time. It is just so that everyone else understands the speaking times that are involved.
—Shucks, Senator, shucks.

—The minister interjects `shucks' on my point of order. She obviously thinks that I am being disingenuous. I am being quite genuine in saying there was an agreement made in the chamber, so much so that Senator Kernot was not going to support the suspension of standing orders unless that agreement was made and so much so that I think she was going to move a motion that those time limits be set in the order of a motion from the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The first two speakers have taken 15 minutes instead of the required 10. The coalition had no concerns about that because Senator Ray gave an undertaking that the government would see its total allocation as a block of time. All I am asking quite genuinely is: at what stage will one of the government speakers be reducing their time so that the government's time in this debate adds up to the time that they agreed to. I presume that they made the agreement with a sense of honour and a sense that they would actually carry out that agreement. I am just seeking to find out at what stage the agreement will be abided by.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—My understanding from my other position as deputy whip was that the time allocated was two hours. I presume that at the end of the two hours the person on the bottom of the list is the one who will forgo some of their time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that it is a bit hard to not understand this as being disingenuous, but I take your word, Senator Campbell, that you have good intent. I sincerely hope that all the time that has now gone is not taken off my speaking time because, if it is or if it comes off Labor's time, I certainly would have to suspect why you ask the question. I have not been advised of how much time my Labor colleagues propose to speak, but I am not intending to take the time of the Senate for too long. Is anybody able to tell me how long the Labor Party—
—It was going to be 10 minutes each—
—I will do my best, Mr Deputy President.
—Order! It was agreed that it would be 10 minutes per speaker.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I might be able to clarify the position. I think there was an agreed time of 50 minutes for either side. I think we had four speakers and were going to split the 50 minutes amongst the four speakers. As Senator Campbell has said, half an hour has gone, which leaves 20 minutes. There will be 10 minutes for each of the remaining two speakers—or 15 minutes and five minutes, depending on what they decide to do.
—Do I understand that this time is to be taken off my speaking time?
—No, I do not believe that would be the case.
—That would be most appreciated. Thank you. It comes off the total time, I should have thought.
—Thank you.

—Thank you, Senator Macdonald. We can always rely on you for a generous, graceful contribution. I note for the Hansard record that that was said with heavy irony. As I was saying, I want to raise here the absolute confidence the Labor caucus has in Dr Lawrence and reiterate the point that has been made by a number of speakers here, a number of editorials across the place and any other articles that this royal commission was set up as a blatant political witch-hunt.

PARA.TAB: If ever there was a time to use the word `witch-hunt', it has appropriately been used here. It is a witch-hunt by a party that has set out to attack a brilliant and successful woman, because a brilliant and successful woman they cannot cope with. It is a point that I think needs to be made very strongly. The opposition cannot cope with the brilliant and successful woman that Dr Lawrence so exemplifies. It is a political party that even in the nineties still maintains a 1950s attitude and philosophy that women basically should be at home and not out in the work force or the community seeking other opportunities. It is a party still prejudiced against women.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Paul Keating's major speech.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not wish to use my time on spurious points of what not, but I believe that Senator Macdonald is interjecting not from his own seat.
—Oh, you are precious.
—No, I am not. I am suggesting that the standing order should prevail and that you should be quiet or go back.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, if you do wish to interject, I would ask you to remain in your own seat.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The words that I want to quote to reinforce this point, since Senator Boswell has particularly taken objection to it, are those from the New South Wales Liberal deputy leader, Ron Phillips, a senior figure in the New South Wales Liberal Party. On 23 October this year, Mr Phillips said:

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly on our side—
that is, the Liberal side—

there is still the prejudice against women—the women come much more under the microscope for preselection than men do. For example, women get asked the questions about their marital status, what will happen if they have babies, you know, does their husband support them. When men—
are being preselected—
it doesn't matter whether you're single, or you're married or what your situation is . . .
That is the quote from the opposition that I wished to put on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: is Senator Crowley allowed to be inaccurate? I think the person she is quoting is Mr Keating, who said those sorts of words in his maiden speech.
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is to seek clarification. Is the minister able to misrepresent the Prime Minister and call him some other name?
—I do not believe it is a point of order because I cannot vouch for the veracity of the documents from which Senator Crowley is quoting or purporting to quote. It is not for me to say.
—I raise another point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Oh, you are precious, aren't you.

—I'm not at all. Firstly, the standing order to which I draw your attention is that relating to relevance. I know from what Senator Crowley is saying that she does not want to discuss the motion that deals solely with the issue of whether Mr Keating should act honourably and sack a minister who has been disgraced and called a liar by a judicial inquiry or royal commission. Senator Crowley is seeking to say that this motion is in some way sexist and that, because the minister who was found to be a liar is a woman, we are making this call and would not do so if she were a man. To then move into the subject area of what a deputy leader of a state organisation somewhere might have said about a preselection process and questions that one might be asked at a preselection have nothing to do with the substance of this motion. I would ask you to direct the minister to make her comments in this debate relevant at least in the broadest possible way to the motion before the chair, and not to some other issue that she has floating around in her hollow head.

—I do not think that last statement was warranted, and I ask you to withdraw it. I make the point that Senator Crowley has been interrupted on more than one occasion and has been trying to develop her contribution. I will listen intently as to which way it goes.
—I wonder whether the senator would care to withdraw.
—Absolutely.

—Thank you. As to the matter of relevance, the whole point is that this is a political witch-hunt. That is what I said at the beginning, and it is entirely relevant. It goes to the points that just about every other speaker in this place has made for or against. Can you have any reliance on the conclusions of a political witch-hunt, particularly one that has set out to discredit and target a woman of the capacity and success of Dr Lawrence? It is clear evidence that the opposition is not comfortable at all with successful and brilliant women.

PARA.TAB: It is also quite clear that it is entirely relevant to pick up on the points argued, I think very splendidly, by Senator Kernot that you have to put grave doubt on any conclusions from a tainted set-up. This is a tainted set-up. As Senator Robert Ray argued so brilliantly, it is nothing more than a fit-up. They set out to get her and that is what they intended to try to follow up. You can place no substance and no serious reliance on the outcome of it. Members of the opposition are not happy with successful women, so they set out to try to bring one down.

What about the royal commission? I would like to make a few comments about this very expensive, something approaching $6 million, Monty Python show, effectively. I will refer to some of the comments from Commissioner Marks. He said on 9 September:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been put in a position which is probably irrecoverable in some senses because this inquiry has become almost impossible to control in an objective sense.
That is the commissioner speaking. The findings confirm that lack of objectivity. Mr Marks also said:
The fact that the present issues may give rise to the impression that I am going to make some political determination is a cause of some embarrassment.
Yes indeed, great embarrassment, and so it has been. The commissioner has been used for blatant political purposes. Mr Marks went on to say:
The experience here has demonstrated that the usefulness of royal commissions is fast receding.

Absolutely, particularly when in the past royal commissions have been set up for the reasons that were so well outlined by Senator Ray, none of which apply in this case. But the most important and revealing comment from Mr Marks is the quote:
The politics that seem to have emerged with all the controversy . . . has made virtually the result of this commission probably open to some doubt.
Not probably, Mr Commissioner Marks—absolutely. Beyond doubt it has been discredited by process, by the selection, and therefore the outcome is entirely in doubt.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone wanted to say in her comments that some of the people writing, particularly women, in support of Dr Lawrence wanted to suggest it was a question of forgiving her. I do not know whether some people want to argue that or not, but it is certainly not the case for me or this government. It is not a question of forgiving Carmen Lawrence; it is a question of asking and discrediting a royal commission that deliberately set out to target her.

It is interesting too to note some of the quotes, and there are many I could give you on the public record today. I think these actually convey a very large sense of what the electorate will judge. A female caller who rang in to 2BL Sydney said about Dr Lawrence:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe in her honesty. She was honest enough to say she couldn't recall. All the other people . . . even her deputy had an axe to grind against her . . . and all that should have been brought forward, and I'm proud of our Prime Minister, who's standing by a woman. All the women of Australia remember that.

That is exactly right. Indeed, to close my comments, I think my last words on this issue should be from the Anglican Archbishop of Perth, who said on 19 October that the royal commission had undermined confidence in Western Australia's social and political system and the state looked stupid. The person who is discredited by this royal commission is Premier Court and the opposition. They cannot cope with brilliant women and they have set up a commission that has not sought the truth but is focused on a selection of targeted misrepresentations. It is a gross error in judgment by the opposition. I concur with the archbishop's assessment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this motion today we are calling on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to dismiss one of his ministers. It has no relevance whether she is a woman or a man. She is a minister of the government, and a senior minister at that. No amount of attacking the royal commission, the royal commissioner or the judicial system is going to alter the fact that Mr Keating and all his ministers are trying to shoot the royal commission. They are trying to destroy the messenger.

PARA.TAB: The facts are these. Whether or not Carmen Lawrence, a senior minister, misled the parliament, the media and the Australian people, 14 of her colleagues said she did. They were not Liberal or National Party colleagues: they were Labor colleagues. On page 130 of the royal commission, in the summary of the conclusions, there are some damning indictments. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That was the first of at least four occasions before 5 November 1995 on which Dr Lawrence participated in discussions about the use of Easton's allegations. Contrary to the evidence of both Halden and Dr Lawrence, there was a briefing of Dr Lawrence by Halden late in the week preceding the petition's tabling.
So the conclusions go on for two pages that Carmen Lawrence misled the people.

PARA.TAB: Carmen Lawrence was prepared to play the political game: discredit the opposition, and use a very questionable petition to do so—but then, because she got caught, to cry that she is a woman. The sex defence: I am a woman; you cannot attack me. And then her sister over there, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), says, `Don't attack Carmen Lawrence.'

If Carmen Lawrence wants to be a minister, she cannot hide behind a skirt. Her attitude was to take no prisoners and that all is fair in love and war. We know the game, we play it hard. All things are fair in this game, except one thing: lying to parliament and misleading the people. When you lie to parliament, you lie to the Australian people. Parliament represents the people. Misleading the House is lying to the people. Carmen Lawrence has misled not one parliament but two parliaments.
Let us see what her response was on the day after the petition was put down:

SPEECH.PARA: Did the Premier have any knowledge of the petition tabled in the other place by John Halden prior to its tabling at 2.30 p.m. on Thursday 5 November; if so, when?
Minister Lawrence responded:
I learnt the detail of the petition and its general thrust upon its tabling. That is the way it is, and that is the way I have explained the position.
Then on four occasions she misled the federal parliament.

PARA.TAB: It does not matter a fig whether she was trying to play politics when she used the petition, or whether we were trying to play politics when we established the royal commission. The facts are these: politics is a rough, tough game. Anything goes and no holds are barred, except one hold: you must never lie to parliament, ever. This is what our whole Westminster system depends on: ministers not lying in the house, not lying to the people. This is what our judicial system, including royal commissions, depends on. Carmen Lawrence has lied to parliament—and it is very clear that she has lied to parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fourteen.

—Fourteen of her colleagues have said so, and the royal commission has said so. She has to accept that. Every newspaper in Australia has said so, and every person in Australia knows she has. The relevant point is this: Carmen Lawrence misled parliament.

PARA.TAB: I would be the last person to deny that Carmen Lawrence is an intelligent women. She was the hope of the Labor Party. She played the game fast and loose. She thought she could crash or crash through. Well, she has monumentally crashed out. She was going to tough it out; she was going to hide behind her skirt; she was going to hide behind the Prime Minister and all her colleagues locking tight around her. But she has failed.

Senator Kernot, who has been often accused of being the fourth or the fifth wing of the Labor Party faction, and who has been seen arm in arm with Jennie George at the ACTU, the political wing of the Labor Party, gave every reason today to support Senator Hill's resolution of dismissing Carmen Lawrence or asking the Prime Minister to do so. She has failed and, I believe, by that failure locked herself in totally to being part of the Labor Party. She has totally forgone any reason for her existence—to keep the bastards honest, as was the slogan her founder used in one of his campaigns. That is finished and no longer can it be used.

Getting back to the motion, 14 people of Labor Party persuasion said under oath that their recollection of events were reflected in the conclusions of the royal commission. As I said, that is why she is condemned. Many people have had to resign from the Labor Party because they have misled parliament. Ros Kelly resigned. Alan Griffiths resigned. Former Senator Richardson resigned. Mick Young resigned. All because they had misled parliament. On some occasions, I believe it was not a criminal offence, it was not a mortal sin.

But Carmen Lawrence has not misled parliament once; she has done it four times. She misled the media at a press conference. Four times in the House of Representatives she said she did not have any recollection of the events or her recollections were totally different from the recollections of her colleagues. No-one believes her, and you wonder why no-one believes her! No intelligent person would believe that Carmen Lawrence was not aware of the Easton petition before it was tabled in the parliament. The evidence of her own ministerial colleagues is conclusive. Her staff—staff are generally loyal to all of us—were not prepared to lie to the royal commission.

If Carmen Lawrence is not prepared to resign, then the Prime Minister of Australia must do what is right. If he is going to protect the integrity of his ministry, he has no alternative but to sack her. If he does not, then he is condoning a lie. If the Prime Minister wants to go down on record as being the first Prime Minister in Australia to condone a lie, then let him do it and let it be on his head.

I tell you what: this parliamentary system depends on one thing—the honesty and integrity of the ministers. In some cases I believe ministers who have been caught out may have made mistakes—the offences may not have been intended. Nevertheless, in this case it was intentional. Ten questions were asked of Carmen Lawrence in the House of Representatives day after day and we heard her denial day after day.

I say again: the integrity of the Keating ministry is on the line. If he condones a lie, then he is condemned, his ministry is condemned and he is no better than Carmen Lawrence. It is irrelevant, as I have said, who did what and whether the petition was used as a political weapon to discredit Richard Court—and that is what happened and we know that. These things happen. But there is one thing that you cannot condone—that is, telling four lies to this parliament, a lie to the press, and a lie to the Western Australian Assembly. Carmen Lawrence is guilty of all offences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We live in a free and democratic society which depends upon, amongst other things, a creative and proper tension being maintained between the political parties which operate within it. Where one of those parties seeks to create tension which goes beyond bounds, it puts that democratic society at risk and ought not be rewarded. If the pursuit of truth takes the pursuer beyond the proper bounds, then it should not be rewarded. That is the concept that has been put forward by this side of the House today and most eloquently put forward by Senator Kernot.

PARA.TAB: We live under the rule of law, and we should not do violence to the rule of law. One of the fundamental parts of the rule of law is the common law, and one of the fundamental principles of common law is that in the pursuit of truth we should use moderation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I will quote the decision in Pearse v. Pearse—and Senator O'Chee will know this decision—decided by Vice-Chancellor Sir J.L. Knight Bruce in 1846. It has been there a long while. It has been brought over into the High Court in such cases as Bunning and Cross—as Senator O'Chee would know. The Vice-Chancellor said:

PARA.TAB: The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much.

We on this side of the chamber have said that we take the approach that has been ascribed to Dr Lawrence's evidence, but I am talking now about the process that was used against her. It was a political process. That was seen and agreed to by Commissioner Marks. I do not want to comment on the character of Commissioner Marks, as has been done in some cases, but I do want to read what he says about this. He says:

The inquiry necessarily threatened damage to persons associated with only one of the political parties and thus possible damage to the party itself. When evidence emerged which had the potential to damage that party a predictable attempt was made to meet it, not merely by the normal methods of challenge such as cross examination and evidence, but by the attempts to discredit and intimidate the Commission itself. Accordingly, the need for protection, which would require amending legislation, or legislation for differently empowered inquiries, is so much the greater.

Commissioner Marks was saying that this was a political storm he was going into. What he wanted to do was arm himself with the sorts of privileges and powers that the courts have so that he could go into this political exercise. I have known Commissioner Marks for some years and have a liking for him. But in this context—and Senator Alston will confirm what I am about to say now—he should have remembered the rule that bound him as a judge pursuant to Chief Justice Irvine's letter that was sent to Premier Lawson in Victoria in August of 1923, which was not a political exercise, as the present one has been, according to Commissioner Marks. The chief justice said:
It is mainly due to the fact that, in modern times at least, the Judges in all British Communities have, except in rare cases, confined themselves to this function—
that means the judicial function—

that they have attained, and still retain, the confidence of the people. Parliament, supported by a wise public opinion, has jealously guarded the Bench from the danger of being drawn into the region of political controversy.

Political controversy is what you are drawn into. This is what this letter is all about—the danger of any royal commission being a political exercise. What is the situation in this particular case? This is the most political royal commission ever called in Australia. That is a very bad exercise of executive power and should not be encouraged. The fruits that the executive sought in pursuing that course should be denied them. There is no doubt that a gross mistake has been made in pursuing this course and it should not be given any reward for it being taken.

PARA.TAB: What has happened on the other side today? I surmise that Senator Alston will take this approach. He will say, `There is a finding that a particular person told lies. We should concentrate on that. That is the only thing that will do violence to our democratic system. We will ignore everything else that has gone before it.' That is a wrong approach if this was a legal case. I agree that this is not a legal case, but if this was a case in the courts you would also look at the process. If you look at cases such as Bunning and Cross, you would see that the more important thing is to look at the process. The process in this particular case was flawed.
I do not want to take Commissioner Marks to task but, unfortunately, I do find that there are some parts of this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I was trying not to interrupt Senator Cooney because he seemed like he was winding to a conclusion, but the more I listen I cannot see where he is actually winding to. I did draw your attention to this and the government whip kindly answered. He suggested that the government senators would take a total of 20 minutes. Senator Crowley took just under 15 minutes of that.
—That's not true, Senator. I was stopped by you.

—I am sorry, Senator Crowley. I do not write the standing orders and I do not write the orders that relate to whether points of order take time out of speaking time, but the reality is that the government has now exceeded its 50 minutes on my calculations. I am happy to be proven wrong. But, if the Senator Cooney goes on any longer, I suspect he will be taking time from other senators who want to make contributions to this debate.
—If I am doing that I will sit down, but I understood I had a couple of minutes up my sleeve. I will sit down if people are concerned.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—My understanding is that you had 10 minutes and you have three minutes to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a matter that concerned me and it ought perhaps be mentioned at this point. Commissioner Marks said that he was not concerned because he was not asked to be concerned with the issue of the suicide that was associated with this matter. He says that the terms of reference excluded the death of Penny Easton from investigations. Immediately after that, in paragraph 1.3.6, he made a statement which suggests that he has a particular conclusion about that matter. I think it is most unfortunate that he should have included paragraph 1.3.6 in his findings when he expressly said that he was not to do that.

PARA.TAB: The main point I want to make—and I will sit down on this—is that in accordance with the long tradition of common law the process used in this matter was a wrong one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the three speakers who are left that this debate will conclude at eight minutes past five.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do want to make some quick remarks. I know that a lot has already been said, but this really is a very important issue because it goes to the heart of the standards of integrity that ought to be applied in government. As Senator Kernot quite rightly said, over the last decade we have had a qualitative decline in the standards of political morality. It is extraordinary, therefore, that the person who some four years ago came to office as Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said this on taking office:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I want to make three commitments . . . The first is I pledge to give everything I've got to the job . . .
He certainly has not given everything he has got to the job. He has given it to a lot of other people. He went on:

The second is to deal honestly with the people, to tell them the truth. In tough times, of course, the temptation is always to gild the lily. I'll be resisting that temptation as much is humanly possible.

What he has done, of course, is quite the opposite. He has dragged the standards of parliament and, indeed, Australian political debate and political life down to a very low level. The real message of this whole exercise is that, as far as the government is concerned, truth, honesty, integrity and other personal virtues are all expendable and are subordinate to party political interests. That is not a creed we espouse.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, Mr Keating, by his very lifestyle and practice, has made very clear that he leads a mob of politically moral bankrupts. He does not believe there is any place for morality in politics. Politics to him is simply the art of getting away with whatever you can. In those circumstances, it is not surprising that there is a high degree of cynicism when he sets the example.

I have done a lot of criminal trials in my time and, indeed, a lot of civil actions. I have had to sit through the calling of witnesses where it is, at the end of the day, quite often a tough call to decide between competing versions. That has certainly not been the case here. In many respects one can say that this is one of the clearest examples of the one-sided weight of the evidence simply overwhelming the person whose truthfulness is called into question. Not only can it be no surprise to anyone as an objective outsider; I think the only surprise is that Dr Lawrence and those who feel it their political obligation to support her have simply ignored the fundamentals of the hearing.

I should just pick up on one of the statements that was made by Senator Cook, in his usual dissembling and disingenuous way, when he suggested that a lot of the commentary was not in support of Dr Lawrence having lied or, indeed, the outcome of the royal commission. The Herald Sun simply says:

It does not matter why the commission was established. What counts is that it was a properly constituted legal tribunal at which a succession of Dr Lawrence's former Western Australian Cabinet colleagues and staff, on oath, overwhelmingly contradicted her version of events.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very disappointed that, when given the opportunity, Senator Kernot did not in any shape or form deal with that issue. She simply said that the editorials were divided and she therefore did not even attempt to address the issue. I think that is a sad reflection on the approach the Democrats have taken to this issue. But I will come to that a little later. The findings made by Mr Marks are absolutely damning. I will quote just three of them.
Generally speaking, it is the weight of the evidence in contradiction of Dr Lawrence's version that requires its disbelief.
Secondly:

Dr Lawrence could not possibly have forgotten the pre-5 November discussions and briefing which were revealed by Kovacs, Willoughby, Marcelle Anderson, Kobelke and the members of Cabinet. Their evidence demonstrates that there were at least four occasions on which she participated in discussion about the Easton allegations.
Finally:

There is a tendency among commentators, and among others, to attach less significance to lies by public figures because so many tell them so often. Prevalence of such misconduct does not excuse it or make it any less serious.
Those findings ought to be incontrovertible. Michelle Grattan says in today's Age:

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that Lawrence had an array of former colleagues and staffers ranged against her version of events—people who mostly had no reason to lie under oath. Too many people remembered her involved in discussions of the petition's substance before its tabling, flying in the face of her denials and protestations of no recollection.

Some people may simply conclude that Carmen Lawrence played the game hard—in 1992 and when she got caught. Others will say she was initially unscrupulous, and then, when it came to choosing between her own good and that of the party, selfish.

SPEECH.PARA: Niki Savva in the Herald Sun said:

PARA.TAB: The most damning evidence came from Dr Lawrence's own lips.
As well as her inability to recall dramatic events, such as the threat by her then deputy to resign over the issue, she raised disturbing questions about the standards she observed.

She admitted that as a politician she felt justified in using any information in parliament in order to damage a political opponent. The guilt or innocence of the third party, or the opponent, appeared irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: Margo Kingston in the Sydney Morning Herald said:

PARA.TAB: In a devastating rejection of her claim that she knew of the petition only just before its tabling and might not have allowed it had she known its contents . . . Justice Marks, found Dr Lawrence pushed for its lodgement over strong objections within her party.

SPEECH.PARA: Geoff Kitney said:

PARA.TAB: The truly extraordinary thing about this whole affair is the damage that has been done to Dr Lawrence by the people who are supposed to be her political allies and friends.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . none of it could have happened without the damning testimony of key people from Dr Lawrence's side of politics.

PARA.TAB: This is the crucial issue. And this is where the real damage is done to Dr Lawrence.
The commission put on public display a parade of people who worked for and with Dr Lawrence during the crucial period . . . all said that she had prior knowledge of the petition.
Her claim, measured against the evidence of the others, was simply not credible.

SPEECH.PARA: The overwhelming weight of opinion on the part of those commentators who follow these issues closely is that Carmen Lawrence does not have a leg to stand on. She lied. She lied repeatedly. She has lied her head off. She has done it to serve her own interests and those of her political party. She has refused to acknowledge the standards of propriety that ought to operate in Australian public life. She has simply demeaned the whole political process.

PARA.TAB: Carmen Lawrence has not only been aided and abetted by the Prime Minister, but indeed her behaviour has also been condoned by him—indeed, I think a standard has been set by him. If it had not been for him, I think Dr Lawrence would have thrown in the towel when Gary Gray came to see her because she knew that her position was untenable, that her behaviour was intolerable and that her manner of denials was totally unacceptable.

There is nothing in the way in which the royal commission conducted its hearings that could in any shape or form explain why people who were Carmen Lawrence's political allies felt the need to say what they said. I think the only explanation that one can come to is that, whilst there is a code of conduct in the Labor Party which will often see them closing ranks on a political issue, the fact is that on this occasion her colleagues simply could not stomach her squalid and sordid behaviour. They broke ranks because they were disgusted and outraged, and they felt they could not remain silent.

That is what this is all about. Everyone on the other side of politics knows that. This is simply rationalised away by them as some sort of toughing it out political stance that will justify the behaviour. That, of course, is the approach that the end justifies the means; it is the code that the Prime Minister has proclaimed for the Labor Party. I think there was a time when quite a number of people in the Labor Party would have felt political revulsion at that sort of behaviour but now, of course, they are locked in behind someone whose standards of morality have sunk lower and lower over the years. It is the New South Wales Right's code of morality, imposed on a party that previously, I thought, would have stood for a whole range of civil liberties considerations and recognised the paramount importance of telling the truth.

Carmen Lawrence has been hung, drawn and quartered by her own side of politics. There could be no argument that would explain away why people gave the evidence they did. They were not forced to tell lies, they were not forced to give evidence; they chose to do it because they felt they had no choice but to expose what they obviously regarded as very sordid and unconscionable behaviour. I think that is what will stick in the gullets of all those who have followed this issue, that Carmen Lawrence was prepared to say or do anything to save her own scalp, even though it had the most serious consequences and certainly, ultimately, it has very serious consequences for the political process.The fact that Paul Keating seems to wear as a badge of honour that he can impose his political amorality on the rest of the Labor Party I think is something that they will regret for long after he has departed the scene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens supported the suspension of standing orders because it is proper that there be a debate on the issues surrounding the Marks royal commission. That did not necessarily mean that we will support the motion. We have listened to the arguments on both sides and have tried to read the royal commission's findings before coming to a final decision. We felt that it was important to debate the motion because it is vital that ministers be accountable to parliament for their actions. Ministerial accountability does not exist in the lower House, and it is constantly being eroded in this place as well.

PARA.TAB: This is a very serious matter because natural justice demanded that it be debated. We support that suspension because it provides a forum for accountability and debate, whatever its outcome. We did not support the two-hour time limit or the use of a speakers list and informal time limits because that itself violates the principles of natural justice and the democratic rights of each individual senator in this chamber to contribute to the debate.

The Marks royal commission was a political exercise. It was a misuse of executive power by the Premier, who made opportunistic use of information provided by Dr Lawrence's adversaries or enemies within her own party. Its timing and terms of reference were undeniably politically motivated. It is ironic that it is entitled the `Royal Commission into the Use of Executive Power'. Interestingly, the very first conclusion is that there was no relevant use of executive power. The only relevant use may well have been the appointment of the royal commission itself.

Nevertheless, the federal government's plan to use public funds to defend this political attack is a further wrong which does not make a right. There is no precedent for such funding of legal costs. There is no clear legislative authority. As the government has now acknowledged, any attempt to pay the amount without parliamentary approval would be constitutionally invalid. The Greens will be pursuing this issue further when the appropriation bill comes before the Senate.

While the process has been inappropriate, it is not to say that there are no questions to be answered over the Easton affair. In fact, there are serious questions here. The very fact that the government has accused the royal commission's terms of reference as targeting Carmen Lawrence begs the question that it does not mention her at all and, if she had not been involved in these matters, she would not or could not have been targeted.

There are some very serious findings within this report, including internal contradictions in Dr Lawrence's own testimony and the weight of evidence contradicting her version which requires its disbelief. This episode is symptomatic of our political culture, which lacks values and ethical fortitude. It totally fails to live up to public ideals and, as such, these sorts of episodes are coming to be more and more expected and will continue. No government should be surprised if their own political tactics come back to haunt them. In discussing the issue of ministerial responsibility, Hugh Emy and Owen Hughes, in their book Australian Politics: Realities in Conflict, state:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a question of whether ministers are, or can be, properly held accountable for their policies and their departments, important though that is. It is also a matter of noting the crop of scandals and growing evidence of systematic abuse of power by governments in all Western democracies in the last fifteen years. There is less reason these days to take the credentials of our would-be governors at face value—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks until the end of my speech, which is my right.

—My understanding of the rules of the game was that each of the major parties would speak for 50 minutes and would make their own internal arrangements. At one stage, when Senator Ray went a couple of minutes over time, he said that how we divide up our time is a matter for us. The end result is that Senator Chamarette has been squeezed out by more than she is entitled to have been. In those circumstances, we would not object to her being allowed to complete her remarks, which I imagine would take only another four or five minutes.
—As I understand it, Senator Chamarette has only a minute or so to go. I do not think it would hurt the chamber to let her go on.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . rogues do get elected and rulers often have feet of clay. There is evidence that democratic governments may, for ulterior motives including raison d'etat, embark on policies which depart flagrantly from the democratic values of society, and involve them in more or less deliberate campaigns of deceit, evasion and the suppression of information. Truth in modern politics seems to be increasingly at a discount. Governments lie when it suits them. Double-talk or `Newspeak' or `officialese' has become something of an art-form.

As senators would be acutely aware, the Greens believe in doing politics differently. A vision of new politics has been variously described as naive, idealistic, impractical, politically inept and irrelevant. However, this belies the growing community understanding and support for a new politics; for a change to the corrupt cronyism of our current political system. Politics in this country is a ship on which there is constant infighting between competing captains and their crew. What both sides have failed to notice is that in the process the ship has lost its moral rudder. Neither side has the ability to steer the nation towards a society of shared values and beliefs where outcomes benefit the community, rather than entrenched political interests.

PARA.TAB: The community expects much more from its representatives. While politicians shed their own values and adopt a chameleon-like belief system on entering the political arena, having surrendered their consciences to the constraints of party politics, the community retains their values. The community still expects politicians to uphold those values as part of the trust that the people give us when we are elected.

The dichotomy here is not just the one of Dr Lawrence between integrity versus political expediency. People have no faith that our political system has any integrity left in it. We have that same dichotomy operating now. Let's be honest. This debate is a political exercise, an opportunity to damage the government and a member of the government. Would the opposition be calling for this motion if Dr Lawrence was a member of the Liberal Party in the house? Do we have clean hands as we conduct this debate?

The Greens will not be supporting this motion. We believe that Dr Lawrence and the government should bear the responsibility for their actions and should be given the opportunity to show the Australian people that they do have a sense of values. Whether it is right and proper to step down after being found to have acted improperly for falsely denying and depriving the public of information is up to Dr Lawrence, her conscience and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is one matter whether it is right and proper for her to do that. Whether it is right and proper to call for it for political reasons is another matter. For that reason we will not be supporting the motion.

But I do want to say this: following the Marks royal commission and its findings, the writing is on the wall. The words are writ large. They are behind the lamp-stand with the glare of the lights on them. Anyone, including the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who fails to read those words is myopic.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this motion may well assist the Prime Minister and others to focus on those words. I believe that our responsibility, as members of parliament, in view of what has occurred and in view of the findings of the royal commission, is to focus the spotlight on those words and hope that the Prime Minister will make a decision in the national interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to earlier this day, I present a report into the allegations relating to the joint state-federal investigation into the alleged unsafe acts aboard BHPP's FPSO Griffin Venture dated 9 October 1995, together with the government's response to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The document that has been tabled is the subject of a return to order which was passed by the Senate today. I thank the minister for his additional response and for having the report into the allegations relating to the joint state-federal investigation into the alleged unsafe acts aboard the BHPP—that is, BHP Petroleum—FPSO Griffin Venture tabled.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I must reiterate that neither Mr Visscher nor myself are engaged in a witch-hunt on this issue, but both of us are keen to see that the truth is uncovered and, if there are attempts to cover up the truth, to determine why such a cover-up is taking place. The fact is that, if Mr Visscher's claims are true, there will have been a breach under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and that breach should be pursued.

More importantly perhaps, my concern relates to the sort of culture that such an attempt at a cover-up is creating in a large company such as BHP. We are all well aware of the many problems that have become obvious in the many BHP operations around the world, and many of these were raised at the BHP annual general meeting which was recently held in Melbourne.

It is my contention that one of the reasons for these environmental problems is that a corporate culture has developed that encourages short cuts and cost cutting at the expense of the environment and the social obligations to the communities in which they operate. The pressure that I understand has been brought to bear on some employees on the Griffin Venture to hold the company line is not conducive to the encouragement of a culture that values protection of the environment, occupational safety and social and community obligations.

In addition, and perhaps of more concern, especially in relation to the debate we have just had, there is the fact that if Mr Visscher's claims are found to be correct both the federal and state governments are guilty of complicity in a cover-up of the very serious allegations in relation to the incident on the Griffin Venture on 29 May 1994. It is these governments and their departments which are responsible for ensuring proper standards are adhered to in the petroleum industry and that the interests of the workers in that industry and the environments in which they operate are protected from any disaster. If the culture of cover-up extends to the government agencies responsible for this monitoring, there is very serious cause for concern.
Finally, I would like to turn to the report that has just been tabled. In the comments under allegation No. 3, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: If the purge pipe were assembled as described by Mr Visscher the joint State/Federal investigating team would agree with these conclusions.

It says that there would have been the potential for a sufficient electrostatic charge to cause sparks. The report then goes on to refer to some crucial evidence to support the report's contention that the purge pipes were correctly installed.

PARA.TAB: Given the crucial nature of that evidence, I therefore ask the minister to table the photographs taken during the Mark II investigation in September 1994, the BHP freight manifest GV0025 relating to the delivery of the purge pipe and joining pieces on 5 May 1994, the statement by Mr F. Jioni indicating that the flexible pipe was joined by sleeves and the comment by Mr J. Patrick in his fax dated 8 September 1995 indicating that BHP Petroleum believed that the purge pipe work was connected using the internal metallic conductors and externally with tape. I will provide these requests to the minister if he does not have a copy of the Hansard because these are extremely important. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 15 November 1995, from Senator Parer:
Dear Mr President,

PROCTEXT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The government's failure to stand by its own Industrial Relations Act, the principal object of which is the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by encouraging and facilitating the making of agreements; its failure to support the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and its failure to dissuade or condemn its Accord Partner, the ACTU, for orchestrating a round of strikes and secondary boycotts which will include a five day closure of the nation's ports.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Parer, I will advise honourable senators that an informal arrangement has been made in the chamber between the whips about times. An agreed list has been circulated. I will ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: The government's failure to stand by its own Industrial Relations Act, the principal object of which is the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by encouraging and facilitating the making of agreements; its failure to support the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and its failure to dissuade or condemn its Accord Partner, the ACTU, for orchestrating a round of strikes and secondary boycotts which will include a 5 day closure of the nation's ports.

SPEECH.PARA: I am moving this matter of urgency today because of the absolutely disastrous effects that have flowed from the dispute at Weipa, the failure of this government to support the Industrial Relations Commission and its failure to dissuade its partner, the ACTU, in orchestrating a round of strikes and secondary boycotts. These secondary boycotts do not apply to just the nation's ports. I understand that today the ACTU has said that it intends to start a seven-day coal strike from Tuesday next week.

PARA.TAB: I think it is worth stating from the outset that this particular dispute is happening under federal and state governments which are Labor. It has nothing whatsoever to do with coalition industrial relation policies. It is the government's Industrial Relations Act under which this is occurring.

Four weeks ago 75 out of about 600 Comalco workers went on strike because they claimed that the company paid workers on individual contracts up to $20,000 a year more than their unionised colleagues. Just in the recent 24 hours, even that has been clarified in that the amount involved in fact is $7,000. That is just a matter of correction, but it shows the sort of exaggeration that goes on among these union people when they get the bit between their teeth. What is this about? It is about CRA offering workers at its sites the choice of an award or a contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Choice?

—I am delighted with that interjection because even the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, did not understand. He said, `Once you make the choice, that's the end of it.' Senator Burns knows better than this because he would have done some work on this. He would have found that those people who make the choice to go onto a contract have a certain period of time to change their minds. They can actually go back onto the award, if they wish.
—They are terrified. That is the problem.

—`They are terrified,' says Senator Burns. There is a choice, and it relates to a whole range of amendments to the sorts of work practices that have occurred under the award. Just to make sure that everyone knows about this, because a lot of people seem not to know, including the Minister for Industrial Relations—I have sought approval for this from the minister who is on duty—I would like to incorporate in Hansard the differences offered between the award and a contract. Rather than read them out and go through them item by item, I seek leave to incorporate that table.
