TALK.START.PARA: —What happened is that after the employees went on strike—and, as I said, they had a choice whether to be under the award or on contract; it is not a compulsory thing—they then decided to blockade Weipa, despite an order from the Industrial Relations Commission under the act, which is this Labor government's act of parliament. The ACTU then announced it would conduct an industrial campaign of unprecedented magnitude—to hell with the rest of Australia, to hell with our reputation as a reliable supplier. The Assistant Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Tim Pallas, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we will seek to initiate a course of action against CRA and CRA associated companies of a magnitude and level that this country has never before seen.
Then we had the Secretary of the ACTU, Bill Kelty, saying:
. . . for us to be beaten is for the union movement to lose its heart, its soul, and its purpose.

There would be many who would argue that they lost all three many years ago, when the most important thing became to them not the workers but their own power base. Bill Kelty then said, `We can't afford to lose this battle,' and last Monday he promised `a tough and brutal campaign'.

PARA.TAB: So what happens in this moment of crisis? When we have all the ports on strike, when we have trouble in our coal industry—our largest export industry and one with which I was involved for many years—we have the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) leaving for Osaka three days early to do some lobbying, abandoning Australia. The minister is so far out of touch that he does not even know how enterprise agreements work, stating on Lateline last night that once an employee accepted a contract there was no going back—and I have mentioned that earlier. Just to clarify that, that position was clarified very quickly when it was said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . new employees start on an individual staff contract but after one month that individual has the option of staying on that contract or changing to a collective award contract—
under the terms and conditions which apply to the relevant award. All this has been done absolutely legally.

PARA.TAB: But we have had the unions over the years taking the view that they are above the law; they can thumb their noses at the law.The fact is, as I have pointed out, people do have the choice. That, for some reason, in a closed shop situation is something that unions cannot come to grips with: giving people a choice. What this is all about is that a contract is being offered which offers better benefits than those which can be accessed under the award.

TALK.START.PARA: —Discrimination is no choice.

—Discrimination! This is not discrimination; you have a choice. There is an award in place—an award that was negotiated with the unions. You can stick with the award if you want to. CRA has done everything exactly in accordance with the act. CRA and every other citizen and company in this country are required to act according to the law, except the leaders of the union movement, who are calling the shots on this.

PARA.TAB: It is the ACTU and the unions which are acting illegally by orchestrating a round of strikes and secondary boycotts. There is no concern whatsoever for the damage being done to Australia's image and our international reputation. We have talked about this for years in this place. We had a bad reputation for many years, which I found embarrassing in my own field, as being an unreliable supplier. Now we are having something like a week's strike that will just exacerbate that position.

The fact is that the new President of the ACTU, Jennie George, and Bill Kelty have a single agenda: simply to retain power. They have no concern for the individual workers. If they had a concern for the individual workers, are they going to allow these disputes around Australia, which will cause stand downs to innocent people, when they could be pursuing the Industrial Relations Act according to the law itself—the act that this government put into place in cooperation with the ACTU? But no, we will not do that; we will use the old thuggery, heavy-handed approach that has been the case in years gone by. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks on this matter of urgency. I rise again to debate the coalition on industrial relations. I take pleasure in doing that because every time we have this debate it reinforces the reasons why those opposite are not fit to form a government in this country—they cannot escape the ideological straitjacket that has bound them since they were taken over by the hard right forces some 10 years or so ago.

PARA.TAB: The opposition feels compelled to support the industrial relations ideology that was championed originally by Robe River in my own state of Western Australia and your state, Mr Acting Deputy President. It later preselected the architect of that particular campaign as a Liberal Party candidate. I think the opposition is very much linked to this hard right industrial relations agenda that we are again seeing run by CRA in this Weipa dispute.

I would like to acknowledge the presence in the chamber of Mr Fred Riebeling, the member for Ashburton in Western Australia. He has had a keen interest in these issues because in his own area in the north-west of Western Australia these debates with Robe River and Hammersley Iron have been at the forefront and have caused a great deal of concern and division within the community.

What I would like to say, first of all, is that this situation is the making of the company CRA. This is not an isolated incident. It is a result of CRA pursuing a quite calculated and deliberate strategy in terms of its industrial relations in this country. It has been endeavouring for some time to undermine longstanding and fundamental principles of the Australian industrial relations system—the right of workers to be represented by unions and their right to bargain collectively.

Even in some of the countries dominated by fairly conservative or right wing governments, those rights to be represented by unions and the right to bargain collectively are a part of their system. I think it would be a grave backward step if this country were ever to accept the sort of philosophy that CRA is promoting.

The situation does not arise from any failure or flaw in the Industrial Relations Act or the government's industrial relations policy. The government stands by those policies and the legislative framework. The objects of the Industrial Relations Act do provide for the encouragement and facilitation of the making of agreements between the parties involved in industrial relations, but it is fundamental to the government's approach that agreements are reached collectively. Collective bargaining is central to and at the foundation of Labor's approach to effective industrial relations.

The act was not intended, nor was it designed, to facilitate or encourage individual contracts. That approach is represented by the WA state government's approach and its Workplace Agreements Act. But the individual workplace agreements used at Weipa are not the agreements that are anticipated by the federal legislation. The workers at Weipa are covered by a minimum rates award, and the payments that the company has made to those persons going onto contracts could be represented as over-award payments, in a sense.

In Weipa we are seeing discrimination between those workers who will sign contracts and those workers who will not. What the company is doing, in a deliberate strategy to undermine collective bargaining, is making those arrangements for, offering financial inducements to, only those workers who are prepared to sign individual workplace agreements. There is no question that the people who choose not to sign those contracts are being treated unfairly. To say that they have a choice is a nonsense, because the choice is to receive far less in pay and conditions than those who are prepared to sign individual contracts. So the workers are left in a situation of either being discriminated against—receiving far less than fellow workers doing the same work—or having to sign the contract. For new employees, there is no bargaining power. Clearly, those new employees sign the contract or they do not get the job.

CRA has embarked on a deliberate strategy of using individual contracts to remove its workers from those collective bargaining arrangements encouraged by the act. As I have said, this is not a new strategy; we have seen it in a number of CRA-controlled sites around the country. In a recent press release, Comalco even admitted that it was discriminating against those workers who chose to stay on award conditions. A press release from Mr Terry Palmer, the chief executive, on 13 November said:

SPEECH.PARA: He acknowledged that the award employees at Weipa had not had an enterprise bargaining pay increase for some time. "We should have addressed the up-dating of pay for award-covered employees earlier," Mr Palmer said.
It went on to say:
Differences averaging $7,000 per annum have emerged and these should receive serious attention.

So we have seen the only sign so far from the company acknowledging that there is a real problem in the way that it has used individual contracts to discriminate against those who chose to stay on the award system, or the collective bargaining enterprise agreement, and who are now being seriously discriminated against.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer made reference to the government's position regarding the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is quite clear that the government maintains its position that the place to resolve this dispute is in the Industrial Relations Commission. The government has always held this view and will continue to argue that the parties should seek to use the good offices of the Industrial Relations Commission to resolve their differences and settle the dispute.

The government does not support the widening of the dispute. Obviously we are very concerned about the implications for the economy of any widening of the dispute at Weipa. We understand the frustration of the union movement over CRA's pursuits of its objectives. On a personal note, I am very surprised that the ACTU has not earlier sought to take on more seriously CRA's attack on collective bargaining rights at the various sites. I know that a lot of the people I have associated with in Western Australia have the view that perhaps this issue should have been tackled earlier. The government does not support the widening of the dispute and is concerned at the prospect of extensive industrial action affecting parties which are not associated with the actions taken by CRA.

It is an unfortunate situation we find ourselves in, but it is of CRA's making. It is seeking, as it has at other work sites, to buy out trade unionism to ensure that there is no role for trade unions or for collective bargaining among its employees. I would argue that that is clearly against the whole intention of the Industrial Relations Act. It is against the whole history of industrial relations practice in this country for over 100 years.

What it is seeking to do is to take us back to contract law, the sort of situation that we saw in the late 19th century and the situation that this parliament and all other state parliaments sought to overcome. Those parliaments recognised the unequal bargaining power of a single employee dealing with his employer and recognised the role of collective bodies, including those of employers and employees. For years the industrial relations system in this country, at both federal and state levels, has sought to encourage those associations and the collective process in terms of settling disputes and arranging working conditions.

The reason we have sought to talk about the Liberal Party's IR agenda in this dispute is that it is part of the wider debate that is going on in this country about industrial relations. We had a similar debate when during the last sitting the Liberal Party were very keen to talk about the second wave legislation in Western Australia. I note no such enthusiasm since they capitulated on that issue. Graham Keirath, the state minister, has not been very keen to talk about it at all for a few days.

We have an example of where the Liberal Party and Labor Party stand in industrial relations. The Labor Party does support collective bargaining, it does support rights for workers in seeking to collectively be represented and it does support the role of unions in society. What we see from the Liberal Party is a continuing attack on the role of trade unions and the continued rejection of workers rights to collective bargain. These attacks go to the whole basis of Australian society and the rights that we have traditionally recognised.

I want to make some more general comments about this whole question of individual contracts versus collective bargaining because we have had a lot of experience in Western Australia with individual contracts, particularly since the Workplace Agreements Act was introduced in that state. We have a situation where the sort of thing that CRA is attempting to do in Queensland is protected and institutionalised in Western Australia under that Workplace Agreements Act. We have very clear examples of what it means.

Briefly, people need to understand that these individual contracts can be used in two ways: firstly, they can be used by companies such as CRA to buy out trade unionism. They will essentially say, `We want trade unions out of the system. We don't want collective bargaining. We want to be able to deal with employees on a one-to-one basis and set the conditions. We will offer them a financial inducement to get them out of the union and out of the award system.' We have seen CRA offer quite large inducements on some occasions at a number of sites. At Weipa the company admitted to a $7,000 difference between those who work on a contract and those who work on the collective agreement. They buy out the union effectively by buying out the workers.

It is all very well to say that there is a choice, but the workers only choice is one of working for less and receiving fewer conditions. They also risk being discriminated against by the company for failing to sign the contract. If they are seeking employment, they may not be capable of being employed. So it is not right to say that there is choice. Clearly, when offered superior contracts, workers tend to accept them and they cannot be criticised for that. It is obviously very difficult for unions to try to work against this if a company is prepared to pay any price to put people onto contract.

The difference between what is occurring in Queensland and Western Australia in the federal or state systems is that at least in the federal system there is the no-disadvantage test and there is the protection of the award system. None of those protections apply in Western Australia under the state legislation, so there is no test to ensure that workers are not disadvantaged by those contracts. I concede from all I have heard about Weipa that the contracts are superior to the award conditions. That is what occurred at Hamersley in Western Australia as well. The company was prepared to buy out trade unions. They were prepared to buy the loyalty of workers and remove them from the collective process.

What needs to be understood is what happens to workers who have no collective bargaining rights and have no unions when the company comes to renegotiate contracts. We have already seen examples in Western Australia of workers on mining sites being forced to renegotiate their contracts when times have become tougher, when they are non-unionised and when they do not have any ability to collectively bargain.

The other side of this debate in Western Australia is what is happening to those employment areas where workers are not highly paid, where they are not highly skilled and where there is a shortage of labour. The other side of the coin is what is happening to workers in areas where people are looking for work in low paid and largely unskilled areas of the work force. Those areas are traditionally dominated by women and young workers. We are seeing the `sign on or no job' syndrome and the individual contract is very different. It is not one like at Weipa. The individual contract is typically one that makes the workers casuals and ensures that there is no overtime, no penalty rates and no annual leave. That is the other side of the coin.

On one side you have companies with a lot of money prepared to pay the price to get rid of unions from their companies. The other side of the coin, occurring in Western Australia under the Workplace Agreements Act, is where they say, `You have no bargaining power. You are low paid anyway. We can exploit you.'

What I have done in this place already, and am prepared to do further, is give examples of those contracts, examples of what is occurring in Western Australia, where workers have no collective bargaining power and the role of unions is restricted under the Workplace Agreements Act. Those people who are weak are getting ripped off completely. They are being put on to contracts to say that they will work any hours, they will not be entitled to annual leave, they will not be entitled to penalty payments and they will not be entitled to overtime.

I have here an assessment of an agreement for a 19-year-old employed as a general hand in a fast food restaurant. His hourly rate was cut from $10.27 as a casual under the award to $7.16 under the workplace agreement. In addition, these workers are required to work very demanding rosters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that is apparent about the dispute which is at the centre of the letter from Senator Parer is that the government could make a much greater effort to resolve this issue. I would contend that the first reactions of the government have been far too slow. In fact, an observer of this issue could be forgiven for thinking that it suited the government to allow this matter to escalate, thus forcing the symbolic, ritual fight that did not quite occur—the Western Australian dispute some weeks ago—but which both sides of this argument seem to be itching to get on with. It seems as if they are missing the glorious battles of the past.

PARA.TAB: I remember Senator Ray coming in here and talking about past demons being created and perpetuated by some of the language that was used. I am glad to say that at least we have seen some action here and the minister is taking some steps.

The government says that this dispute—we heard it from Senator Chris Evans just now—is of the making of CRA, and the coalition says that the unions are being unduly provocative. We hear accusations tossed from one side to the other. That is, as I say, part of this scaling up of a ritual performance which it seems some people are actually revelling in. That is not actually doing anybody any good.

Before I go any further, I might say that the question I asked in question time today was asked with the intention of finding out whether the government was actually interested in doing something about it. You might recall that I asked the minister to not regurgitate the debate about who started it and to try not to blame the unions, the contract workers or the company. I asked the minister to tell the ordinary Australians who might have to pay for this dispute what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was actually going to do about it.

The answer that I got was that he was very interested and that he was trying to conduct meetings and to facilitate a resolution. I was very pleased to hear that, because it was the first time that I had seen any evidence that anybody—whether it be the unions or the company—wanted to resolve it. I have subsequently found out that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has made certain decisions, only recently, about jurisdictional issues which clear the way for further hearings regarding the Weipa dispute.

That, to me, is what it is all about: to see a situation where both sides can have the opportunity—and they do, now that the Industrial Relations Commission has cleared the way—to seek a resolution through negotiation in that forum, which is the most appropriate one. This chamber is not the most appropriate forum. We just have repetition, trotting out the repetitive rhetoric and continually attempting to score political points—notching up a motion here and a motion there. The best thing we can do in this chamber is to support a process of resolution. Rather than emphasising the differences, entrenching the ideological differences and chucking hand grenades across those trenches, we would be serving Australia best if we supported the negotiation which is now possible in the Industrial Relations Commission.

The Industrial Relations Commission is the correct forum, not here. It is not in here that we will resolve the matter, unless we come out with a resolution that does not seek to score points against each other but seeks to resolve it. If anybody is interested in resolving the matter, they would see the sense of that and would not pursue the rhetorical challenges and the great puffing out of the chest that we see.

I find it rather boring and I am sure most of Australia does. We do not have a full gallery and we do not have people clamouring to see this debate. We have people saying, `Why does this have to happen? Why is it that this has to escalate and why is it that we, the rest of Australia, have to suffer?' Surely they pay us to come here to resolve these matters rather than to create them and emphasise them to serve our own political needs. I do not think we are well viewed if all we do is escalate these problems.

I am very pleased to note that there is a path that can be followed. That path is at the Industrial Relations Commission. In the wash-up of this whole business, the Australian Democrats do support the concept of collective bargaining. We think it is a crucial part of Australia's unique industrial history and a crucial part of our present Australian society and the way it works. But we note that enterprise bargaining can work, that it is working in many places in Australia. We also note that individual contracts can be very dangerous. The present industrial relations legislation does have faults, but we can work with it and we should be working with it. There are many enterprises across Australia that are working perfectly satisfactorily, and we should support them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could be few, if any, more important urgency motions before the Senate than the one we are now debating. I have only six minutes to speak in this debate, so I can do no more than highlight what seem to me to be the major considerations.

PARA.TAB: The first point I make is that the dispute at Weipa is all about the abuse of union power and the government's failure to utter a word of condemnation of the illegal actions that the ACTU and several unions have perpetrated. The company, Comalco, has acted totally lawfully and has followed all the legal provisions of the Keating government's own industrial relations act—all the steps proposed in the legislation for the conduct of enterprise bargaining. The overwhelming majority of the work force have welcomed the company's initiatives and signed individual contracts, which have resulted in more money for them and greater efficiency for the company—in other words, a classic win-win situation, which is what enterprise bargaining is, and should be, all about.

I understand that, out of a work force of around 700, no less than 635 employees have taken this course of action—signing the individual contract agreements—and only 71 have not. The ACTU and the other union bosses have objected violently. Why? For one reason only, and that is that they see this as a weakening of the power of a few elite union officials over the rank and file workers, despite the fact that the overwhelming majority of these workers have said to their unions that they and their families are more than happy with what the company has done and with what the parent company, CRA, has been progressively moving towards at its various operations over the past three years, with very successful results for both the company and its employees.

Let no-one be fooled about this matter. This dispute is not about terms and conditions of employment, unless you are saying that somehow or other we should be objecting to a deal which improves the terms and conditions of employment. Rather, it is about the naked overweening ambitions of a small bunch of union leaders and officials who have become drunk with power over many years, who are not prepared to face up to the changes that are going on around them and who are not prepared to be part of those changes because they fear their power will be eroded.

The ACTU Secretary, Bill Kelty, made this absolutely crystal clear last Monday in his address to the maritime unions, during which time he rabbleroused them to undertake a five-day national stoppage. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's actually a very simple issue: it's an issue about unions, about workers, about friendship, mateship.
He went on to say:
We can't afford to lose this battle. It's a battle we have fought for close on 200 years . . . To be beaten on this issue is to be beaten as a trade union movement.

As Senator Parer pointed out, his assistant secretary, Mr Pallas, has said that the ACTU and the union movement will `initiate a course of action of a magnitude and level that this country has never before seen'. That is a blatant call to union thuggery and blackmail. It is turning back the clock by decades to the old `them and us' attitude of the bygone era in which regrettably some of Australia's most powerful and power hungry union leaders still live.

PARA.TAB: The cruel tragedy for Australia is that the Keating government—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) and, to my regret, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray)—refuse to condemn the illegal union action. They refuse to condemn not only the 70 strikers at Weipa but also—this is even worse—the ensuing round of strikes and secondary boycotts, including the national waterfront strike that is in train, which is at a terrible cost to the economy and which is in total contravention of the government's own Industrial Relations Act and the rulings of the Industrial Relations Commission.

The strongest term that Mr Brereton can bring himself to use is `regrettable'. How weak, how pitiful and how supine can you get. How can a minister for industrial relations refuse to condemn in the strongest possible terms the unlawful actions of the trade union movement, action which is totally contrary to the provisions of the government's own legislation? The strike action that is happening at Weipa and around the nation is illegal in the terms of the government's own legislation. That point needs to be stressed time and time again.

My real condemnation today is of the government. This urgency motion is all about the government's abject failure to stand up for its own Industrial Relations Act, its abject failure to support its own Industrial Relations Commission and its failure to condemn its partner, the ACTU, for orchestrating a disastrous course of illegal strikes, including a five-day closure of the nation's ports, that will bring more hardship to Australian people already battered by one of the most incompetent governments in Australia's history. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing an urgency motion introduced by the opposition. I believe there is an urgency to tell the real story about industrial relations in this country. First of all, let us go back to the early 1980s when Mr Viner was a minister in the Fraser government. He addressed a meeting at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Australia. He outlined a plan to introduce a United States style industrial relations into this country. The United States system, under the slogan of `enterprise agreement', allows the might of capital to destroy trade unions and to use employers' central power and their tremendous resources to deny workers, particularly in isolated sites, the intelligence, the resources and the support of trade unions to represent them.

PARA.TAB: It also means in the United States the use of goons and standover merchants in industrial relations. Of course, Mr Viner was an embarrassment to Mr Fraser. He had to be transferred out of industrial relations very shortly after that speech because Mr Fraser was facing the 1983 election. The number of individual disputes was at record levels under the Fraser government. Senator Parer said he was embarrassed about our name at various times. We have to assess that Mr Fraser was a moderate when we look at the experience of Dr Hewson and Mr Howard as opposition leaders. The current Liberal Party supports every feral employer's attempt to smash the trade unions and destroy the system of conciliation and arbitration as we know it today. How often have employers in Australia introduced physical and emotional abuse. Liberal Party policies acquiesce to those same powerful interests.

Senator Short talked about union power. We all realise the significance of union power, which is based on the collective strength of a group of people against the enormous resources of employers. At this moment these employers are stretching and testing the current arbitration system with their massive financial and legal resources. Senator Parer talked about choice under those circumstances, when all that power is in the hands of giant organisations in this country. Of course, we know that if Mr Howard were to become the Prime Minister, the employers would have open slather.

Last night Senator Carr described the sorts of tactics being used by Australian Meat Holdings in Queensland. AMH have hired strikebreakers to harass and intimidate workers. These are professionals when it comes to intimidation and standover. Firms such as Troubleshooters Available have specialised in strikebreaking in Tasmania and Victoria. Who can forget Bruce Townsend and his thugs hired from interstate during the APPM dispute in Tasmania and their harassment and intimidation of workers?

During the meatworkers dispute in Camperdown, Victoria, in 1991-92, one Warwick Leeson appeared on the scene. His tactics included crude abuse and throwing rocks and eggs at picketers, and even driving his car at one of the picketers. Mr Leeson was hired by the law firm of Kroger and Kroger. Mr Kroger was President of the Victorian Branch of the Liberal Party and is a long time associate of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Costello. Warwick Leeson himself is a member of the Liberal Party. And Senator Parer talks about thuggery!

CRA's long association with the Liberal Party is no secret. I am showing the links between the employers who are launching these attacks, testing out the arbitration system and indicating Liberal policy of the future. At the time of the last federal election, CRA chief, John Ralph, was in the inner circle of advisers to the then Leader of the Opposition. He still has that link to the leadership of the Liberal Party. So when we look at the current strike—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be able to partake in this debate and to support the motion so ably moved by Senator Parer. It is in fact a sad day in Australia's political history, because today throughout the newspapers we have seen that Labor Minister Lawrence has been found to have been a liar. There is another Labor minister who rejoices in the name `Laurence', and that is Minister Brereton. I am not so sure that he is much better.

PARA.TAB: The government, through Minister Brereton, has failed to condemn the ACTU action, which is not so much about workers' benefits but about trade union power and relevancy. The simple fact is that those workers at Weipa under individual contracts are getting paid more than those who are under the old, stale award system negotiated by the trade unionists such as shown on the other side of this chamber. They are the ones who have negotiated the awards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Discrimination. They're not the same.

—Senator Collins says that it is discrimination. Why on earth should a worker be locked into a lower wage package because the trade union has failed to negotiate as good a package as workers as individuals can with their employer direct? You have a policy of keeping the workers on a low wage because of the incapacity of the trade union movement to be able to negotiate new innovative packages for workers. You are locked back into the 1930s and 1940s. You are still into the socialist mentality of `them and us', of the working class and the capital class. We have moved a long way since then, but you are still back in the 1940s and 1950s with your trade union mentality.

PARA.TAB: I still remember that, when I suggested the concept of enterprise bargaining in Tasmania, I was vilified by the Labor Party and the trade union movement. These were some of the allegations that were made against me: it would be the end of civilisation as we knew it; it would be slave labour; it would be reduced wages and reduced conditions. But what are we hearing today from Labor Senator Jacinta Collins? That this dispute is all about those workers under enterprise bargains and individual contracts being paid more than those under the awards. What I was accused of, of trying to get slave labour, is the exact opposite.

The workers are better off. That is why, out of a work force of 700 or so at Weipa, in excess of 600 have voluntarily and individually signed up on a contract, because they see the benefit of doing that, as opposed to sticking with an old, tired, negotiated award by trade union officials who usually are a lot more interested in getting Labor Party endorsement and getting into a parliament somewhere than looking after the real interests of their workers.

What we have is a situation where the trade union movement is losing its relevancy within this country. That is why thousands and thousands of workers are leaving the trade union movement. Senator Childs talks about standover tactics. Those of us who have experienced the sort of thuggery and standover tactics of the trade union movement say that your comments, Senator Childs, are very hollow. I recall working on the Dollar Sweets case in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Glad you acknowledge that.

—I have acknowledged that. A trade union official was convicted of assault because he would not let a fellow worker through. I remember interviewing immigrant workers who had received threatening phone calls from trade union officials, broken windscreens and broken windows in their flats because they had the audacity to exercise a choice—their choice—to work for an employer they found completely and utterly satisfactory.

PARA.TAB: If we want to talk about standover tactics and thuggery, let us talk to Peter Baldwin in the other place. If you want to talk about thuggery, what happened in the New South Wales Labor Party? The Labor Party are the masters of thuggery. What this party on this side of the House is on about is to give workers choice. If they want a stale old award, they can stick with it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen J.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than the wording in this matter of urgency, I think that Minister Brereton's comments on page 1 of this morning's Australian more accurately reflect the situation, contrary to the comments by Senator Abetz. Minister Brereton said that it is `unconscionable' that employees seeking to advance their industrial interests through collective bargaining should be penalised to the extent acknowledged by the company. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Government's view that the company should offer equivalent remuneration through collective bargaining to that presently on offer by them under staff contracts.

Yesterday, Senator O'Chee attempted to describe this dispute as an ACTU beat-up. He sought to explain away the dispute and said there was very little separating workers and management. The difference was, he said, simply a question of representation in negotiations. He is right, but it is no small issue. The key issues are representation and discrimination; that is, choose collective representation and miss out on over-awards.

PARA.TAB: Minister Brereton was also correct in emphasising this morning that this dispute exists despite the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, which the government continues to stand by, and despite the Industrial Relations Act—a principal object of which is helping to prevent and eliminate discrimination on the basis of, amongst other things, political opinion. Collective representation is a political opinion.

Rather than relying on Senator O'Chee's opinion expressed yesterday regarding the views of workers and shop stewards, I will draw upon a statement by a striking worker at Weipa—a statement amongst a few I should outline. Richie Ahmat, who has worked at Weipa for 23 years, has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I was offered an individual contract by my employer in February 1994 which would have delivered higher salary, extra airfares and other benefits to me. My employer advised me it would be in my best interest to take the contract or I would become like a dinosaur . . . . . . extinct.
I declined the offer because it meant giving up my rights to have union representation and to be able to bargain collectively.
Because of my experience and knowledge of the plant I'm regularly called upon to train new employees. These new employees at the outset earn thousands of dollars more than me!

TALK.START.PARA: —That's choice.

—A choice to be discriminated against. On a previous occasion when I participated in a debate on industrial relations, Senator Crane, who I understand will speak next, implied that the federal government was responsible for low minimum wage rates in Queensland. Let me reinforce our argument in this matter by adding to my comments on that previous occasion. There are cases where minimum rates in Queensland are lower than they should be, but the federal Industrial Relations Commission has acted to rectify such inequities on application.

PARA.TAB: For instance, my first arbitrated case in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, along with the minimum rates adjustment process, lifted the minimum rate for Queensland vehicles sales people from $324.60 to over $400 per week—an increase of over $80 per week. This occurred under the federal commission's wage fixing principles of the time, supported by the federal government, to remove anomalies and inequities. Once again, this emphasises that those opposite continue to run superficial arguments, where, upon closer examination, it is revealed that the circumstances prevail despite rather than because of federal government policy.

Senator Parer, in his opening comments in this debate, implied that this matter had nothing to do with federal coalition policy, but that policy encourages individual contracts. As Minister Brereton has pointed out, the act was not intended or designed to facilitate individual contracts. Contrary to the comments of both Senator Short and Senator Abetz, individual contracts are not synonymous with enterprise bargaining. You cannot say this can be achieved under individual contracts and imply it is a benefit of enterprise bargaining. This government supports enterprise bargaining with a safety net, and that safety net includes adequate collective representation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct something that Senator Jacinta Collins mentioned in her contribution to this debate. I never implied or suggested that the state minimum wage in Queensland was the responsibility of the federal government. I said that it was the responsibility of the Goss government, which is the state Labor government. I would just like to put that correction on the record.

PARA.TAB: It is ironical that we on this side of the chamber are supporting what, logically, one would have thought the government itself would have supported: that is, its own Industrial Relations Act and what has occurred under that. Secondly, I would have thought the government would have supported the institution that it has supported very strongly for as long as I can remember in industrial relations—that is, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—and its findings. In both instances, the government is failing to do so. I think that is really the crux of this debate.

In terms of what has occurred with the CRA operations, it has gone further in a legal sense than I initially thought it would. One has to question why at this particular time, after the Industrial Relations Reform Act has been in operation since December 1993, some 11,000 employees out of 16,000 from the CRA groups—from Gladstone, Bell Bay, Hamersley and elsewhere—have signed individual workplace contracts. There has not been a word out of this government, not a word from the ACTU and not a whimper from anyone else. Jennie George stands up on the steps of the Western Australian parliament and says, `We are going to take industry by industry down,' or words to that effect. We now find that after 1,635 employees at Weipa have signed individual contracts 74 have not done so, and all of a sudden it is the big No. 1 issue. What has occurred proves absolutely and categorically that this is a political exercise.

We have heard from the other side of the chamber consistently that their minimum standard in terms of negotiations from awards into certified agreements or enterprise agreements is a no disadvantage test. They are now saying, because individuals at Weipa have negotiated deals for themselves with significant differences in flexibilities which make them significantly better off, that the no disadvantage test is no longer good enough. Those other people have to have the same remuneration, regardless of what comes out of the agreement, as what those individuals have been able to negotiate. That is a classic double standard.

We know and the government knows that the no disadvantage test protects that particular position. Similarly, Senator Chris Evans knew very well when he made certain claims today regarding minimum conditions and holiday pay in Western Australia that he is absolutely and totally wrong. Because of the time limitations, I will deal with that issue at another time by tabling the minimum conditions which exist in Western Australia. It is absolutely, totally unbelievable and ironical that we have the government arguing against people in the workplace being able to get better conditions, more flexibility, more holiday pay, more leave, different arrangements for taking their leave and better wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better productivity.

—In return for productivity. I find that absolutely ironical and unbelievable. Senator Childs came in here today and based his arguments on some address that Ian Viner made when he was in government—one hell of a long time ago. Even Mr Brereton and people sitting on the other side of the chamber, like Senator Burns and Senator Sherry, have gone past the position which Mr Viner was at when he was a member of that particular parliament. That is really turning the clock back into the Dark Ages.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were a long time ago. The debate in this country and the position of the government has moved a long way past the position the Fraser government was in at that time. You know that. For Senator Childs to use that position as the basis of his argument is really quite amazing.

PARA.TAB: Another thing that Senator Chris Evans referred to in this debate today was sickness leave. I want to make it categorically clear for those listening to this debate that sickness leave is part of the Western Australian protection. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always spoken out strongly in support of the right of workers to collectively bargain. This is fundamental to any choice or leverage for workers in negotiations with management. My criticism of government has been that it has attempted to pursue labour reform which undermines collective bargaining as part of its New Right agenda while trying to care about workers. Its compromise solutions obviously have not and do not work.The issue is, and always has been, that reduction of the scope of collective bargaining—making unions smaller, removing the base of collective action by forcing `open shops' and making them less able to make links across industries—ultimately works against workers.

PARA.TAB: Some businesses have cooperative and democratic approaches to labour. Some businesses, however, see a return to the labour relations of the 1800s as an ideal to be sought. Workers could come cap in hand to bosses in hope of work and wages would let them put a few crusts on the family table. Ideally, a police force and army, backed by law and government, would put down workers in the event of the economic club rendering them numb enough or angry enough to resist. These businesses often use the fact that workers in Vietnam, China and Indonesia already live and work under such conditions to force similar conditions on the workers in developed countries in the name of `international competitiveness'.

Individual contracts are the cutting edge of the current push. The idea of individual contract is a legal embodiment of the isolated worker, cap in hand. CRA is pushing this line hard. It is using the vulnerability of workers by buying the less scrupulous, or more desperate, as essentially scabs to try to eliminate unions. This is union busting plain and simple and there is no guarantee that individual contract workers will continue to get paid significantly higher than union wages.

It is, or should be, quite illegal to discriminate against someone on the basis that they belong to a union, and of course that is exactly what the CRA is doing in offering workers tens of thousands of dollars more per year if they refuse to belong to a union or are refusing jobs to union members. That is what the individual contracts are designed for, to allow this sort of discrimination and other sorts of discrimination. Such contracts, however written, must violate no discrimination rules, and certainly the principle that similar work should attract similar wages and conditions. If workers performing similar work can have massive wage differences based on union status, they could equally be discriminated against individually on sexual or racial grounds.

The mask used by industry is that of choice. But the option of non-union workplaces, especially in remote areas, means management can use its power to eliminate the option of union workplaces. Choice applied to workers is driven by necessity. Most individuals have little economic power. Given the choice between hunger and exploitation, most people choose exploitation. Given the choice between hunger and abandoning unions, many workers would give up their power. Look around internationally and you will see the truth of this. If you think hunger is an extreme statement of unemployment, I remind the Senate that the coalition has suggested limiting unemployment benefits to a few weeks or months. The labour market is a biased market. This gives management a lot of power to determine the conditions of sale. This is the basis of the push for so-called choice. It is not freedom; it is coercion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted, I was concluding my contribution to the debate on the ANL Sale Bill, a bill to facilitate the sale of the Australian National Line. I have made my points fairly completely. There are reasons for continuing Australian government ownership of a national shipping line. There have been criticisms of this sale process. Those criticisms have been about how the sale has been conducted up to this point, but that is a side issue. The audit report has been quoted extensively so far in the debate. We have also had quoted extensively and very carefully evidence taken before the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee, which is about to table its report into the conduct of the sale tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: With the information we have before us, we were rightly able to criticise the sale process. I have already mentioned a number of other reasons why the Democrats would not be voting to support this sale bill. I simply conclude by saying that there were also reasons other than the problems with the process. There were reasons for the continued ownership of the shipping line by the Australian government. I conclude with those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ANL sale is of course a matter of great embarrassment to the government. It is something that the government planned to do and then the government planned not to do. In fact, the government planned not to do it because the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, said ANL could not be sold. What we see at the moment is a situation where the government does not know really whether it is Arthur or Martha. Certainly in terms of privatisation the government does not have the slightest clue what is on its agenda. That is the simple nub of the matter. The government is incapable of even ascertaining the real value of this company. That should be a cause for some concern.

PARA.TAB: If the Labor Party is going to run government business enterprises such as ANL, one would hope they are run for a purpose. One would also hope that those business enterprises are going to be run in such a way that the government knows at any point in time what is the value of those business enterprises. That is not the case at the moment. The ANL sale issue just shows that the government is incapable of running the privatisation process properly.

One only has to look at the absolute fiasco that we have had in other areas of government privatisations. Look, for example, at the fiasco the government created in relation to the Commonwealth Bank. That was another situation in which the government thought it was going to privatise. The government said it was going to limit the size of the float and then came back afterwards and said, `Forget what we told you. We are going to have a larger float than we anticipated; we are going to have another two tranches.' Labor cannot be relied upon to make its promises stick in privatisations of any business enterprises. I think that is the lesson that has to be learnt from this whole experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last we have come to the end of ANL. We all knew it was only a matter of time. It is very difficult for an enterprise to survive in the face of hostile ownership and management. I have no doubt the ANL Sale Bill will pass and ANL will be sold off. I know the opposition hates the idea of the people of an island continent owning a shipping line as much as the government does. They both hate the idea of the people owning anything through government aside from submarines or monuments.

PARA.TAB: This government has the gall to promote the idea of an Australian republic, citing national sovereignty as the rationale, at the same time as it donates our economic sovereignty to the international money market. It worships at the altar of free trade, which purports to promote competition but in fact delivers entire industries to a handful of giant international oligopolies. There are fewer, not more, players in world shipping, with a collection of smaller operators at the margin who survive by undercutting operational and safety standards. Most of the major operators also have second-string operations which utilise flag of convenience ships and poorly paid crews.

This chamber rejected the notion of a comprehensive liability regime to encourage a better standard of shipping. Who are we protecting? Before ANL—one of the remnants of Australian industry still publicly owned—gets sold, like Qantas, let us look at what we have done here. Ideology aside, the major argument for selling ANL is that it is a commercial disaster. Last year, just in case there is any doubt, the board was sacked and replaced by a board that would ensure that ANL showed up as a disaster.

The last annual report is revealing. It talks about a mandate from government, which apparently was that ANL should be prepared for sale. I remember that when the board was put in place it was a clear wish of the government to sell ANL, and it was delayed. My understanding was that technically, on the surface, the new board was to try to manage ANL to see whether it needed to be sold. When the board was announced, it was widely perceived as a con—a board which would beat up the books and assure that no-one would want to keep ANL; not a board that had any intention of managing ANL as a shipping line, since it had not had any expertise in this.

At the last committee hearing it was raised and noted that the cumulative losses were tripled by the board, primarily through provisions for restructuring. Where all earlier provisions for restructuring were efforts to restructure to make the enterprise more profitable, the provisions by the new board seemed to be restructuring to allow an easier sale.

When queried as to what this debt was about—this restructuring which seemed to strip over $100 million from the book value of the company—the explanation was that businesses can, under ordinary circumstances, hide debt and not include it in accounts. But when they are sold they should be included in the accounts. I do not know whether any other enterprise that had successfully covered up debt under normal business practice would drastically increase the debt on the books as an enticement to buyers, but it seems to me to raise some serious questions about accountability of government business enterprises and the general practice of government and accountability in relation to government business enterprises.

This brings us back to the management of the company by the Commonwealth. One of the central problems appears to have been a high level of indebtedness. ANL was allowed to have a high debt burden; hence a very high component of costs went to servicing loans. I have heard a number of stories from people in ANL about government promises of capitalisation, which led to commitments to overhaul or purchase ships. When the capital failed to materialise, ANL, and some shipbuilders expecting payment, I have heard, were left in an untenable situation.

This appears to be part of the problem—government, in relation to government business enterprises, seems to corporatise them in the belief that it will automatically make them profitable and try to operate them as though they were magic milch cows, extracting profits, refusing to commit capital and forcing them to unsustainable levels of debt. The shipping industry as a whole has generally suffered economically in the last several years. It is always important when businesses operate on the margins to reduce debt levels wherever possible. This was not done.

Some may claim that this would simply transfer debt to the state, but I have argued on a number of occasions that a major problem of government is a shortfall of revenue. It is not addressed by shifting debt to government business enterprises or allowing government business enterprises to build up unsustainable debt levels in order to keep the book debt of the Commonwealth hidden. Nor, incidentally, is it addressed by selling assets and then leasing them back—something that is generally financially stupid, even in the medium term.

Fundamentally, why can the Commonwealth not run a shipping line as easily as P&O can? I do not think there is actually any reason. There is some mad belief that governments are inherently unable to participate in industry, although they are supposed to be able to operate national economies just fine. The contradiction in this attitude becomes very clear when such an argument is used to privatise something like a power company and the wonderful competitive bidder that is brought in is a foreign government government business enterprise. Obviously the only thing that stops a government business enterprise from being fully competitive is that it does not bid for businesses in other countries.

Are there any other underlying reasons that ANL should not be successful, aside from owner hostility, an attitude towards company finances typical of Bond or Elliott and an ideological belief that what is occurring is heresy? Is there something about Australia or ANL that makes it inherently impossible to operate a shipping line as a profitable business?

There are a few basic issues. We are competing with companies which hire labour at a very low cost and impose exploitative conditions on seafarers. There have been reports in the news of seafarers who feel like prisoners, unable to get off and who feel that life is literally at risk. They make their complaints public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: My intention was drawn to comments made by the Australian Workers Union delegate, Mr John Maitland, in his address, which is at appendix 4, in which he talks about societies divided into haves and have-nots. One of the intentions of the government in creating award superannuation was to ensure that that did not occur. That is why many award superannuation policies contain provisions for life insurance as well because, obviously, it is a concern to every worker that they could die before what we consider to be the normal time and their widow or children would be left without anybody to provide for them. I think it is a laudable intention that such policies do have life insurance provisions.

PARA.TAB: What I want to lay before the Senate tonight is a case where a fund is seeking to deny those life insurance benefits to the next of kin of a member of one of those funds who died an untimely death. I think everybody should be shocked to hear the case of the late Bryce Robert Rodgers, who was a member of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union and was also a member of the Building Union Superannuation Scheme, Queensland, called BUSSQ.

The facts of Mr Rodgers's case are simply this: Mr Rodgers started work with a company in Queensland called Marlin Consultants Pty Ltd on 14 March 1995. He was a member of the Building Union Superannuation Scheme and his national membership number was 2408028. Unfortunately, Mr Rodgers was killed in a car accident on 1 April this year, about two weeks after having joined the scheme. On 14 March his contribution was forwarded by his employer to Jacques Martin Industry, which is the administrator of the fund, together with the premium paid up from March. The only problem was that the form was not signed by Mr Rodgers. The employer, in remitting the form, did not get Mr Rodgers to sign it. Notwithstanding that, the fund accepted Mr Rodgers as a member. It accepted the money, made no attempt to return the money and made no complaint.

Mr Rodgers was then, unfortunately, killed in a car accident. Since that period Mr Rodgers's de facto and their three children have been without support. They have tried, without success, to have their entitlements under the life insurance component of that scheme paid to them. Time after time they were told either that Mr Rodgers was not a member of the fund or that the matter was still being considered.

We have now seen a period of some six or seven months elapse and it is thoroughly unacceptable that this woman and her children should be in this situation. There is a young family that needs the benefits that were supposed to be provided under this superannuation scheme. I think the manner in which Mr Rodgers's de facto has been treated by Jacques Martin is absolutely disgraceful.

It is not acceptable that they are continually putting off—day after day, week after week. I spoke to Mr Rodgers's mother a couple of weeks ago and she was absolutely distraught, as well she might be. I find it disgraceful.

The essential point is this: Mr Rodgers had an equitable interest in that fund. The fact that he had not signed a form was not his fault. The fund had accepted his money and had accepted him for membership. Of course, he and his de facto were entitled to all of the benefits of the scheme.

Now, the matter is one which the trustees will have to decide upon. Otherwise, it will have to go to court. But I would hope that these people would recognise that there is an equitable interest. I do not believe that Mr Rodgers's de facto should be forced to go to court to fight for these things. I would have thought that decency and good commercial judgment on the part of the administrator would mean that they would accept their obligation and ensure that the widow is paid out. I do not think it is acceptable at all that this situation should continue and I would think that anybody who has any dealings with these people would be disgusted. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator Abetz) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The horticultural industry, as Senator Collins well knows, is going through a very tough time at the moment. That is as a result, in part, of the infestation of papaya fruit fly. I think it is appropriate to take this opportunity to outline to the Senate the sorts of concerns growers in Far North Queensland have had as a result of the infestation. We discussed some of the matters in the Senate estimates committee the other night, but we did not discuss all of them and I think it is not inappropriate to raise the matters here again.

PARA.TAB: The first matter is that, as a result of this infestation, markets which were previously open to growers have become closed. The markets are closed to all growers at the moment, irrespective of whether they are in the infested area or not. I think particularly of the market for mangoes in Japan, which was closed by Japanese authorities as a result of the infestation. It is not only growers on the Atherton Tableland that have been affected; growers further south, in Bowen and elsewhere, have also found that the market has been closed.

The minister said at the estimates committee hearing the other night—I have no reason to not take him at his word—that efforts are being made to ensure that this situation can be rectified and that we can get some expedient entry into Japan again for our product. What concerns me is that it may not happen this season.

It is to do with the way in which mangoes are grown. You have different varieties and some come off earlier and some come off later. Of course, it is for our benefit that that happens. Consumers get the benefit of a longer season and the growers get the opportunity to sell into a market for a longer period of time with less competition amongst themselves and, therefore, better prices. The problem is that the late varieties have not had certification for vapour heat treatment protocols, as has the earlier variety of Kensington Pride. The consequence is going to be that if we get acceptance into the Japanese market it may be only the late mangoes that could possibly be exported and, of course, they are not eligible for export because there is no protocol in place for the vapour heat treatment of those mangoes.

One of the other problems relates to other fruit and vegetable growers on the Atherton Tableland and the problems they suffered. For example, when the infestation was first discovered, the pumpkins were coming off. The growers of pumpkins found that they had a grave problem in so much as other states were refusing to accept the pumpkin. There were controls placed on the movement of those pumpkins out of the Atherton Tableland to markets further south because there was a concern that the pumpkins could be a possible vector for the movement of papaya fruit fly. I understand that that is not possibly the case, but I understand that in the interim there has been enormous loss suffered by growers. Basically, the benefits of the season for those people have been lost altogether. I think that is very sad.

What is also sad is that the ongoing protocols are such that much of the fruit currently has to be moved in refrigerated wagons. Refrigerated movement is much more expensive than other types of movement. The problem relates to the refrigeration of the fruit after it has been chemically treated. If this situation occurs, there is major loss in terms of profitability because the higher transport cost comes out of the money that the grower receives.

I believe this is a matter that must be urgently rectified. The joint working committee of state departments and the federal department must rectify this situation as soon as possible. Protocols must be put in place so that growers can get their crops to market as quickly as possible. If that happens, we can minimise some of the damage that is being suffered at the moment.
This has been a major disaster for Far North Queensland growers and I hope that every effort is made by all concerned to ensure that the damage, the loss and the injury is limited as far as possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to quickly respond to what Senator O'Chee has had to say. As Senator O'Chee has mentioned, there has been a great deal of effort by officers of my department and the Queensland Department of Primary Industry to deal with the problem on the ground in respect of eradication and also to ensure that the difficulty for the markets is as short-lived as possible. The immediate effort that is going into that is that areas of freedom are being established in other cropping areas by laying out, on grid patterns, traps that will satisfy our trading partners that those particular areas are free of this pest.

PARA.TAB: I want to conclude by quickly referring to the concern that Senator O'Chee has raised in respect of the late varieties of mangoes other than Kensington Pride. I simply want to confirm what I told Senator O'Chee in the estimates committee hearing. Senator O'Chee drew my attention to correspondence which had been sent to him—and, as I understand it, has subsequently been forwarded to me—by growers in the area asking for consideration to be given to the research required for establishing protocols with the late varieties of mangoes other than Kensington Pride. I stress that this submission was made not in respect of the papaya fruit fly but in respect of treatment that is already required in Queensland for the endemic Queensland fruit fly, which was done only in respect of Kensington Pride.

The position that Senator O'Chee put to me at the estimates committee hearing, which I said I considered was sensible, was that, in respect of the protocols that now have to be established to satisfy Japan and other trading partners, the protocols required for dealing with the endemic Queensland fruit fly that are already in place will also deal with the papaya fruit fly and, sensibly, should also involve the later varieties.

As I said at the Senate estimates hearing—and I am happy to repeat it here—that suggestion makes sense to me. Not being a technical expert and not having yet been able to get a response from the technical experts, as I said in the estimates hearing, the only caveat I wish to put on that is if there is a massive technical problem that would prevent it. If there is not, I think it makes enormous sense for that to be done so that the protocols for all of these varieties of mangoes—both early and late—can be developed at the same time.
I gave the Senate estimates committee a commitment, which I repeat here in response to Senator O'Chee, that, as far as I am concerned as minister, I will ensure that that is done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great problems for Australian society is the fact that our community is ageing very rapidly.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not how the people who are ageing see it.

—I hope that everybody is ageing gracefully. The community is ageing very rapidly because, quite simply, people are living longer and, hopefully, people are living much more fulfilling lives as well. One of the difficulties is that there are some people who, for various reasons, find themselves incapable of living in their own home. As a consequence, more and more people are finding themselves in nursing homes.

PARA.TAB: I point out that the nursing home industry has grown up as a consequence of this occurrence. People can make judgments as to whether it is good or bad that larger numbers of elderly people are now living in nursing homes. There are people who would say, `This is dreadful. It's a demise of society. Children are no longer paying attention to the best interests of their parents.' But, at the same time, it is interesting to note that people in traditional communities which have generally looked after their parents are also moving into nursing homes. For example, many of our ethnic communities are setting up their own ethnic community nursing homes. It is probably not an indication that society is falling apart; rather, it is an indication that there are pressures on families that make it more difficult for some people to live with their children. Also, some of the needs of these elderly people are such that they cannot be cared for at home. Of course, when people live longer, they are more likely to have health complications which make it necessary for them to have some proper care. That is why people are going into nursing homes and hostels.

As I said, this industry has grown up and it is being advertised very heavily. So it is important that proper standards do exist for people who find themselves in nursing homes. How one does that is another matter. Obviously, the published nursing home and hostel standards monitoring statements are produced by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). One of the things that we should always remember is that the nursing home or hostel environment should be as human as possible. We do not want a situation where people find themselves in these institutions and feel that they are not a fully valued member of society. That creates a situation of despondency, a situation of despair. It is something that we can really do without. It is also a dreadful way for people to live. That is something that has to be taken into consideration.

The other thing that needs to be taken into consideration is that we need to create opportunities for people to get care in some other way and avoid going into nursing homes. For example, we need to be much more creative in our responses to the provision of health services to elderly people. At the moment, there is very little difference for people who need ongoing medical care between going to a doctor and going into a nursing home. It is increasingly difficult to get home nurses. One of the suggestions that was made to me recently when I was on the Tweed Coast was that we could set up a sort of one-stop shop where people could come and get medical care—it may not be the sort of medical care for which one would require a doctor; it may be the sort of medical care that could be provided by a registered nurse—and advice from a nutritionist and so on. It would offer people an opportunity to get all of those services. It would not have to be a fully functioning centre. It could operate for only part of the day.

Those are the sorts of creative solutions which offer people who are currently going into nursing homes because they need a little bit more care because they cannot afford to go to the doctor all the time a viable alternative to a nursing home. Whatever it is, the standard of care that we provide for elderly people in our community must be of the very highest standard possible. We need to be as flexible as possible in the sorts of solutions that we provide to these people so that they have dignified and fulfilling lives. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

I think it is appropriate to put on the record Senator Patterson's commitment to the elderly in our community, for her benefit, so that she has the opportunity to address this matter, hopefully when she returns to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
