SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of some concern to me that the Australian Workers Union, and in particular Mr Ludwig, are able to spend amounts of money on legal fees and internal battles but do not have, apparently, any money to look after their members when their members' interests are not only at risk but also have been severely attacked by unreasonable employers. The unreasonable employer I have in mind is a well-known piggery and the men involved are people who were dismissed. I have to say they were dismissed after the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, ceased being a half-owner of the piggery. They were dismissed in June and his interest was acquired by Indonesian interests in March. These men were wrongfully dismissed after they protested that for the previous two years they had been paid less than the award rates by a piggery half-owned by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I have a letter from one of these men, who, I must say, I did help when they came to see me as a result of approaching the Tamworth office of one of my colleagues. It is quite a sad story because these people who were wrongly dismissed—and there is no doubt about that—in June 1994 are still to receive any recompense. In fact, one of them is still out of work and receiving unemployment benefit. It is very difficult in a country town, particularly after a rural recession, to get jobs. I would like to read bits of the letter written by Mr Ken Purdue of Moonbi that was sent to a few people. It goes like this:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out that we are not after a quick buck. We three blokes have put twenty-two years between us into our jobs, we did our jobs well and cared for the livestock we looked after, one of us was a leading hand.
As I said, these are the people who got sacked because they complained about getting underaward wages while employed by the Prime Minister's half-owned piggery. The letter continues:
It appears our big blunder was that we had the audacity to ask about the under payment of wages which had been occurring for years.
The result of this is that we three were sacked and I have listed the sequence of events that have occurred since.

On 30th June, 1994, after five years of employment with the Brown & Hatton Group Piggery, which was half owned by Mr. Paul Keating (the Prime Minister) and half by Mr. Al Constantinidis, I and two other employees were sacked on the spot with no money or entitlements being paid to us until a week later.

I note that Mr Al Constantinidis was Mr Keating's partner and was the person through whom Mr Keating disposed of his half-interest to Indonesian interests. I must say that Mr Constantinidis is subject to summonses at present from the Australian Securities Commission and has received numerous penalties for failing to meet the requirements of the Corporations Law, but he was Mr Keating's partner.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating trusted him enough and he had enough confidence in him to have Mr Constantinidis look after Mr Keating's interest entirely. Whenever I raised problems about the improper behaviour of Mr Constantinidis, Mr Keating consistently said that he had nothing to do with running the companies. In other words, he was quite content to have his companies run by a man who was continually breaching the law. At no stage has Mr Keating ever publicly stated that he wanted to dissociate himself from the activities of this man. He has been repeatedly challenged to do so in this chamber and he has never done so. Mr Purdue goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: As I stated above simply because we had made enquiries about under-award payments to the Dept. of Industrial Relations. A few weeks later we found out our superannuation contributions had gone missing on the day of our dismissal. We contacted the union, the A.W.U.F.I.M.E., who said we were unlawfully dismissed.
To fight our case the union hired McClellands as our solicitors with Greg Keating, the Prime Minister's brother, to be our representative.

I should interpose that Mr Greg Keating did eventually recognise the potential conflict of interest involved and recommended that another member of the firm look after the men. I might say that the advice they gave was grossly inadequate, massively to the men's disadvantage and quite disgraceful. The letter goes on to say:
They—
the union—
sent us to the wrong address for conciliation meetings with company and Industrial Relations Court and failed to meet us at places and times they had organised.

On 22nd November, 1995, a Conciliation Meeting with the Union, Al Constantinidis, the Conciliation Commissioner and us was held. The union advised us to accept a pittance of our entitlements e.g. five weeks pay.

The required amount for wrongful dismissal, if it is established, is up to 26 weeks pay. The union recommended for a variety of reasons that they take five weeks pay—one reason of course being that it would cost the union something like $30,000 to pursue the case and the union said that it did not have any money. The letter continues:
9th December . . . I contacted the Commissioner and asked when we would be payed, he told me to back off and leave it alone.
Basically, as I understand it, that was because he said that the company probably would not have any money. It continues:
I was dissatisfied with proceedings thus far so I reopened the case.

It was because of the treatment we had received up to this time that I decided to contact Senator Michael Baume in the hope he may be able to help, as by now the case was growing out of all proportion. If it was not for the Senator we would still be banging our heads against a brick wall.

I in fact did introduce these people to a solicitor who I thought may be able to help them on a pro bono basis, because they had no money. In fact that is what happened. As a result of my doing that, in the Senate estimates hearing on 6 November Senator Bolkus accused me of probably being a reason for this matter dragging on and these men getting nothing. When I had asked why this case had dragged on—I was asking questions in estimates to the Industrial Relations Court, Attorney-General's Department—Senator Bolkus interrupted, `Because of your involvement.' I am not involved in the case. I simply referred these workers, who had been robbed by the Prime Minister's half-owned piggery company, to a solicitor who has looked after them, as I understand it, on a pro bono basis. It goes on:
I have all the facts and legal papers, court records and affidavits.

We have now been fighting for eighteen months for justice and believe we have a right to our day in court. We are just three ordinary Australian blokes and we have discovered that we apparently have no rights when we try to get justice from a BIG COMPANY.
It has now got to the point where the PRINCIPLE of being declared legally UNJUSTLY DISMISSED is more important than the dollars.

And they have no dollars. But it is interesting to note that the Australian Workers Union apparently has dollars, because here we have William Ludwig taking action against Stephen Harrison, Christopher Hayes and a whole series of people on 25 October in the Industrial Relations Court of Australia. In a statement of claim—Mr C. A. Sciacca and Associates are the solicitors—Mr Ludwig says:

As at the date of filing this statement of claim no balance sheets for the financial year ended 30 June 1993 or 30 June 1994 have been provided by the Branches of the former FIME to Branch Committees of Management of those branches nor to the National executive of the AWU.

This union has plenty of money to fight legal battles for itself and to get involved in a whole lot of things but does not, frankly, have the interest or the determination to back workers who are involved in a dispute with the Prime Minister's former piggery company. I believe that is an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I want to address tonight relates to a matter I raised in the Senate in the evening of 1 March this year. On that evening I read into the record a letter from Pastor Hasoloan Tambunan at Galang Island in Indonesia. The letter I read into the record was addressed to Deaconess D.E. Fletcher, Administrator, SEAAC Inc., 4 Troks Court, Glen Waverley, Victoria 3150.Without reading all of the letter into the record again, because it is already on the record, the letter essentially asked Deaconess Fletcher and the SEAAC organisation in Melbourne not to send any more letters of sponsorship to people who were screened out of the refugee process at Galang Island in Indonesia.

PARA.TAB: As I very briefly explained to the Senate on that evening, I had earlier in the year visited for the second time Galang Island in Indonesia and had witnessed the distress that some people on the island had suffered because false hope was being given to individuals on the island—boat people who had fled Vietnam and Cambodia, who had been screened out as refugees and who were awaiting resettlement or repatriation to their homelands but were refusing to voluntarily return.

The people on the island who raised this matter with me and with officials who accompanied me from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta were equally upset with the strength of feeling that people had expressed to us during our visit to the island. I undertook at that time that, when I came back to Australia, I would see what I could do to stop the messages of false hope being given to individuals in the camp from people in Australia. I figured that the best way of doing that was to put some facts on the record by reading the letter into the record from the vicar on the island who was expressing his own feelings to the organisation.

It turned out that the letter that I read into the record was never received by Deaconess Fletcher. When I sent her a copy of my speech it caused her some upset to not have received a letter which ostensibly was addressed to her. I think it was never received because the organisation's address is 4 Tricks Court, Glen Waverley and the pastor's letter was addressed to `4 Troks Court'. It never reached her, and it would appear that the SEAAC organisation, Deaconess Fletcher, others involved in the organisation in Melbourne and indeed, and more importantly, the 3,000 or so people on the island were the subject of a great degree of trickery.

Perhaps another letter that I want to read into the record tonight will explain where that trickery comes from. This is a letter that Deaconess Fletcher has supplied to me. I will not read into the record the names of the people to whom the letter is addressed because I do not have their permission to do so, but it is there for people to see if they want to. If there is any need for clarification afterwards, I will seek the agreement of those people to read their names into the record at a later time. After the salutation the letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: In reply to your letter dated 16th February, and further to our telephone conversation following receipt of same, we would first of all apologise for our slowness in responding to your request for information.
This has been due to circumstances beyond our control.

We are concerned and saddened at the plight of so many thousands of refugees who have remained in camps for long periods of time. However, the fact is that it is quite beyond the capacity of the South East Asian Assistance Com. to undertake sponsorships for more than we are already committed to help.

This particularly refers to those who are presently at Galang Camp, Indonesia. We have received more than 2,000 letters to date from those seeking sponsorships. The three hundred sponsorships which have been lodged with the Department Immigration are the absolute capacity which we can cope with.

False hope is being given by tricksters within Galang Camp. This is not only causing much heart break among the refugees themselves, but is also causing us to have to cope with such a work load that great strain is being placed upon workers and office staff.

We have been advised by an officer of the Department Immigration that further lodgement of any sponsorships from Galang would only jeopardize the possible acceptance of those who we have already named for possible acceptance and resettlement assistance.

We appreciate your readiness to convey this information to contacts at Galang Camp, and hasten to assure you that S.E.A.A.C. has a record second to none, in the program which has been maintained since the beginning of 1976. Many refugees have been successfully resettled, and close friendships have been forged through these years. We have done our best to assist many hundreds who have come under our care as they have come to Australia.
Please be assured of our readiness to be of help in any way possible. However, the present demands are quite unreasonable.
Thankyou for your assistance . . .
That was raised in regard to a letter which was sent to SEAAC from the other organisation, which I have not got permission to name. That letter went on:
Dear Deaconess,

Recently there have been rumours in Galang refugee camp, Indonesia that your organisation is going to sponsor 1000 asylum seekers to be resettled in Australia. There are already people going around in the camp selling application forms and making profits.
We would like to ask you to clarify the matter so we can explain to asylum seekers there in order to stop them from harbouring false hopes.
Thank you very much for your help.

It is unfortunate that it has now taken until November for me to come into the chamber and read this into the record and perhaps correct the impression that I may have incorrectly given—the impression that the South-East Asian Assistance Committee was in any way encouraging the trickery, the fraud or the bewilderment of the individuals that I met in Galang in January.

PARA.TAB: The reason for taking so long is that Deaconess Fletcher only last week supplied me with the correspondence that I read into the record. I did offer quite early in the piece to correct any incorrect statements that I had made. I hope that my reading into the record tonight the details of the letters—the letter to SEAAC in response to the letter from the organisation which I will not name at this point—will correct any bad impression I gave that Deaconess Fletcher or her organisation had not been doing the right thing on behalf of those unfortunate individuals at Galang Camp in Indonesia. I will forward the proof Hansard to them tomorrow and, hopefully, that will be the end of the matter.

I would just like to divert and say that when I was in Galang Island in January I had hoped that, come December of this year, that camp would be closed down under the terms of the comprehensive plan of action which was agreed to by the major nations involved in the resettlement of Vietnamese boat people. Unfortunately, it does not appear that that will happen. It certainly will not happen from Hong Kong, where many thousands of people vegetate in circumstances that human beings should not be subjected to.

The reason for that of course is that there is legislation before the parliament in the United States which I most sincerely believe is giving false hope to those people who are living in less than preferable circumstances. They have fled their country, some of them for genuine reasons. Some of them were screened in as refugees and have been resettled in places like Australia. We can be very proud in this country for what we have done for those unfortunate refugees who have had to flee their home country.

There are others who took advantage of the boats leaving Vietnam who wanted to improve their economic circumstances but unfortunately were not deemed to be refugees and not deemed to be valid for resettlement. They choose to vegetate in camps such as Galang Island. It is unfortunate they choose to do so. It is even more unfortunate that the people in the United States should be encouraging them by seeking to put the legislation through the Congress, which of course will be vetoed at a later time.

The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: SENATOR NOEL CRICHTON-BROWNE

INTERJECT.PARA: APPEAL AGAINST EXPULSION FROM THE
LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA WA DIVISION (INC)
SUMMARY
This document is meant to be neither exhaustive nor definitive but its purpose is rather to highlight both contemporary and historic facts. In order to argue the following:-
1.That all the grounds of the State Executive are contrived, concocted and trivial.
2. Two grounds are covered by privilege.

3.One ground is the product of the malicious leaking of a private conversation by a destructive and disloyal liberal party member to a member of the media whom they knew would be receptive to such mischievous gossip.
4. One ground is factually incorrect.
The motion does not justify expulsion, suspension or censure, but is rather intended to justify a predetermined view of the State President for what ever his motives that I should be expelled.

No such ground has ever been ventured in respect to any member of the Liberal Party in Western Australia, never mind a senior Federal Senator, a past State President and a life member of State Council.
The State Executive motion asking me to resign gave no ground, justification or reason.

I was refused a right to attend that State Executive and to be heard. The resignation resolution by the State President to State Executive was based on different grounds to the expulsion motion. No grounds could or did justify the resignation motion. The expulsion motion was moved because quite naturally I would not simply bend to the misinformed, improper and biased call to resign.

The Presidents motives in moving the resignation and expulsion motions had nothing to do with the grounds, but were in part, the result of a deal he entered into with a small but threatening group of organisational and parliamentary members. Euphemistically called, on some occasions, "the peace plan".
The State President has deliberately ignored the debilitating, disruptive and destructive conduct and comments of a number of party members including senior office bearers and Members of Parliament.
One ground relates to the improper obtaining of private information and its improper distribution.

In respect to the restraining order, subsequent to its public disclosure, both the State President and the Premier have condemned its publication and stated frequently it should not and does not impinge upon my role or contribution as a Liberal Senator and both subsequently offered me publicly their full support.
Market research shows that the matter has had no impact whatsoever on voter intentions.

The action undertaken in respect to me is a gulf of difference between that of other contemporary Members of Parliament and the historic response to grave conduct by organisational and Parliamentary members.
The grounds contrived against me bear absolutely no comparison with examples which I have given.
The process undertaken by State Executive was based on an adversarial nature rather than one of ensuring proper and full opportunities for the matter to dealt with in a fair and conciliatory way.

My counsel and myself were invited to attend the State Executive, present our case and to answer a number of questions, but we were not entitled to ask questions, we were not able to rebut assertions made against me and nor were we able to rebut comments made in respect to our submission.

The public and private statements by the State President and other State Executive members prior to the State Executive meeting should have led to the disqualification of those from the hearing. However not withstanding a request from Malcolm McCusker QC that they disqualify themselves, they refused and participated in the deliberations.
1. RESTRAINING ORDER
The clauses of the State Executive resolution headed RESTRAINING ORDER AND PARTY LEADER are in breach of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which codifies article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1688[9].

The immunity of parliamentary proceedings from impeachment or question in courts or other tribunals depends ultimately on article 9 of the Bill of Rights of 1688 [9], which is part of the law applying to the Australian Houses by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution.
Article 9 provided that "the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of Parliament".

Section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 codifies the interpretation of article 9 in its application to the Australian Houses. The section provides that evidence of parliamentary proceedings cannot be used in any court or tribunal in any way contrary to article 9 or the section. The prohibited use of evidence of parliamentary proceedings is defined to include any use of those proceedings against any person in a wide sense.

While the Act provides a wide definition of "impeached or questioned", it does not exhaust the meaning of that phrase, and the definition of "tribunal" does not exhaust the category of bodies before which parliamentary proceedings must not be impeached or questioned. This is because section 16 provides that article 9 has the effect of the provisions of the section "in addition to any other operation".

The question is determined by the nature of the body, to its proceedings and of the detriment imposed on the member. The court would distinguish between mere withdrawal of political support, which obviously would not be unlawful, from anything in the nature of a penalty imposed on the member.
It should be noted that some procedures by which political parties impose Party discipline on their members may well be unlawful when imposed because of the members' activities in Parliament.
I draw your attention also to paragraphs (1), (2), and (4) of Resolution 6 of the Senate Privilege Resolutions setting out activities which may be treated as contempts:-
6.Matters constituting contempts
(1)A person shall not improperly interfere with the free exercise by the Senate or a committee of its authority, or with the free performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Improper influence of Senators

INTERJECT.PARA: (2)A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence a Senator in the Senator's conduct as a Senator or induce a Senator to be absent from the Senate or a committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Molestation of Senators

INTERJECT.PARA: (4)A person shall not inflict any punishment, penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, a Senator on account of the Senator's conduct as a Senator.

This precludes most methods of Party discipline. I also draw your attention to Clause 16 ss3 (a) (b) (c) under section 7 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 (Cth). With regard to individuals, section 7 provides for maximum penalties of six months imprisonment (ss1) or a fine up to $5,000 (ss 5 (a)). Under this section corporations are subject to maximum fines of $25,000. (ss 5 (b)). It does not matter if the organisation is incorporated under Commonwealth or State legislation.

Clearly the Senate resolutions and the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 preclude items 1 & 2 of the resolution and therefore State Council will be in breach of these provisions if it considers them as grounds to support the resolution.

My view is confirmed by Harry Evans, Clerk of the Senate, considered internationally as the ultimate authority on matters of privilege. His opinion is supported and confirmed by the Hon Clive Griffiths MLC, President of the Legislative Council in Western Australia who is also acknowledged as a distinguished authority on privilege. Mr Griffiths is the longest serving Presiding Officer in the Commonwealth.
However for the purposes of further deliberations I set out the facts.

At the height of the controversy over allegations of the restraining order I engaged RM Quantum, the Liberal Party's pollsters, to research the effect of the allegations and disclosures upon the voters.
23% of the voters approved of the public disclosure of my private affairs.
65% were opposed to the disclosure.
89% said they would not change their vote as a result of the disclosure.
3% said they would.
Mr Camakaris, the Principal of RM Quantum, expressed the firmest view that the 3% would dissipate.

His strongest view is that the 3% will totally dissipate in the course of a campaign and at the election. He makes the obvious and sensible point that electors vote for self interest and that usually manifests itself in economic circumstances and the leader most likely to achieve those objectives. People vote for themselves, not against others.

In respect to the Senate, the voting is now almost totally above the line and personal voting is inconsequential. In other words Mr Camakaris' advice is that the matter of the publication of my alleged private life has absolutely no impact upon people's voting patterns.
Further matters referring to the restraining order are outlined below:

On the morning of Friday 24 March, the day before my preselection, Esther rang Mr Viner to tell him she was aware that he had and was disclosing a private conversation between he as a lawyer and she who had sought his advice. His initial preoccupation was to quiz Esther about who had told her of his disclosures.

She asked the pertinent question, "Have you betrayed me?" He said in response "No, I have not betrayed you." Esther made it abundantly clear that she would be very upset and considered it a breach of lawyer confidentiality if he so disclosed matters discussed between them.

Esther of course approached Mr Viner because she knew him to be a lawyer, a Liberal, and someone she had known for a considerable time. She assumed she could trust him, believing that if he was hostile to me he would never hurt her or our children, all of whom he knew well.

That same day within hours of that conversation Mr Viner proceeded to visit the Court of Petty Sessions, requesting the restraining order which of course had never been served, and therefore not enforced. Mr Viner was attended to by a Mr Titelius, a clerk of the Court.
Mr Titelius, for his part, had been a member of the Wembley Downs branch of the Liberal Party who defected to join Liz Constable's campaign.

Notwithstanding instructions on and in the file, of which Mr Titelius was well aware, saying that information from the file was not to be made available, Mr Viner was given a copy of the restraining order by Mr Titelius. Mr Titelius had some hours earlier, refused a similar request from Mr Andrew Gaspar who is an employee of Mr Eoin Cameron, the Federal Liberal Member for Stirling because he was not an interested party within the meaning of the Justices Act. I understand Mr Viner made no claim within the definition and applied for the order on the same basis as Mr Gaspar.

Mr Titelius left the file on the counter while he photocopied the restraining order. The time the file was left on the counter, either accidentally or by design was sufficient for Mr Viner to rummage through the file and make further hand written notes. Mr Viner most certainly must have seen the clear instructions on and in the file that he was not entitled to the restraining order or the notes he surreptitiously acquired.

Shortly after Mr Viner had obtained both the restraining order and additional information from the file, Eoin Cameron's son Ryan Cameron, an employee of his collected these notes from Mr Viner and took them back to his electorate office where he had Andrew Gaspar, another employee, type them into a computer in Mr Cameron's electorate office in the form of an anonymous dirt sheet. The documents were subsequently distributed in the form of an anonymous dirt sheet.
A considerable number of copies of the restraining order, copied in various bright colours, were located in Mr Cameron's office for access to the public.
At Mr Cameron's preselection he was asked the following questions by a member of his selection panel, from the Executive of the Stirling Division:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "I refer to a so called smear sheet or dirt sheet circulated prior to last Saturday's State Council Senate preselection in regard to personal information contained therein about Senator Crichton-Browne.

INTERJECT.PARA: Did you know that the smear sheet was going to be circulated and if so did you or your staff directly or indirectly have anything to do with that circulation?
Also if you knew of people's intentions to sink to this type of gutter politics why did you not try to stop them or intervene in some way?
Do you condone this type of behaviour?
Mr Cameron answered "No" to the questions and in general terms replied in words to the effect that neither he nor his staff were involved in that kind of campaign and nor would he condone it.
This starkly contrasts with the facts:

1.that an employee of Mr Cameron's sought information about Esther and myself, no doubt for the purpose of distributing it to smear me and in the process, hurting Esther and the children, not to mention the Liberal Party, of which the motion now before State Council complains.
2.Another employee of Mr Cameron's—his son—went into Mr Viner's office to collect the material Mr Viner had obtained in the manner outlined above.
3.the material was reproduced in dirt sheet form on Mr Cameron's office computer.

4.the dirt sheet was distributed by Mr Cameron in an anonymous form. It was also sent anonymously by someone to the Labor President of the Senate, Senator Beahan and the Federal Labor Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, neither of whom had requested the document. They were both disgusted with the material and promptly and properly gave it to me.
5.Mr Cameron reproduced copies of the restraining order in bright colours, in large quantities also for distribution.

6.Mr Cameron's officer sought this dirt the day before my preselection. Mr Gaspar had also some time previously sought material from Mrs Crichton-Browne's file and had of course then also had his request refused. However, he was not deterred and persisted in his attempts.
SECTION 148 (1) of the Justices Act 1902 (WA) provides that only an interested party may obtain documents of the type obtained by Mr Viner.
The words "interested party" mean a party affected by the outcome of the hearing.
A lawyer would be seen to be a "party interested" only if he or she was acting for a party to the action in the documentation.

I am advised that several previous requests had been made by other sources including Mr Cameron's staff, on more than one occasion. Each had been refused on the above grounds. One can reasonably presume Mr Viner knew this and of the advice given to Mr Gaspar.
I understand Mr Viner claims not to be a party to the action.
As to the further distribution of the various dirt sheets, they were sent to members of the Liberal Party, my Federal and State parliamentary colleagues, the Labor Party and media across Australia.
The lists used to send the material to members of the Liberal Party came from a number of data bases including that of at least one Federal Liberal Senator.

The attached photocopy of envelopes were sent to Mr Bob FYFE but misspelt as FUIFE. The envelope that shows Senator Knowles name and office address contained standard political material. The envelope without her name and address contained a dirt sheet of filth and lies.
Mr Fyfe has advised me that Senator Knowles is the only person who misspells his name as FUIFE.

I have been advised in writing by Mrs Wendy Bartlett that the only person in the Liberal Party who writes to her from time to time is Senator Sue Knowles. I am further advised that the only person who spells her address as 5 Curry Grove rather than 5 Currie Grove is Senator Knowles.
The attached photocopy is of envelopes which were received by Mrs Bartlett and contained in one, was a dirt sheet relating to a restraining order.

I am advised by Mr Ian Dewar that he receives correspondence from Senator Sue Knowles, occasionally from Mr Allan Rocher as his local member on the basis of being a constituent not a Party member and occasionally from head office soliciting donations.
The attached photocopy of his envelope contained a dirt sheet.
Mr Dewar was a member of Stirling Division some years ago and has continued to receive correspondence from Senator Knowles since his membership expired.

I do not know who acquired Senator Knowles data base or who posted the letter with the dirt sheet in it, however it was this campaign that not only did great damage to me, brought enormous hurt and suffering to my family but which lead to "the publicity associated with" as it is referred to in the State Executive resolution. To blame me for the publicity of the matter is ridiculous and borders on the absurd.

PARA.EMPHASIS: This is but a small sample of available evidence.

INTERJECT.PARA: If the administration of the Party is concerned about the publicity they would as Dr Honey once publicly promised, investigate the distribution of the dirt and smear.

A simple examination of the data bases of each Federal Liberal member of parliament would be an elementary step in beginning the process of discovering those who in their unrelenting, crude and vile campaign against me, are so wilfully and recklessly prepared to wreak so much damage upon the Liberal Party.

I don't claim to know, other than that outlined in respect to Mr Cameron, what part if any, was played by members of parliament in providing Liberal Party and other membership lists, however no doubt the Liberal Party could begin to enquire. To my knowledge, they have done no more than write to each member asking for the lists, at my suggestion.
No doubt for their part, the innocent members of parliament would wish to be thoroughly exonerated.
The begging question is "does the Liberal Party condone the conduct of such tactics and are those who undertake it fit and proper people to be members of the Liberal Party or to represent it.
SUMMARY
. Esther withdrew the restraining order even before it was processed.
. Esther's intention was to obtain exclusive access to a family property.
. Mr Viner, Mr Cameron and other Liberals were responsible for the circulation of the restraining order.

INTERJECT.PARA: 2. COMMENTS ABOUT PARTY LEADERS
2.1In the Federal Parliament on 26 June 1995 in the course of a Personal Explanation you stated:-
"No leader ever tells me when I have to go. My history is that I have had to tell a few leaders when they have had to go." (Hansard 26 June 1995 page 4)
2.2That statement by you was the subject of widespread adverse and embarrassing publicity to the Party in the media across in Australia.
2.3By reason of your standing in the Party and public profile through the media the remarks made by you were imprudent and reflected adversely on the Party.

Again this ground is covered by privilege as it refers to a quote made by me in the Senate and may not be subject to scrutiny or consideration by State Council. It cannot be a ground of the expulsion motion. However, for the purpose of presenting the facts I set out the details as follow.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The statement was made in jest with tongue in cheek as those present know.

INTERJECT.PARA: The speech I made in which this quote is to be found and which the State President seeks to make much for the sake of concocting these spurious grounds for expulsion was made under Senate Standing Order 190 which provides that a Senator can claim to be misrepresented and to correct the misrepresentations.

The article complained of was one written by Glen Milne in The Australian. It was a particularly savage article factually incorrect in almost every material way, but which was the result of a misinformed briefing either by Mr Howard's staff or that of one of my colleagues.

The article in part read, "The truth of this appeared to be borne out during the tough negotiations in Perth during which Howard initially told Crichton-Browne he had to go." It was at that point that I injected my phrase.

The article continued, "Crichton-Browne's wife Esther was present for some of these negotiations. She made tea for Howard and, given the nature of the discussion, must have maximised the Liberal Leader's discomfort."
I again injected in jest that, "I find this kind of quaint—can you imagine any leader discomforted because my wife was making him a cup of tea?"
Senator Gareth Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate then interjected—"Depends what she put in it."
I responded, "She put a strong dose of courage in it. I am not referring to courage for him but courage for decision making." Hardly treasonable blasphemy which demands burning at the stake."
The only people at the meeting from which this distorted account was leaked and reported in The Australian, were John Howard, Geoff Prosser, Esther and myself.

By any measure it is a trivial matter, a nonsense ground and did not attract attention across Australia. By contrast it most certainly does not compare with public statements on pages 121, 122, 123 & 124, made by other Western Australian Federal Members of Parliament attacking the leader which are outlined below, not the least being those made by Senator Knowles, who in her public statements implied that Mr Downer had bought votes by promises of positions, and Mr Cameron who launched a vitriolic attack on Mr Downer. Mr Cameron also publicly criticised the Premier Court.
For example : "West Australian back bencher, Mr Eoin Cameron said he was "appalled" and "outraged" by the sacking (of Dr Hewson from the front bench).
"He (Mr Downer) was called a sook in the parliament and I don't know whether its an over-reaction to that or not,—- EOIN CAMERON THE WEEKEND AUSTRALIAN 27 AUGUST 1995

While I do not claim to have all coverage of the matter, my extensive inquiries show my quote about the leader as running to a total of 6.5cm or 2(1/2 ) column inches in all Australian newspapers. So much for claims of widespread adverse and embarrassing publicity to the Party in the media across Australia.—The press treated it for what it was.
Neither Sue Knowles or Eoin Cameron were ever censured for their comments about the leader which received heavy national media attention and which were said in a very critical context.
One gets the feeling that not only are these grounds contrived and concocted, but that they were made up on the spot without even a minimum of research, or a pretence of seriousness.

The last ground—that claiming I called for the expulsion of unspecified members was added at the State Executive meeting without any evidence being presented. "One may say it seemed a good idea at the time", that is why it is absolutely without substance. However, more than anything, it shows the sloppy and irresponsible way in which these four grounds were made up.
SUMMARY
.The comments have been taken out of context and were tongue in cheek.
.They were in response to a untrue newspaper article.
.The comments certainly did not embarrass the Party.

PARA.TAB: The comments were not "the subject of wide spread and adverse publicity as claimed.

INTERJECT.PARA: .The ground is contrived and trivial.

3. SEXIST COMMENTS
On my memory of events the quotes provided by the Liberal Party which seem to be taken directly from Colleen Egan's article in The Australian on 2 August 1995, are taken out of context.
I did not show Colleen Egan how I voted however she most certainly saw how I voted. When she appeared to write it down I did use the words or words similar to that quoted by Miss Egan.
This comment was made in the midst of banter of a nature not unknown between journalists and members of Parliament whom they know when talking "off the record".

As a matter of trivial historical record, the expression was first used in Australia perhaps in a more colourful way in 1988 by the hostess of Great Temptation Barbie Rogers. Barbie Rogers, who did not know her microphone was on immediately prior to introducing a midday movie said "If you don't, I'll rip your t..s off", warning viewers to watch the movie: SYDNEY MORNING HERALD 4 August 1995
The expression was the subject of a conversation in 1973 between US Attorney-General, John Mitchell, and reporter Carl Bernstein of the Washington Post.

Bernstein had asked whether Mitchell had been involved in illegally raising campaign funds. Mitchell responded with a reference to Katherine Graham, the publisher of the paper: "If you print that, Katie Graham is gonna get her t.. caught in a big fat wringer."
George Negus used the expression when referring to the ABC popularising serious subjects in 1993.
"But as soon as they do it, the commercials start screaming their t..s off that they're doing it too well."

In respect to the second expression attributed to me, my memory of events is that Miss Egan asked me several times for the number of my hotel suite, and finally I responded with words to the effect, "Why do you want to know, do you want to sleep with me?" This is hardly the sort of conversation I would have on the record. I should add that my family were with me in the suite.
This conversation was of course completely off the record as is obvious by its nature. The banter was jocular and within the ambience which exists between Members of Parliament and journalists.
LIEBMAN: "I was just going to say, in response to all of this, Crichton-Browne is saying that the comments he made were, quote off the record and were in the ambience of frivolity, they were a joke."

EGAN: "They were in that, if you like the word ambience, and we had been joking earlier, he was in a very jovial mood and I accept that, that was his version of a joke. I don't see it as anything but that and I've never said that it was." TODAY PROGRAM STEVE LIEBMAN/COLLEEN EGAN

This conversation would never have been made public had it not been for the fact that a member of the Liberal Party, described to me as a bitter enemy, contacted Margo Kingston of the Sydney Morning Herald. Kingston is also known as a strong opponent of mine due in part, I believe, to her close relationships with Mrs Judi Moylan and Senator Sue Knowles.

Following the conversation between Miss Egan and myself, which was apparently overheard, Miss Egan was approached by a group of Liberal Party women described to me as bitter enemies of mine. In fact Miss Egan described them to me as "Anne Hector type haters." Miss Egan was pestered and badgered by these people to report the conversation in her paper "The Australian", however she refused because as she said the conversation was off the record and private.

Subsequently at least one of these people rang Margo Kingston in Canberra and conveyed to her the substance of what they believed to be the conversation between Miss Egan and myself for the purpose of having the story published. It was done with wilful and malicious intent to damage the Party and myself.
As Miss Egan has said she did not find the comments

sexist, threatening or insulting. Miss Egan rang me to say that she had told Dr Honey prior to his public comments that if he publicly called on me to apologise to her she would publicly disassociate herself from him.

As is well known within the Liberal Party this is not the manner or style of my conversation with women in spite of anonymous Liberal women telling Miss Egan that it was not unusual. As Miss Egan has said, "the women some of his most vicious critics, say they have long resented what they perceive to be his sexist behaviour." This untruth was manufactured as a further attempt to pressure Miss Egan into writing a story.
When all else failed these people rang Margo Kingston to have the story, for which I am now condemned, published. She would have relished the task.
What I said in the circumstances was not detrimental to the Party but rather the publication, connived and urged by Liberal Party opponents to damage me and also the Party.
Miss Egan says one woman, in an attempt to encourage her to publish the conversation said to her "People should know what the most powerful man in the (State) Liberal Party is like."

Mrs Margie Bass, President of the State Women's Council of the Liberal Party, for one, may well claim to be outraged by my private comments however when Eoin Cameron was brought before State Executive for his public statements criticising the Party, the leader and the Premier, Mrs Bass vigorously defended him and clapped him when he rose to leave the meeting.

Mrs Bass had a different view of Mr Cameron at the 1994 Kalgoorlie Central Annual Divisional Conference held at Exmouth on 14 May 1994. She approached me during the Saturday morning session to tell me she had flown up in Senator Sue Knowles' charter aircraft accompanied by Mr Eoin Cameron, the Federal Member for Stirling, and Mrs Anne Griffiths, a member of the Liberal Party. During the flight Cameron had said to her in the midst of a conversation "We all know you Margie, you like young men with big c. . . s." Mrs Bass expressed her disgust at the way in which Senator Knowles "rolled around the plane laughing" at the smut. That rather contrasts with the vocal support and acclamation for Mr Cameron when brought before State Executive for disciplinary reasons. I do not believe Mrs Bass made any formal complaint to the Party about Mr Cameron's conduct. However she was quite distressed when she spoke to me. She would hardly come complaining to me if that was my manner of speaking to women.

I of course chose not to pass Mr Cameron's comments on to the media. Had I chosen to, no doubt it would have caused considerable pain to Mr Cameron, no doubt some embarrassment to Mrs Bass and damage to the Liberal Party.
The fact that it did not receive publicity was due to my decency and my concern for the effect it would have on the Liberal Party, whatever I may think of Mr Cameron.
I raise this matter to demonstrate how private conversations
when improperly disclosed, have a capacity to develop a life of their own and I respectfully suggest that there are different standards being set between various members of parliament.

Can I submit with respect that the matter of my private conversation with Miss Colleen Egan was in itself unexceptional, although seen in black and white and out of context as crude. However, it would really have never seen the light of day without the actual and determined actions of a group of bitter Liberal women opponents who when they failed to have Miss Egan run the story had it conveyed to Margo Kingston. Miss Egan as I have reported has said the matter was a private joke between the two of us and was not for reporting.

John Howard put out a one line statement which was originally barely reported, although I am prepared to stand corrected. However as Matt Price of Channel 9 observed on the weekly media round up, which was made up of a number of senior Perth journalists on the ABC Utting program, when discussing the political events of the week;

PARA.EMPHASIS: "Well the interesting thing about these comments is the story ran, I think on the Monday, and Colleen's comments were reported on the Monday, and I think it was the Tuesday that the story ran again. But by midday the story basically had been run and people were sort of thinking well, we've reported that, but it was then that David Honey and Richard Court started ringing around, their people started ringing journalists, lining up to criticise Crichton-Browne, which, we were all shocked, because that's never happened. . . But they were lining up to criticise him."
UTTING AND NEWS PANEL 4 AUGUST 1995

INTERJECT.PARA: Michelle Grattan is a senior journalist in the Canberra press gallery, a political commentator and a former editor of the `Canberra Times.'

PARA.EMPHASIS: GRATTAN: "On the other hand I also think that the sort of chatter at a press table, some of which would sometimes make your hair stand on end, is not the thing that usually gets highlighted in the media, its not something that is expected by either side at the time to form a story, therefore I do think this whole incident should be put on hold.

INTERJECT.PARA: UTTING: "Yes well I think that Colleen didn't intend to report it until other media outlets reported it, then she felt obliged to set the record straight so to speak."

GRATTAN: "Well the whole thing then takes off but in terms of the wider things going on in the West Australian Liberal Party, I think that this is a pretty minor bit of, a minor incident and its a bit of gossip really as much as anything else." 6WF RICHARD UTTING/MICHELLE GRATTAN 4 AUGUST 1995
With respect, the news and publicity was not so much what I said, but rather how the Premier's adviser and the President responded to it.

The State President publicly pursued this issue to the extent that not only were the press shocked at his reaction but they were so puzzled they were convinced there had to be another agenda. Frankly if the State President was concerned about the publicity the issue attracted, he should have been politically mature enough to realise he was creating the news and keeping the issue alive. I said very little about the issue but Dr Honey kept it alive for days and now weeks. I counselled from the outset against a public response. Price in particular subsequently articulated my political judgment.

The story was dead until the Party's comments on my private conversation created a story of their own. I don't recall any righteous or indignant fulmination from our side of politics when the Prime Minister allegedly privately called Laura Tingle from the Australian "a fat arse bitch". However I can imagine the political implications if the Federal President of the Labor Party had called on Keating to resign. Finally as Reg Withers said "I have heard Paul Keating make worse remarks in the parliament about people and he hasn't been expelled." SUNDAY PROGRAM 8 October 1995

The general view amongst the media and political commentators is the State President badly mishandled the issue and gave it a whole new life of its own. Note Utting, Grattan, Price comments. The Canberra press gallery are still trying to work out the State President's politics on the issue.

It rather seems that he has become a media junkie notwithstanding counselling from the State Parliamentary party and others including myself in months past about his propensity for speaking to the media at every opportunity without regard or contemplation of the political consequences.

By example his recent blurting out without thought or consultation that the Upper House should be constituted on the basis of one vote one value embarrassed both the State Government and the party organisation.
SUMMARY
.The State President's public comments and conduct caused a great deal of the publicity.
.The conversation was a private matter.
.The journalist refused to publish the story because it was off the record.
.The conversation was conveyed to the press by members of the Liberal Party.

.Miss Egan has said she would disassociate herself from any request for a public apology by Dr Honey. Miss Egan said she personally did not find the comments sexist, threatening or insulting in the context of the conversation
4. ALLEGEDLY CALLING FOR EXPULSION OF PARTY MEMBERS

It is claimed that at the State Conference of the Party in July 1995, I publicly called for the expulsion of unspecified persons from the membership of the Liberal Party. It is further claimed these remarks were divisive and undermined calls and attempts by members of the Party to create unity and harmony in the Party.
The claim is factually incorrect and should be struck down. As I observed earlier, this claim was added at State Executive without foundation and it shows.
In truth I am quoted in The Australian of the 31 July in the following terms:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senator Crichton-Browne said last night he assumed that those who spoke publicly against the interests of the Party would now be "dealt with properly and firmly". "I think there's room in the Party for everybody. But there's no room in the Party for anybody, wherever they come from, to make public comments which are capable of damaging the prospects of us winning the next state election or winning seats at the federal election" Senator Crichton-Browne said.

INTERJECT.PARA: In fact my comments were prefaced with the words, "On the basis of what the State President has just said following his re-election I assume (not published ) that those who spoke publicly against the interests of the Party would now be "dealt with properly and firmly"". (published.)

I am also quoted in the same article as saying, "That the message is that the organisation wants stability, certainty, vigour and the opportunity to win the three Labor-held marginals and return the Court State Government. It is also that dissidents will be dealt with properly and firmly.
On the AM program of 31 July 1995 the following exchange took place between myself and the interviewer Fran Kelly:
FRAN KELLY:Does it bother you that you're blamed for much of thebitterness in the Western Australian State Division?

NCB:Well I don't know that there's a lot of bitterness in the Liberal Party. There's probably a half a dozen trouble-makers, that with appropriate execution that would make sure that the Liberal Party went back to being a very consolidated organisation.
FRAN KELLY:When you say appropriate execution, you're talking about perhaps getting rid of these half dozen trouble makers.

NCB:No, no, it's not for me to make comment about that. But I did notice today that the President said, after he was elected, that if there were people who were prepared to make comments detrimental to the organisation, detrimental to the Parliamentary Party, or detrimental to their prospects of being re-elected, that he would deal with them. I assume that he's got something in mind.
FRAN KELLY: So you in fact would expect some heads to rolls if this speaking out, outside of the Party rules, continues?
NCB:I hope so.
This is in stark contrast with the assertion that I publicly called for the expulsion of unspecified persons from the membership of the Liberal Party.

This transcript is not as I understand it in the possession of the Liberal Party and nor was it when this ground was contrived and drafted and therefore could not have been considered in the grounds of the resolution. It is provided by me to the Party to make the facts clear to all.
SUMMARY

.These transcripts and statements confirm the fact that this ground is based on a totally false premise and was contrived and manufactured from some totally incorrect media article. There appears to have been no attempt to substantiate it. Most certainly, no one has bothered to ask me.

PARA.TAB: It is my submission that not one of the four given grounds warrant or justify the expulsion of a senior Federal Senator and former State President.

Putting aside the facts, the first two issues are eliminated by privilege and contempt; the third is a repetition by a Liberal member to the media of a private conversation which Miss Egan has said was not sexist, threatening or insulting and has disowned the State President's request for an apology. The last issue is factually incorrect.

INTERJECT.PARA: BIAS—CHILLA PORTER

PARA.EMPHASIS: JUSTICE AND EQUITY

INTERJECT.PARA: The truth of the matter is the State President's resolution is an attempt to kill off the victim, not the villains. Whatever the public perception may be of me, that perception has overwhelmingly been created by those now most anxious that I should be expelled from the Party.

At the Kalgoorlie South Divisional Conference held at Kalgoorlie on Saturday 2 September Dr Honey was asked why people who had been making public statements had not been expelled. In fact as I recall Messrs Viner and Tomlinson may have been mentioned by name.

Dr Honey responded in words to the effect that disciplinary proceedings within the Party were very much intended to ensure the smooth running of the Party and political judgements had to be made as to the level of disruption which expulsions would cause.
Expelling Tomlinson and Viner was too hard but he thinks expelling me is not.

In other words, Dr Honey was stating that he as State President was not applying the constitution in an even handed and impartial way, to say nothing of the legal imperatives which flow from the constitution of an incorporated body.

It may be held that if you are a notorious trouble maker who is well known as a source of internal Party information to the media, and the President judges that you are "too difficult to handle", particularly given that you may have support for your conduct then you are exempt from the rules and standards applying to others. If you are a little old retiree without a base of support in the Party you may be an easy target. Alternatively if there is a political judgement made that irrespective of consistency, precedent, fairness or justice, it is deemed desirable to expel someone for all the wrong legal reasons, then a different standard is set. The tyranny of Presidents and office bearers making subjective political judgements becomes a ramrod against the bastion of democracy and the rule of law.

The facts and grounds of each case are ignored and disregarded contrary to the constitution. On that basis, there need be no reason to provide grounds—a total denial of natural justice and constitutional requirements.

The great evil of any body or society of men and women is the suspension of the rules, the abuse of the rules or the contrived use of the rules for reasons other than their proper intention. When the leaders of an association or body apply the rules to achieve their own views and judgements, the whole process is corrupted and the leadership destroys the integrity, goodwill, faith and respect of those they are elected to serve.

It is not a question of my conduct or my public statements but rather the fact that I am seen or perceived by these dissidents as symbolic of their opposition which prevents them achieving their objectives. They are unable to win the intellectual will of the majority of people at various fora of the Party with their arguments so they seek to impose their will upon the majority by waging a war against the Party and me in particular, through the media. Truth is their first casualty, political fortunes of the Party are second and the reputation of individuals and their families third.
It seems there are no steps to which they will not go. The array of obscene and utterly untrue allegations which run through the various press cuttings show testimony to that.

Often these statements are made to the media in the form of "senior sources say". The enormous damage done to the Party comes not from me but rather what this group claim in the public arena through the media.
Following is but a small sample of the type of campaign that has been waged against me through often anonymous but invariable untrue leaks to the press
These people have little if any care for the effect of their media attacks on me and the Party.

Perhaps one of the most recent examples of media dishonesty which totally misrepresents me and can only damage my reputation within the community and the Liberal Party is to be found in the West Australian of the 21 August 1995 under the heading, "Senator Faces Final Curtain"

The offending paragraph reads when referring to the Federal Liberal members meeting with Dr Honey that, "The meeting, the first between pro and anti Crichton-Browne MPs in four years, was hosted by Dr Honey, who is understood to have admitted that Senator Crichton-Browne could have prevented Mr Filing's downfall."
The State President well knows that to be utterly untrue because at my request he thoroughly examined that claim when made by Mr Filing.
I promptly wrote to Dr Honey asking him if he would either confirm or deny that claim and in the event that the report was wrong I asked that he advise me what steps he had taken to correct it.
The State President was kind enough to convey to me that the article was wrong however, to quote him, "I have no intention of making any public comment on this matter."

I must say, reading the newspapers together with the various radio and television transcripts, it must be one of the few occasions he declined an opportunity to make a public statement about me or the Liberal Party.

As matters stand, the article has been left uncorrected and the view pressed in the media by Filing and his supporters that I was responsible for him losing his preselection has been reinforced and confirmed by the State President. This is no help to me and certainly of no assistance to Paul Stevanage, the Liberal candidate.

For one, who has in recent days since he was re-elected State President, suddenly expressed concern about public perception of me, I regret that when Dr Honey is offered an opportunity to put a wrong public statement right, he declines to do so.
THE CAMPAIGN GOES ON
Below are further examples of the type of unwarranted publicity imposed upon me and the Party by those who claim I am now to be punished for their public smear campaign.

In so doing, I include a summary of the letter sent by me to you on the 25th of July outlining the scurrilous allegations made against me claiming I had made death threats and obscene phone calls to a fellow Liberal parliamentarian.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dear. . .

INTERJECT.PARA: "On Wednesday evening of the 21st June, every television network in Australia ran as their first news item allegations that I had made death threats and obscene phone calls to a Senate colleague. The allegations went on to claim that I had been interviewed by the Federal Police in respect to the matter. These threatening and obscene telephone calls were supposed to have been made to a Federal politician in Perth and Canberra.
For your edification I set out the true facts.
The first visit by the Federal Police to my office took place on Friday 16 June 1995 at my request. This request was the result of criminal matters which I wanted investigated.
The Australian Federal Police have treated the matter with the utmost seriousness and are pursuing the matters with vigour.

While the Federal Police were in my office a junior officer arrived to join the meeting. Waiting to come into my office, he was asked by someone other than my staff whether he was being attended to. In good faith the officer disclosed that he was a Federal Police officer and he was visiting my office. Need I say any more.

On Monday the 19th June Channel 9 in Perth contacted their Canberra bureau, who then asked me about allegations that I had made threatening phone calls, and as a result had been interviewed by the Federal Police. I conveyed to the Canberra bureau that the claims were utter nonsense and I naturally expected to hear no more about it.
On Tuesday 20th June, one hour before the Perth news was broadcast, I was informed by Channel 9 that the story, as conveyed to me the previous day was going to air.
I formally advised Channel 9 that these allegations were utterly untrue and I would sue them if they ran the story. On the advice of their lawyers the story did not go to air.

However, failing to have the story run by giving this false information to the media, those Liberal sources then gave the information to the ALP. John Kobelke raised the same allegations under parliamentary privilege, thus protecting the media and allowing them to run the story.
I can think of few more disgusting and outrageous claims than those made against me by Mr Kobelke with lies given to him by members of the Liberal Party.
Immediately following the publication of the allegations through the various media outlets I was inundated with media requests for a comment.

During the day the Federal Police had, with my approval, been saying "no comment". The reason for that was quite simple. The investigations which arose as a result of my complaint, were of a covert nature and neither I nor the Federal Police wanted these operations to be exposed or compromised. Late in the afternoon the Federal Police contacted me to say that they thought they should put out a short statement to clear me of the allegations, to which I agreed.

Subsequently the State Police also put out a statement which also put lie to the claims made against me. I made a very brief statement in the Senate refuting the claims without ever acknowledging that I had spoken to or lodged a complaint with the Federal Police.

The net effect is that a most serious complaint of a criminal nature made by me to the Federal Police has resulted in a nation-wide media saturation that I was being investigated for making death threats to a Federal colleague. I leave it to you to imagine the effect that has had upon our family.

If this Party is to allow Members of Parliament and their innocent families' lives, reputations and careers to be destroyed by a small band who have no regard for decency, privacy and least of all for the well being of the Liberal Party we shall stand condemned.

To what level will this little band of dissidents sink. The allegations have of course brought great hurt and suffering to Esther and our children, who seem to be fair game in these sordid attempts to attack me by foul means because fair means have failed.
Think not about those who are being publicly criticised but about those whose names and faces you see, read and hear speaking out against the Party and members of it."
Yours sincerely
NOEL CRICHTON-BROWNE

This highlights the style of campaign which has been waged against me in the media and which has caused the type of publicity which damages the Party, myself and my family. I know of no inquiries by the Party to deal with such conduct.

The various dirt sheets which have been anonymously circulated by Liberals using Liberal Federal Members' data bases are a matter of public record. I know of no action by the Party to deal with this except to collect a number of envelopes.
One allegation for instance asserted that I had fraudulently made an insurance claim for a damaged mobile phone.
One dirt sheet asserted that I had beaten up a female friend.
One claim implied my 2 year old son who strangled in his cot, died in suspicious circumstances. How sick are these people.
A recent rumour has me as a homosexual.
Liberal sources fabricated a document alleging I am an anti Semitic Jew Hater and gave the forgery to John Halden of the Labor Party.

Barbara-Dene Jones as President of Tangney Division circulated a document claiming to be the substance of confidential State Executive deliberations in which she made certain untrue allegations against me.

Not satisfied with their best efforts, a member of the group who produced and distributed the dirt sheets, had the media ring a former employee of mine who had in the past been a personal assistant to me. The purpose of the call was ask her to confirm a number of untruths which had been passed on to them and to enquire as to whether the lady had any dirt on me she would care to pass on.
By process of elimination, it was not difficult from the line of questioning to establish that the source was either a parliamentarian or an employee of a parliamentarian.

I have also attracted adverse publicity with various named and unnamed sources claiming that I was responsible for Paul Filing and Allan Rocher losing their preselection, together with Brian Hilbert being unsuccessful in the Federal preselection for Swan.

When Mr Howard rang me to say he wished me not to attend further Party meetings I asked him for what reason. He responded that "this would not have happened if I had not been so intransigent two months ago." In other words I was to be blamed for Filing's and Rocher's preselection failures. I was on my way to another meeting so the conversation was brief, however the message was clear.

These claims are totally untrue and without foundation and in the case of Moore, at my request, the State President fully investigated Mr Filing's claim some months ago and found it to be without a shred of evidence and said so publicly.

When Cameron and Filing were confronted by myself and John Howard in the Leader's office about claims made by them to the leader that I was seeking to undermine their preselection, much to their embarrassment neither could give one name.
People in the divisions of Stirling, Moore and Curtin know that I was not involved, however it is a story peddled to Howard by Rocher and Filing, together with others seeking to damage me.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is quaintly ironic that those who have significantly contributed to the public perception of me are excused with an apology, an offer they couldn't refuse while the victim is to be called to show cause why he should not be expelled.

To the extent I am symbolic of the majority voice in the Party and have to be torn down when to the chagrin of the dissidents democracy prevails, any other symbol of opposition to their ambition can expect the same evil, corrupt destructive campaign to destroy them.

Today it is me, tomorrow it will be David Honey or Richard Court or another strong personality in the Party who does a job of work and has broad Party support—anybody who dares represent the majority.
I for my part will never reward treachery.

To give succour and comfort to those who seek to impose their minority views upon the majority by wrecking the Party and the contribution made so generously and unselfishly by so many volunteers is to succumb to blackmail and its success will guarantee its repetition.
The decent people of the Party have to say, enough is enough.
It is worth reflecting upon whose names appear in the media reports attacking the Party and members of it. That is when the attacks are not anonymous.
Following is a brief summary of events which bring us to the present unpleasant circumstances.
THE FACTS
STATE EXECUTIVE 7 AUGUST 1995

I was first advised either on the 7th August or the day before that a State Executive meeting was to be held to consider correspondence which had taken place between the State President and myself on the 2nd August 1995 and 4th August 1995.
That correspondence related to my private conversation with Colleen Egan which sadly the State President made public in a press conference he called.
My request to be present at the State Executive to answer any claims which may have been made against me was denied.

I first spoke to the State President at 3.30pm on the day of the meeting (7 August) and asked that I be allowed to attend. His response was that if I did request to attend the State Executive, then it was likely the request would be granted. However if I attended and was seen to be successful in my representations it would make the President and the Premier look weak. Dr Honey advised me that the media would all be at Menzies House and would therefore be aware of my attendance.

I said in that case, I would not persist in my request, not wishing to compromise either the Premier or the State President, particularly since I had been led to believe no action against me was to be taken. In fact I understood the motion to be moved was simply one endorsing the comments and actions of the President and the Premier and the matter was to be ruled off at that point.
That fact was conveyed to me, amongst others, by the Premier.

That is an understanding, I believe, shared by others. Most certainly the very senior office bearers of the Party were not aware of the proposed action by the President, and nor was the Premier. Many others were also apparently unaware that they were to be confronted with such an important resolution. I understood no agenda was provided to members of State Executive prior to the meeting.
I subsequently rang Dr Honey at 5.20pm on the same day and asked that in the event any motion was to be moved, which in any way reflected upon me, then I formally requested the right to attend.

Dr Honey acknowledged my request, but gave no indication any such motion was to be moved. I have reason to believe Dr Honey changed his mind in respect to the motion, or had his mind changed for him between 3.30pm & 5.30pm (the time of the meeting).
It is my understanding that the State President did not even put my request to attend the meeting to the members of State Executive.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The practice of the Party has been always been to give notice and provide an opportunity to members of the organisation and the Parliamentary Party who are subject to disciplinary proceedings.

INTERJECT.PARA: Dr Honey's motion certainly falls within the general category and principle.
Recently Senator Knowles and Mr Cameron were both asked to attend State Executive to explain their criticism of their colleagues and the leader.
Both were provided with the motion, or the purpose of the meeting, well in advance, and a time of mutual convenience was set by State Executive to hear their responses.
This was not a courtesy extended to me.

In Senator Knowles' case the motion was no more than: State Executive expresses its grave concern at the public statements made by Senator Knowles following the Federal Parliamentary Party leadership ballot, particularly those statements which reflect upon her colleagues and the leader Mr Alexander Downer.

State Executive notes in particular Senator Knowles' comments in her interview of 23 May with Mr Peter Kennedy on the ABC radio "Drive Time" program and her further interview with Mr Peter Newman on "6PR Breakfast" on Friday 27 May.
State Executive instructs the Acting State Director to convey the terms of this resolution to Senator Knowles and to remind her of the damaging effect upon the Party of such public statements."
In Mr Cameron's case the motion was similar.

During the evening of the 7th August the State President rang me at home to inform me that State Executive had carried a motion calling upon me to resign. He gave me no explanation or reason and I made no comment other than to acknowledge his call and terminated the conversation.

Subsequently on the 8th August I received a letter signed by the Western Australian Liberal Party State Director, Peter Wells, informing me of a motion passed at a meeting of State Executive held on 7 August calling on me to resign, still giving no explanation, no grounds and no justification.
The motion reads:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "To avoid further damage to the Liberal Party, Senator Noel Crichton-Browne be asked to resign immediately from the Party.

INTERJECT.PARA: As will be shown the motion moved by the State President on 7th August was a defacto expulsion motion to the extent that if I did not resign the State President intended to move for my expulsion.

Given that I was not advised in advance of the motion the President intended to move, that I was refused the grounds for the motion and refused the right to attend, I believe that my standing in the Party and the community was improperly compromised and damaged. It is a clear denial of natural justice which one would barely expect of the Liberal Party.

That the motion was to lead to an expulsion motion set a process in place which by the very dynamics of politics was bound to influence members of State Executive in their further deliberations. Having been allowed to arrive at a conclusion about my alleged conduct and the subsequent penalty without proper and due process has inevitably lead to a denial of natural justice. Had, for instance, I been present and presented a persuasive case and the motion was defeated I would not now be confronted with an expulsion motion as it is euphemistically called by Dr Honey.
The process used at the State Executive on 7 August guaranteed the expulsion motion which an uncharitable soul might believe was the motive for the lack of fairness and due process.
Having voted for the first step, no doubt some delegates were capable of being influenced in their further deliberations by their preconceptions and deliberations thus far.

To date my request for the grounds for the resolution as shown in the minutes of State Executive has been denied. It is absurd to imagine that a senior Federal Liberal Senator with 25 years service to the Party, including 10 years in a full time voluntary capacity, would respond in the positive to such a motion calling on him to resign without explanation, reason or justification. I am appalled to learn that in the event I did not resign as demanded of me without cause or reason, that the State President proposed to move an expulsion motion at the next State Executive.
This is confirmed by his own words;

route is a very long and drawn out process, which will take a minimum of 3 months to 6 months, and will almost inevitably end in the Supreme Court, and that's why in the interests of the Party we're giving the Senator this option to resign."

Dr Honey has shown preconceived bias and prejudice against me by publicly stating only my resignation would prevent an expulsion motion from him.

I believe that the motion calling on me to resign was prejudicial to proper deliberations of a motion to censure, suspend or expel me. You will see from the Constitution clause 17, that there is no provision for an expulsion motion in isolation, however Dr Honey continued to talk of an "expulsion motion" which in itself is prejudicial to any other outcome.
