Dr Honey has never personally asked me to resign. Five minutes before he went into State Executive to move his motion, he was contacted by me and did not mention it. He was given every chance. After the meeting, he did no more than ring to tell me of the State Executive resolution.

I will most certainly not embarrass or humiliate Dr Honey in this appeal document, however, Dr Honey's complaints of my alleged high profile at State Conference and of my role in the party organisation are in stark contrast with his attitude when he needed me to win the Presidency and my almost daily advice thereafter. I say little more so as not to humiliate him other than to say that at his 1994 contest he did not make one single contribution on his own behalf save for one phone call to the delegate in his home town of Cranbrook—that includes his letter to delegates and his speech to the Conference.
This was due in part to the pleadings to me of his wife—apparently he was unable to cope.

May I be forgiven for resenting Dr Honey's comments given that he knows the truth of the machinations of the 1994 & 1995 President's campaigns and particularly, for instance, the fact that my wife did not go to bed at all on the evening prior to the Presidential vote, working through the night for Dr Honey. He and his wife were comfortably tucked into bed. STATE EXECUTIVE 21 AUGUST 1995
As any sensible person would do, I declined to resign without explanation or cause from the State President and now that I read the expulsion grounds, my decision has been vindicated.

The subsequent State Executive held on Monday 21 August was convened for the purpose of Dr Honey moving for my expulsion, however as with the previous State Executive no notice of intention was given prior to the meeting.

I rang the State Director Peter Wells and requested a right to be present to address the meeting, however I was not provided with the resolution and therefore the grounds for the motion which had been moved prior to my attendance.

Mr Wells rang me at 6.10pm to say that State Executive had agreed to my attendance which was required immediately. After a denial of attendance at the previous meeting I did not expect my attendance to be agreed to, so it took me approximately three quarters of an hour to arrive.

Dr Honey told me I had been granted 10 minutes to present my case, and when I argued that would be totally inadequate he said the executive was not going to spend the whole night on the matter and 10 minutes was to be the maximum. In view of the great seriousness of the motion, I thought that a capricious, unjust and cavalier attitude; but it is in keeping with the general approach taken at the previous State Executive calling for my resignation. I have subsequently learnt that decision was not the subject of an agreed resolution by State Executive.

Notwithstanding several interruptions by the President I spoke for some minutes beyond the allocated time, however for a period considerably less than would have allowed me to present a comprehensive and coherent case. I was refused a right to ask questions or to have questions put to me.
I understand the motion to expel me had been moved and spoken to by Dr Honey prior to my attendance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: I was not provided with the grounds for Dr Honey's motion which made my task of presenting a defence ridiculously impossible.

INTERJECT.PARA: Given that the motion calling on me to resign was tantamount to what is now called by the State President "the expulsion motion", I believe I was denied natural justice by not being provided with either the grounds for the motion or an opportunity to respond in the forum of State Executive on the 7 August when my resignation was demanded.

I believe the State Executive of the 7 August prejudiced the prospects of an unbiased hearing of the State Executive on the 8 September when the expulsion motion was moved. Calls for expulsion by Dr Honey clearly demonstrate a preconceived bias and denial of natural justice.

Except for the reference to these "couple of comments to Colleen Egan" the President is now claiming that the grounds proffered by the questioner caused damage to the Party, and that they were such that neither the Party nor the public would accept. I have not the slightest idea what he is referring to, but certainly they are not matters referred to by Dr Honey in support of his motion for my resignation or his subsequent motion calling for, as he likes to put it, my expulsion. Most certainly these obscure thoughts are not contained in any written material provided to me.
They cannot be considered by State Council, however I believe the State President had an obligation to explain his criticism to me and State Council.

The truth of the matter is the State President was under duress, pressured by others to move for my expulsion. He then set about contriving ways of achieving that. The first step was to pressure me to resign, however this attempt was so absurd that no grounds or justification were given to me. I was not told in advance of the proposed motion nor were senior office bearers of the Party, I was refused attendance to the meeting to defend myself and the State President used different excuses to those contrived for the "expulsion" motion.

The next step was the censure, suspend or expulsion motion now the subject of appeal before State Council. Under the constitution this required justifiable grounds. That required the contrivance of the four grounds given.

1.Previously the State President has strenuously opposed public use of the restraining order matter and publicly criticised those who raised and published it. His public statements of support are on page 13.

2.The State President has never previously raised the matter of my leadership statement in the Senate. In fact to my knowledge, he has never previously raised it with anybody within the Party. Frankly, I believe he thought it so trivial that he saw no reason to raise it with me.

3.While he publicly promised to pursue with vigour, those who had damaged me and the Liberal Party by distributing dirt sheets, he seems to have shown no interest in those who conveyed my private and personal conversation at State Conference, to the media. In fact I haven't even heard him criticise them.

4.The claim that I publicly called for the expulsion of unspecified persons from the membership of the Liberal Party is simply untrue and the Party has not produced a shred of evidence to justify it. The facts produced by me show it to be completely false.

What is of great concern to me is that there are a number of members of State Executive who either do not believe or will not accept that when arriving at a decision about this matter, only the four grounds as set out in the motion before State Council can be considered. It is quite wrong and the Supreme Court would overturn any decision which is based on other matters or because regardless of the failure and weakness of the grounds, a decision is made for political reasons. The State Council must address the four grounds given and nothing else—no other material consideration can be entertained, least of all political considerations.

The Liberal Party is a registered body under the Commonwealth Electoral Act and is the recipient of taxpayers funding. Because the Commonwealth Parliament confers legislative recognition upon political parties, it has taken them beyond the mere ambit of voluntary associations.

Given the functioning of the Liberal Party and the way matters have been considered and dealt with in the past it really is a nonsense to suggest these four contrived grounds now before State Council are of such a nature as to justify censure, suspension or expulsion. As have most political commentators, I believe the decent and fair minded people within the Liberal Party will see these grounds and this resolution as a sham to appease the dissidents, malcontents and those who have sought to destroy me over two decades.

"Well yes it is doing well (electorally), but that's the ultimate of ironies. CHANEY—DERRICK TOMLINSON
The following two cases contrast dramatically with current events and go to highlight just what course the Party is now embarking upon.
The contrasts are stark, disturbing and put matters into perspective.

I say without apology that if this motion in its complete form is not repealed in its entirety by State Council, this episode of jackboot, contrived and prejudiced conduct by the Party will be looked back upon with shame and disgrace. Future office bearers will look back with bewilderment and horror.
I said very much the same things at the time of the Federal Governments retrospective tax when I was part of a minority,—I have of course been proved to be right.

In June/July 1991 the Liberal Party was in the midst of a very difficult Floreat by election caused in a large part by the public campaign run by the same small group who were unable to convince the majority to support their candidate. Liz Constable had deserted the Party after a short flirtation and stood as a Independent.

The State Parliament leadership did not give support to the endorsed Liberal candidate, a fact of which the media were well aware. In fact, obscene as it may be, Sir Charles Court was criticised for supporting and campaigning for the endorsed candidate.

A considerable number of Liberal Party members handed out How to Vote cards for the Independent and were shown on television celebrating her victory. With one exception, not one person who so treacherously campaigned against their own Party, were censured, suspended or expelled. My memory is that they were neither spoken or written to. Accordingly, we saw a repetition at the next general election.
The same financial Liberal Party people again handed out How to Vote cards for Constable with complete immunity.

Perhaps the most graphic contrast between the motion State Council is now being asked to consider and the conduct of MPs and the Party is to be found in the events of the Hon Derrick Tomlinson MLC and Mr Fred Chaney.
In the midst of this campaign, Mr Tomlinson, then Shadow Minister for Justice under the State Party leadership of Barry MacKinnon, appeared on the ABC 7.30 Report.

Mr Tomlinson's appearance was for the purpose of attacking Party preselection procedures, threatening to quit the Liberal Party and to demand the reforms of which he said had become a corrupt Party with corrupt members. He tied me to the corruption.
As I wrote at the time, "The effect of the allegations very badly damaged my reputation, not only in the Liberal Party, but in the wider community.
As someone who has deep roots in the Western Australian community, nobody would know better than I, the extent of the damage done to my personal reputation."

He said it is a Party which he did not believe he could continue to be a member. Mr Tomlinson made no complaints to the State President, giving evidence or grounds for making those assertions before or after appearing on the program.

Mr Tomlinson told Mr MacKinnon during the by election that he would not campaign for the official Liberal candidate because the independent candidate Liz Constable, (who never stood for Liberal endorsement for Floreat) was, "one of my few close, personal friends."
Mr MacKinnon neither disciplined Mr Tomlinson nor asked him to stand down from his shadow ministry.

It was alleged at the same time that Mr Reg Davies, then a Liberal MLC, sought Mr Tomlinson's advice about what he should do about his future and that Mr Tomlinson encouraged him to resign from the Party during the by election. Mr Tomlinson did not communicate to the State President that one of the members of the State Party was proposing to resign at such a critical time or that in fact he was even contemplating such a course of action.

This all took place in the midst of the Floreat by election. After some delay, Mr Tomlinson was censured by State Executive and re-endorsed as number two on the Upper House ticket after very reluctantly making an apology to State Executive. This apology was only secured by Mr MacKinnon's intervention.
Mr Viner was President of the Party at the time.
No disciplinary action was taken against Mr Tomlinson with the left of the Party fiercely defending him.

On the 19 June 1991, shortly after the Floreat by election campaign had begun, Mr David Smith, an officer bearer in Curtin Division, resigned when it became apparent that neither he nor the candidate of his choice was going to obtain the Liberal endorsement. In so doing, he dumped all over the Party and members of it, attracting considerable media attention.

Mr Smith was not popular in the Party. On the one occasion I recall him standing for preselection for the Senate, he did not receive one vote from amongst the 120 delegates including his own division.
In the midst of this campaign, Mr Chaney, who did not disguise his support for the Independent found the need as a Federal Member to publicly buy into the matter at great cost to the Party.
On 20 June 1991, Mr Fred Chaney was interviewed by Peter Kennedy on ABC Drive Time.
CHANEY

PARA.EMPHASIS: I think the resignation of Smith is a tragic sort of, what I call the latest tragic development, in something that has been going on for a long time.

INTERJECT.PARA: The previous day Chaney has described Smith as an independent mind who had made a valuable contribution to the Party.

In the process of resigning from the Party, Mr Smith who was barely known to me to my relief, bitterly attacked the Party and me. It was never clear to me what my sin was but that was the way of Mr Smith.
I understand that Mr Smith has recently been deeply involved with the group who have run the campaign against me personally which was designed to destroy my preselection.
The circumstances and events of that campaign are now a matter of recent and contemporary history.

I believe, Mr Chaney's damaging intervention was based on the misguided belief that I supported Michael Huston, the successful candidate, and that he was known to me. In truth, I barely knew Michael Huston and think at that time I had met him probably no more than twice.
Mr Smith, whom Mr Chaney praised when he resigned, did so at a critical time in the Floreat by election.
Mr Chaney the then Member for Pearce was interviewed by Kevin Hume on ABC Drive on 11 July. This was just days before the Floreat by election.
CHANEY

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . the Party organisation has to stop having the sort of problems that are leading decent honourable people like Reg Davies to resign

INTERJECT.PARA: CHANEY

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . I would have to say that all of these resignations are a symptom of a deep malaise in the organisation and anybody who goes around saying that there is nothing much wrong is either a fool or a knave.

. . . I think that there will be a lot of trouble in getting that sort of decent, in getting support from the decent section of the community while they believe the Party organisation is a body that can't be trusted.
With the Floreat by election just a week away on the 13 July 1991 the then Liberal Party State President, Peter Jones banned state and federal MPs from speaking to the media.
Mr Chaney promptly ignored him and made statements to the Sunday Times the following weekend.—No action was contemplated or taken against him.

You can imagine the enormous damage done to the Party's prospects in the Floreat by election by the public statements of Mr Chaney, Mr Tomlinson and Mr Smith. Smith resigned, however Chaney was not censured, suspended or expelled. I do not believe Chaney was ever spoken to. Tomlinson was censured then promptly re-endorsed for the Upper House.

These are I believe, vivid and stark contrasts with the trivial and silly motion now before you, calling for my expulsion. While these two gentlemen were wreaking havoc on the Floreat by election, I like many others, was working desperately to try and salvage the situation.
During this period, I was attacked through the media by Chaney, Tomlinson and their obvious supporters.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Turning through my files I have unearthed a letter sent by me to Party office bearers in late September 1991 as a result of this episode.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is with a sense of deja vu that I now read it again for the first time in four years. I enclose the 1991 letter to remind ourselves that the past is with us in the present;

PARA.EMPHASIS: Dear. . .

INTERJECT.PARA: Over the past eight weeks you will have been witness to what has been described in The West Australian as a campaign of "public vilification of Senator Crichton-Browne". This campaign has been pursued through the media by a small group of Liberals who have indulged in the worst campaign of character assassination perhaps ever launched against a parliamentary member of the Liberal Party,. They have also done great damage to the Liberal Party.

TAB.TAB: Little did I know what they were really capable of.

PARA.EMPHASIS: I notice that Sir Charles Court has also been criticised in the media by Liberals. His sin apparently was that he was supporting the endorsed Liberal candidate at the request of the Party. There was a time in the Liberal Party when support of the endorsed Liberal candidate, through thick and thin whether or not he or she was our particular choice, was the proper and honourable thing to do.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are two ways to guarantee cheap publicity—attack your own Party and your own members of parliament. The media love it and voters will leave in droves.

Other than to point out the fact that Mr Huston, the endorsed candidate for Floreat was at the time of his preselection barely known to me and that I played no part in his preselection, I steadfastly refused prior to the Floreat by election polling day to provide the media with any comment which may have damaged our prospects of success during the Floreat by election.

I understood that the role of members of parliament was to get behind the endorsed candidate and try to win the seat for the Liberal Party, not to enter into a war of words, not to attack other members of parliament and not to attack the Liberal Party.

I do not now intend to give respectability to these despicable attacks. I believe they have been dealt with by the State President, Mr Peter Jones, Sir Charles Court and others. However, with the by election and state conference behind us and in the interests of fairness and an informed Liberal Party, I set out a number of other matters which I believe deserve to be explained and understood.
You will recall that on 18 June Barry MacKinnon called a press conference following the resignation of a Mr David Smith from the Liberal Party.
The clear implication flowing from that press conference was that I was involved in the Floreat preselection. Barry did not name me but background briefing of journalists by others did.

The media was not convinced that the leader would call a press conference simply over the resignation of a relatively obscure Party official. That predictably invited media speculation about Barry MacKinnon's leadership, my contribution to the Liberal Party and, perhaps more particularly and damaging, the legitimacy of the endorsement of the Liberal Party's candidate for the State seat of Floreat.
The subsequent events are of course now self evident.

It is totally incorrect for it to be claimed by anyone that I was in any way involved in the affairs or the outcome of the Floreat preselection or that Mr Huston was my candidate. I hardly knew Mr Huston and I am not familiar with the branches in the electorate. Had Barry contacted me or others he would have learnt that.

I had no particular interest or concern in the outcome of the Floreat preselection. During my four years as State President, for better or worse, not one sitting member of Parliament lost his/her preselection and not one was able to claim thanks to me for his/her success.
In truth Barry MacKinnon's press conference should not have been about one of his colleagues but about those who seemed determined to wreck the Party to get their candidate endorsed or elected.
According to media reports, the only two Parliamentarians who expressed a view about any of the candidates for endorsement were Barry himself and Philip Pendal.
Both MacKinnon and Pendal were known to be backing Constable and Pendal said so at a Cottesloe Women's meeting.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Barry MacKinnon's press conference following the resignation of a relatively obscure Party member wherein much was made of the alleged involvement of unnamed members of Parliament, set in train a series of events which gave failed candidates and their supporters a public cause for their campaign.

INTERJECT.PARA: The endorsed Liberal candidate's prospects were not helped during the campaign by the reported comments of Mr Chaney when he was quoted in The West Australian on 12 July 1991 following Mr Davies' resignation saying of Mr Reg Davies' actions, "But of what I know of Reg he had no other honourable course left but to leave."

PARA.TAB: No one seemed to know why he resigned except that he was fourth on the Upper House ticket and thought his chances of re-election were better as an Independent.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Chaney was also reported as reflecting adversely on his own Party during the campaign when he was quoted as saying, "Liberals who went around saying there was nothing wrong with the Party were either knaves or fools."

INTERJECT.PARA: His further public comments about me and the internal affairs of the Party were equally unhelpful to the campaign to hold the seat of Floreat for the Liberal Party.

Mr Derrick Tomlinson's claims of "corruption" within the Liberal Party in the midst of the by election can only have helped the independent candidate. One who calls "rotten fish for sale" is hardly likely to attract customers or, in our case, voters. His statement within a forum of the Party that he would not be campaigning for the endorsed Liberal candidate because Elizabeth Constable was a friend of his is hardly the conduct one would expect from a shadow minister.
Mr Tomlinson's further public comments during the campaign about his future within the Party can only have further damaged the Liberal Party's prospects of winning the seat.

I further observe that Barry's press conference stimulated talk and speculation about a leadership challenge which I understand from the media arose simply because they were and remain at a loss as to why he called the press conference.

No Federal member worked harder for him or his team in the last State election and I have publicly continued to give him my unqualified support and commitment since, a matter which barely need stating.
I assume I can expect the same.

I asked for neither reward, nor recompense. I declined a number of preselections and when I stepped down after four years as State President, the Party was in excellent shape. I therefore take grave offence at the accusations recently made against me. It seems to me that those with the most to say have made the least contribution.

There has been mischief made in the media about my attitude to multiple proxy voting, [stimulated by Chaney, Tomlinson and the dissidents] the history of multiple voting in the Party and the outcome of the state conference constitutional amendments.
For the record I make the following points clear.
. During my period as State President, multiple proxy voting for preselections was not allowed and never considered.
. Multiple proxy voting was not allowed in any other forum of the Party except for country delegates to State Conference.

. The present alleged problems arose as a result of the re-writing of the Constitution in 1987 during the period of Mr Keith Simpson's presidency and at the time Mr Derrick Tomlinson was a State Vice President.

. I opposed the new Constitution at the time these gentlemen were enthusiastically supporting it. It is that Constitution which gave the Party multiple voting about which much has been made by Mr Tomlinson. [Paul Filing was also a State Vice President at the time and an enthusiastic contributor and supporter of the new constitution]

PARA.EMPHASIS: Had my proposals at the recent State Conference been fully implemented, there would be a great deal less multiple voting than still exists.

INTERJECT.PARA: Given the nature of the attacks against me, their effects upon my family and my self imposed silence in what I believed to be the best interests of the Party during the by election campaign and prior to State Conference, you will now expect my comments to be frank and forthright, hence this letter to you.
Kind regards and best wishes
Yours sincerely
NOEL CRICHTON-BROWNE

One could have hardly expected that the campaign then mounted by essentially the same people who are party to the current disgraceful campaign of character and Party assassination would have bettered themselves with their present efforts.

PARA.TAB: However, the modus operandi has not changed, if you cannot get your way through the ballot box at State Council or at any other forum of the Party, the tried and proved formula is to wreck and spoil the Party through the media.

PARA.EMPHASIS: ATTACK ON SENIOR PARTY OFFICIALS BY MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT—PHILLIP PENDAL

INTERJECT.PARA: Perhaps the most blatant attack upon officers of the Liberal Party by a member of parliament came from the Hon Phillip Pendal, then the Liberal Member for South Metropolitan Province.

In parliament under privilege but more particularly in a public forum, Mr Pendal first attacked the then chairman of the Central Campaign Committee in which he dredged up dirt upon Mr Bacich and then followed by a further attack upon the State President, Mr Barrie Payne.

Mr Pendal's excuse for publicly attacking the campaign chairman in the parliament was that he had complained to "very senior people in the Liberal Party in the state" but nothing had been done in response. That certainly leaves me with the feeling of deja vu.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Pendal went on to say

"a number of important things are happening with the Liberal Party in this state. There will be a bit more bloodshed before the day comes when the Liberal Party is restored to its former greatness. I believe that is not a long way down the track and I personally hope to see Mr Barrie Payne removed as the President of this state. . .

INTERJECT.PARA: I hope that people, most particularly the Liberals, around the state will come to understand that the Liberal Party has great difficulties. However, they are difficulties surrounding a very small clique of people who are not representative of true Liberalism and the sooner that the cancer is cut out the better the Liberal Party will be."
All of this was said in the parliament in front of the Labor Party with the media taking it all in.
Not one single member of State Executive moved a motion of condemnation, censure, suspension or expulsion of Mr Pendal.
Ironically Mr Bacich was expelled some time later for describing some of the front bench of the Liberal Party opposition as dunderheads.

Again, I make the point that there is a gulf of difference between my trifling, irreverent comments which are now being used as a ground for Liberal Party expulsion and a brutal and premeditated attack upon two senior members of the State Executive by Mr Phillip Pendal then a state member of parliament which attracted no action at all by the Party.

I do not claim precedence as the full measure of justice, however it demonstrated not only the varying standards of the Party but more particularly the contrast shows the shallow and feeble substance of this ground in the resolution before State Council as it relates to me.

I have on several occasions asked the State President to investigate or take action when public attacks have been made on me by people such as Mr Alistair Tomlinson, Mr Viner, Barbara-Dene Jones, Mrs Hector and Mr Eoin Cameron just to name a few. I have been singularly unsuccessful.
The expulsion motion against Alistair Tomlinson languished in the head office of the Party and then in the offices of Parker and Parker for months and was then finally withdrawn and he was promoted.

INTERJECT.PARA: As I have been moved to observe before, the Liberal Party is a body which is recognised and incorporated in the Australian Commonwealth Electoral Act and the recipient of very substantial public funding or as it is euphemistically described as taxpayers money. As such the organisation has a far greater responsibility in terms of its conduct and accountably than that one would expect from a small voluntary organisation such as a sporting body. To that extent the courts will entertain consideration such as the failure to comply with the organisations own rules, bias and matters that come under the grounds of denial of natural justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will take a little more than a minute to say this, and that is that the document is not definitive or exhaustive but it is a defence of the four grounds which were provided to me, however contrived, concocted and trivial they are, for my expulsion from the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill would understand that, while I am endorsed by the Liberal Party, I am elected by a million people in Western Australia. Those people would be very curious to know why I was a fit and proper person to be recommended to them to represent Western Australia in the Senate just some few short years ago and now am deemed not to be. While my primary object is to convey to the Liberal Party that there has been an aberration in their judgment, I do—to myself, my family and my constituents—have a responsibility to set down in a very clear and definitive way my rebuttal of those grounds, and this document does no more than that. If it were to be simply a document intended to attack the Liberal Party or members of it, it would in many respects, in my view, taint, dilute and damage its integrity.

This document has been written, in my view, with impeccable objectivity, care and detail. I thank Senator Hill. He will know that I have resisted all temptations in the last days to deny leave to the opposition for anything, because I trusted that in due course commonsense would prevail. The only people who will be disappointed by this incorporation, Senator Hill, are the Commonwealth car drivers: they tell me that they are having daily bets to see how many pages I can read in the given time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I intend to make a contribution on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, a committee on which I had the honour to serve. The committee produced a report entitled: The public interest revisited. But more fundamental than that is the question of integrity of our political structure.

PARA.TAB: Today our newspapers heralded headlines such as `She lied', `Lawrence a liar' and others of like nature. Those headlines were about a senior minister, Dr Carmen Lawrence. Today we witnessed the Democrats and Greens combining with Labor to defeat a call to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to sack Dr Lawrence. The implication of the vote is that the slogan of the Democrats should be changed from `keeping the bastards honest' to `keep the bastards honest, except if they happen to lie'.

When the evidence is so overwhelming that the conclusions reached by Mr Marks QC were to be expected, today we have witnessed all sorts of tactics, somersaults and empty rhetoric to somehow explain why the Greens, Democrats and Labor combined to defeat the motion moved by the opposition. However, I give credit to Senator Harradine who voted with us; he usually exercises a fair and genuine mind on these matters.

In the Senate report, entitled The public interest revisited, there is a section entitled `Ethics and attitudinal change'. We as a committee unanimously quoted, with approval, from the previous whistleblowing committee. It said that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . believed that recent programs in ethics and accountability, particularly in the public sector, would be a useful base from which to emphasise, in positive terms for the organisation and ultimately the public interest, the benefits of reporting wrongdoing, accepting such reports and taking appropriate investigative and corrective action.
The very next paragraph then tells us that:

Revised guidelines on official conduct of Commonwealth public servants were issued in March 1995. In launching the revised guidelines, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Mr Gary Johns MP, emphasised that—
and this is the important part of the quote—
`ethics and honesty were a key to modern and effective public service'.
Let me repeat that: ethics and honesty were a key to modern and effective public service.

PARA.TAB: Dr Lawrence has been found to be dishonest and to have acted improperly by Mr Marks QC. I wonder if Mr Johns thinks that Dr Lawrence is somehow involved in public service and that the standards he would set for public servants around this country should also apply to Dr Lawrence—that things such as `ethics and honesty are a key to modern and effective public service'.

But it is interesting to see how the Labor Party played out this Dr Lawrence issue. Dr Lawrence continually denied her involvement in the Easton petition. However, a former minister in her government, who also happens to be a minister of religion, Reverend Keith Wilson, found that it was necessary for him to blow the whistle on Dr Lawrence's denials.

It is interesting that on the front cover of this report The public interest revisited there is a newspaper headline reproduced `Tell and be damned'. Of course that is exactly what happened to Reverend Keith Wilson. He said, in effect, Dr Lawrence is lying. So what happened? A campaign was orchestrated to say that Reverend Wilson had a few problems; Reverend Wilson was this and Reverend Wilson was that and you really could not believe what he was saying. As a result of that campaign, another minister, a female minister, in Dr Lawrence's government felt compelled to come out and support Reverend Wilson in his allegations and statements because she thought he was being ostracised and treated most unfairly by the campaign to discredit him when he was in fact telling the truth.

Those of us who sat on this committee and took evidence all around the country heard time and time again what happens to you if you are a whistleblower trying to expose the truth. Those against whom you are telling the truth, who have something to hide, will come out and say, `They are a bit disturbed. You know they have not really got their facts together. Let's pity them. Let's belittle them and let's try to make them look a little bit foolish.' That is exactly what Labor people tried to do to Reverend Keith Wilson.

Dr Lawrence was found to be a liar not on the evidence of any Liberal Party member, National Party member or conservative person in politics but on the evidence of her own staff members who, under oath, felt the need and compulsion to tell the truth. Her former ministers, even her own Deputy Premier, had to give evidence and say she did tell a lie.

Dr Lawrence, through her legal counsel, tried to attack and belittle each one of those people in the methods and tactics of cross-examination. So it is quite appropriate that in relation to Mr Zoltan Kovacs, a former Lawrence staff member, Commissioner Marks found him to be a manifestly honest witness. He said, `Kovacs was deeply affected by what occurred.' He said, `. . . in my opinion his integrity is not in question.' One wonders whether anybody in the Greens, Democrats or Labor honestly can say the same thing about Dr Carmen Lawrence, that her integrity is not in question. Clearly, it is more than in question; it has been found to be wanting.

Today we also had what I consider to be quite an astounding attack on the findings, that somehow it all had to do with some men not liking women and so this was a way to try to attack a woman in public life. For those of us who read the papers, does Niki Savva from the Sun Herald have that view? Does Michelle Grattan from the Age have that view? Indeed, does Margo Kingston from the Sydney Morning Herald have that view? I hardly think so. But those journalists wrote, I think, pretty balanced articles about Dr Lawrence's future and what it ought to be. I suppose even the former female minister who felt compelled to speak out against what Dr Lawrence had done would also somehow hate women who have succeeded in public life. Really, all the arguments that have been put forward are unbelievable.
Also on the cover of this report The Public Interest Revisited is another headline `Crusaders for the truth'. Then there is a subheadline, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Whistleblowers are vital to anti-corruption inquiries . . . but they often suffer ostracism, abuse or the sack . . .

Who was involved in trying to establish the truth in this royal commission? It was Ms Vanstone QC. Remember her being attacked? Remember her being ostracised? Mr Marks QC, who had the job of sifting through all the evidence—remember him being attacked? Remember how he was vilified by the Prime Minister and other Labor Party people? That is exactly what happens to whistleblowers and the sorts of people who try to get at the truth.

PARA.TAB: I simply repeat the view of Mr Johns, a Labor minister, as to how public servants ought to act. He said that ethics and honesty were a key to modern and effective public service. I suggest that the Labor Party apply that standard to Dr Lawrence, that the Greens apply that standard and the Democrats apply that standard. If they did apply that standard, Dr Lawrence would do the honourable thing and resign. If she does not resign, then the Prime Minister ought to keep ethics and honesty high on the political agenda and sack her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My response to the months of allegations made by Senator Crichton-Browne about me will be very brief and to the point. As many who are close to me know to be fact, I have endured years of persecution by the senator, without response. If ever anyone has had cause to retaliate, it has been me.
—I agree.

—Thank you, Senator Collins. I acknowledge that interjection. I have chosen to ignore his threats and intimidation and get on with the job for which I have been elected, which is to represent the Liberal Party and also the people of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The assertions that have been made by the senator about my role in disclosing his record of domestic violence are just plain wrong. While I do admit to knowing of the most serious event, because he told me the day after what he had done, and he subsequently told others, I have not sought to use that against him in the six years that have elapsed, in spite of his greatest provocation.

It disturbed me, as a consequence, that the senator's estranged wife—whom, I might add, I assisted to stay in hiding for over 12 months—telephoned me just after midnight soon after the disclosure of the restraining order this year and accused me of betraying her trust. I also totally reject that, as my staff, friends and I had sought to be totally supportive and retain the expected respect for her position associated with such a totally distressing time.

I therefore reject absolutely the assertion that I somehow facilitated the use of my mailing list for the distribution of the facts surrounding these events. My staff have been most willing to sign statutory declarations that they too had no role in such facilitation. When one looks at the examples provided, it is clear that the format is different from that which is used by my office. The senator flatters himself to think that I or my staff would spend that much time in reformatting and retyping the entire mailing list for such a purpose.

Like many other people around Australia, I was sent a copy of the sheet detailing the tragic events. I have also been provided with envelopes containing mistakes identical to another colleague's mailing list. I do not for one moment suggest that that person is responsible for the distribution, but mention it to demonstrate further the preposterous nature of the allegations made specifically against me and my colleague the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron).

The honourable member for Stirling will respond for himself when he has an opportunity. However, I believe it suffices to say that the often repeated allegation of the senator about the Australian Federal Police finding incriminating evidence in Mr Cameron's computer has been proven to be incorrect according to none other than the police themselves.

Additionally, I would like to make reference to the ferocious allegations made against the Hon. Ian Viner QC that he too had betrayed the senator's estranged wife in his capacity as her lawyer. It needs to be put on the record that Mr Viner did not act as Mrs Crichton-Browne's lawyer but referred her to a lawyer in her desperate time of need. It should also be put on the record that the sheet containing the details of the senator's domestic violence had been circulated before Mr Viner gained access to a copy of the restraining order, and he did so only after the senator both protested his innocence and accused Mr Viner of lying about the existence of such an order.

There are many other colleagues, state and federal, former colleagues, party members and staff who are subject to gross abuse in the said document, which has now been incorporated. I know that the senator has a long, deep and abiding loathing of a number of those mentioned. There needs to be no other explanation of his accusations against them than

SPEECH.PARA: just that. I could provide much more evidence of the whole sordid affair, but I will continue to resist that temptation.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I wish to state that I find this whole saga so unnecessary and unsavoury, as I have found the years of personal persecution that I have had to endure. However, I did need to place on the public record the truth. Sadly, the senator's performance has been the best possible display I have ever seen of pseudologia fantastica. I rest my case.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) When and by whom was application made to the Foreign Investment Review Board for approval for the purchase, on 17 March 1994, by Indonesian interests (through JGL Trading Pte Ltd, a company resident in Singapore with directors resident in Hong Kong) of the 50 per cent ownership of the Euphron Pty Ltd piggery group previously owned by the Prime Minister.
(2) When did the FIRB recommend approval of this request and when was it approved.
(3)(a) Was the approval unconditional or were there conditions to it; and (b) will a copy of that approval be tabled.
(4) Were the FIRB and the Treasurer advised that the interest being sold on 17 March 1994 had been held by the Prime Minister until only 10 days previously.

(5) Did the FIRB inquire whether the transaction was bona fide in respect of the real status of the purported vendor, Mr Constantinidis, who was selling the Prime Minister's shareholding in line with a draft memorandum or understanding for the sale, dated 3 days before the Prime Minister says he disposed of his interest to Mr Constantinidis, so avoiding the need for the Prime Minister to disclose any potential conflict of interest before the FIRB and the Treasurer.
(6) If the FIRB was aware that this application related to the Prime Minister's half-ownership of the piggery group being sold overseas, did it alert the Treasurer to this fact.

(7) Was the existence of a `re-purchase' option, as revealed in the draft memorandum of understanding, under which up to one-third of the company could be restored to Australian ownership, so lifting Australian control to 66.7 per cent, taken into account in the decision of the FIRB.
(8) Will the FIRB release all documents relating to this approval.
(9) To what extent has this alteration to Australian ownership affected the FIRB amended approval given in December 1992 for the Danpork joint venture in which Euphron Pty Ltd is a partner.
(10) What amendments to this approval have taken place since December 1992.
(11) Are there any further applications at present before the FIRB relating to this group of companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (3) JGL Trading Pte Ltd, applied on 28 March 1994, through its solicitors for foreign investment approval to acquire a 50 per cent interest in Euphron Pty Limited. Foreign investment applications in respect of the agriculture/farming sector are normally readily approved unless assessed as contrary to the national interest. Under established processes for the administration of policy, proposals involving the acquisition of a substantial interest in a company or business with total assets below $50 million and not in a designated sensitive sector, are normally not subject to detailed examination.

On the basis that the assets of Euphron were valued at less than $50 million, no detailed examination of the proposal was required and the parties were advised on 7 April 1994, in accordance with the usual FIRB procedures, that there were no objections to the proposal in terms of the Government's foreign investment policy. No conditions were imposed.
(4) to (7) Transactions between Australian interests are not required to be advised to the FIRB and they do not require foreign investment approval.
(8) No. It is long standing practice and a basic aspect of the administration of foreign investment policy that commercially sensitive or confidential documents are not released.
(9) & (10) The changes in ownership do not affect any previous approval.

(11) On 20 September 1995, no objections were raised under foreign investment policy to an application from another foreign interest to acquire the other 50 per cent of the assets of Euphron Pty Limited and associated companies. This application also involved assets less than $50 million.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Mineral Exploration and Mining on Commonwealth Land

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the inter-departmental committee on mineral exploration and mining on Commonwealth land, currently chaired by the Minister:
(1) What is the composition of the inter-departmental committee.
(2) What are its terms of reference.
(3) What is the timeline for the committee's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Responsibility for policy and management of mineral exploration on Commonwealth land in general rests with the Minister for Administrative Services.

An inter-departmental meeting was held in June 1994 in response to an application for an exploration licence for mining on Garden Island, Western Australia, following a recommendation by the Western Australian Mining Warden to grant such a licence. This meeting was chaired by Defence and attended by representatives of the Australian Heritage Commission, the Commonwealth Environmental Protection Agency and Australian Estate Management. The outcome of this one meeting was that Defence should seek legal opinion as to the ownership of the mineral rights on Garden Island. Legal opinion received was that the Commonwealth owned the mineral rights to that area. No further meetings were therefore necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the cause of the grounding of the Navy's Fleet Air Arm helicopters, as reported in the Canberra Times of 8 October 1995.
(2) What action was taken to inspect the helicopters while they were grounded.
(3)(a) What problems were identified; and (b) was any rectification required.
(4) What other issues were raised at a forum of naval officers in Sydney.
(5) What action is being taken in response to the concerns raised by the officers at the forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Navy's Fleet Air Arm helicopters were not grounded as suggested in the Canberra Times. Rather, the HS 817 Squadron's operations were temporarily suspended to permit an aviation operations audit to take place.

The squadron was found to be in a satisfactory state, but HS 817 Squadron aircrew had lapsed in certain currency requirements due to reduced aircraft availabilities which had resulted from the aircraft's life of type extension, stores support problems and the loss of the Sea King at Bamaga.

The audit team provided advice to the squadron on how to regain currencies and correct a number of documentation anomalies and the squadron was released to flying operations for the purpose of conducting a work up program on 6 October 1995. Having regained flying currencies and having implemented the recommendations of the audit team, the squadron was subsequently released to resume full operational tasking on 24 October 1995.

The other Fleet Air Arm squadrons, HC 723 and HS 816 Squadrons, were also audited for aircrew currencies and qualifications, flying safety and training, but these squadrons did not have their operations suspended as they were found to be in a satisfactory state.

(2) The helicopters were not grounded and there were no concerns raised at the naval symposium about the airworthiness of any Royal Australian Navy (RAN) aircraft. Therefore, the aircraft were not inspected.
(3)(a) and (b) See answer to (2) above.

(4) The issues discussed at the naval symposium are too numerous and wide-ranging to mention individually in responding to the honourable senator's question. I can, however, provide Senator Newman with a copy of the naval symposium papers when they are published.
(5) See answer to (1) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that, although the Australian Executive Service Overseas Program Ltd (AESOP) obtains over 99 per cent of its funds for its overseas aid program from the Commonwealth, the terms of the grant agreement with AusAID preclude the Commonwealth from obtaining information about salaries paid to AESOP staff.
(2) Do AESOP's financial statements disclose that the managing director's remuneration in the 1994-95 financial year amounted to $137,873.
(3) What redress does the Commonwealth have against the board of a non-Government organisation that apparently allows such a high level of remuneration to be acquired by its employee.

(4) Is the Minister aware of the claim by a former director of the AESOP Board that the full board never authorised the remuneration paid to its managing director and furthermore was never aware of its extent.
(5) What records exist within AESOP that provide authority for the remuneration that has been acquired by its managing director.

(6) Did independent auditors recommend in April 1995 that the board should investigate whether any amounts received in the 1993-94 financial year by the managing director in excess of the remuneration incorrectly stated in the financial statements, approximately $22,000 less than the actual amount, were properly authorised, and that any unauthorised payments be refunded to AESOP.
(7) Has that investigation been carried out; if so, what was the result.

(8) Will the Minister seek the co-operation of AESOP's chairman in ascertaining whether the managing director's present remuneration package still contains, as it did in the 1994 financial year, a salary component of $95,000, employer superannuation contribution of $13,520, employer health insurance contribution of $1,400, provision for spouse airfare for an overseas trip, fully maintained motor vehicle and other benefits.

(9) Did independent auditors report in April 1995 that, of the approximately $146,000 paid by the managing director to himself as travel advances and travel expenses in a little over three years, some $15,000 had not been properly acquitted.
(10) Did the managing director inform the independent auditors that the relevant documentation had been stolen from his office drawer.
(11) Did the independent auditors recommend that the board investigate the missing documentation and the factors surrounding their disappearance.
(12) Has this investigation been undertaken; if so, has the board reached the conclusion that a theft occurred within AESOP.

(13) What consideration has the board given to the recommendation of the independent auditors that any unauthorised payments or unsubstantiated and/or unacquitted cash advances be refunded to AESOP by the managing director.

(14) Did the independent auditors report that, in breach of the grant agreement, AESOP had not repaid the unexpended part of its grant each year and that the outstanding amount, between $145,000 and $273,578, should be repaid to AusAID, or alternatively, the grant agreement amended.
(15) What action has been taken by the board and/or AusAID in this matter.

(16) Did the independent auditors report that, in breach of the grant agreement, funds for overseas aid had been used to make a substantial out of court cash settlement to a former AESOP employee; (b) that AESOP should repay the amount from non-AusAID sourced funds; (c) the payment be treated as a recurrent cost; and (d) the grant agreement be amended to allow for such out of court settlements.
(17) What action has been taken by the board and/or AusAID in this matter.

(18) In light of the numerous reported breaches of the grant agreement by AESOP, does the Minister propose to have the agreement amended and renegotiated in order to provide for greater safeguards in the use of public funds.

(19) Has the board reported to AusAID yet on the circumstances which led to the payment of $33,245 to the AESOP representative in Thailand during the 1992-93 financial year, while AESOP's 14 other overseas representatives were paid a total of $12,324 in that year.
(20) Has the board reviewed all AESOP's overseas representatives' agreements, as recommended by the independent auditors; if so, what was the outcome.

(21) In view of the fact that AESOP funds are almost entirely Commonwealth money and that AESOP should therefore be publicly accountable, will the Minister make available to the public the independent auditors' report as well as the AESOP board's response to it.

(22) Is the Minister satisfied that AESOP Board members, including those members nominated by James Hardie Industries, Shell Company of Australia, HDC Group, the Order of Australia Association, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the members elected by the returned volunteers, are adequately informed of their duties as company directors, and have been made aware of the standards of management, reporting and acquittance required in the use of public funds.

(23) Could the Minister confirm that, in the 10 years AESOP has been incorporated, there has been only one woman member on the AESOP board and that she was elected by the returned volunteers, not nominated by the organisation and foundation members.

(24) Did the Minister for Development Co-operation and Pacific Island Affairs advise on 25 July 1995 that AusAID's nominee on the board would act positively to ensure that AESOP takes gender issues fully into account.

(25) Did the chairman of the AESOP Board state on 23 August 1995 that, in order to comply with Government's policy for gender equality among the membership of the AESOP Board, the nominating organisations would in future be asked to nominate a woman if a suitable candidate is available.

(26) Could the Minister advise whether there have been any changes in the structure of the membership of the AESOP board since 25 July 1995; if so, did any changes involve the nomination by an organisation member of a male person to the board of AESOP.

(27) Can an assurance be given that both AusAID and AESOP are committed to, and are acting fully in accordance with, both the letter and the spirit of the guidelines mentioned above in order to bring about the nomination of women to the board of AESOP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. AESOP was established on private sector lines to provide volunteer services mainly to the private sector. A clause in the Agreement precludes access to personal material about individuals and commercial information obtained from clients on a confidential basis. Both types of information are normally kept confidential by commercial companies. However, the AESOP Board does consult AusAID over key decisions and the annual Financial Statement reports expenditure on the Managing Director's salary package.
(2) The financial statement disclosed a salary package of $137,873. This included $12,023 for fringe benefits tax.

(3) AusAID has no formal legal redress as AESOP is registered under the Companies Act as an independent company. AusAID is represented on the Board, but the Board is responsible to the company under Corporations Law and not the Government. However, the continuing funding of AESOP is subject to an annual allocation of funding approved by the Minister for Development Cooperation.

(4) I am advised by AESOP that negotiation of the Managing Director's remuneration was previously delegated by the Board to its Finance Sub-committee which reported back to the Board when negotiations had been completed. This practice has been altered in 1995. Remuneration conditions for the Managing Director are now agreed by the full Board.
(5) I am advised by AESOP that the Finance Committee maintained minute books.
(6) Yes.
(7) Yes. The AESOP Board has advised that there were no unauthorised payments.

(8) AusAID has consulted the AESOP Chairman, who has advised that the recommendations of an independent salary review by Coopers and Lybrand have been implemented. The review recommended a salary equivalent to Band 1 of the APS SES (ie in the order of $100,000). None of the non-salary components referred to in the question apply in the new package.

(9) The independent auditors report stated that "since 1 July 1991 approximately $146,000 has been paid to Mr Cheatley in the form of reimbursement of expenses or cash advances, of which an approximate amount of $15,000 has not been properly acquitted " (p.12).

(12) Yes. The Chairman of the AESOP Board has advised that the Board received a report from the Managing Director advising of the missing documentation and the steps taken to improve security. As there was a time gap between the document loss and the Board being advised it was considered no benefit would result from Police investigation.

(13) The AESOP Board has advised that: there were no unacquitted cash advances for travel; the Managing Director's travel had been approved in advance; his travel expenses had been "signed off" by the Treasurer in the course of normal quarterly reporting procedures; and, to the Treasurer's best recollections, the documentation now missing had been made available to him. The Board noted that Coopers and Lybrand had audited the previous year's acquittals and found appropriate documentation. Procedures have been implemented to ensure greater control over accounting for cash advances.
(15) Positive discussions have taken place between AusAID and AESOP on this issue. A number of complicated accounting issues are involved. The issue will be finalised in the near future.
(16) The independent auditors report noted payment of an out of court cash settlement. The report provided the following options:
the unfair dismissal settlement be treated as a "recurrent cost"; or
amendment to the Agreement to allow for such expenditures; or
requesting payment (refund) of the unfair dismissal settlement amount.
repay the unfair dismissal settlement from non-AIDAB sourced funds."

(17) The issue has been discussed between AusAID and AESOP. AusAID has accepted AESOP's view that recruitment and dismissal costs are standard operational costs for business and that they should be treated as recurrent costs.

(18) AusAID is currently reviewing the standard Grant Agreement on the basis of legal advice from the Australian Government Solicitor. When this review is completed it will be used as a basis for renegotiating agreements with all NGOs and volunteer organisations currently funded by AusAID, including AESOP.

(19) The Chairman of the AESOP Board has advised that the Board has carried out the first stage of a review of the terms and conditions for overseas representatives of AESOP. The Board is conscious of the relatively high cost of its operation in Thailand and is evaluating the merits of continuing present arrangements. Further consideration was to be given at the Board meeting on 10 November 1995.
(20) Refer to response to question (19).

(21) Subject to any legal considerations, the audit report will be made available to the public together with the report of the follow-up audit by BDO. The follow-up audit is expected to commence shortly to examine AESOP's response to and implementation of each of the recommendations contained in the audit report dated 24 March 1995.

(22) Members of the AESOP Board are typically senior, experienced business people from the private sector, who are nominated by major companies supporting AESOP. The Chairman of the AESOP Board has advised that advice on the duties of company directors has not therefore been considered necessary. AusAID has suggested that the Board might consider providing some form of advice on their duties and responsibilities.
(26) The Chairman of the AESOP Board has advised that there have been no changes in Board membership since the 25 July 1995.
(27) The Chairman of the AESOP Board has advised that the Board is conscious of the lack of female representation and has minuted that when the opportunity arises a letter will be sent to mem-

ANSWER.PARA: ber organisations requesting nomination of a woman to the Board if a suitable candidate is available.
